"items":[{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361409964693","timestampUsec":"1361409964693161","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/edf575bfd1d7a5b1","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Ubuntu Phone","Ubuntu Tablet","developer","ubuntu phone","ubuntu-tablet"],"title":"What To Expect from the Ubuntu Touch Developer Preview","published":1361406208,"updated":1361406208,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-touch-developer-preview-coming-tomorrow-heres-why-you-shouldnt-get-too-excited"
}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/67-JW93C8f8/ubuntu-touch-developer-preview-coming-tomorrow-heres-why-you-shouldnt-get-too-excited","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/multitask.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"multitask\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/multitask.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"255\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eLater today a developer preview of Ubuntu Touch will be made available to download and install on a handful of Nexus devices.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth the Phone interface and the newly unveiled Tablet interfaces will be distributed; the type of device you’re installing on deciding which Ubuntu Touch format you get.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith anticipation for the touch-centric interfaces unquenchable, many of folks will be planning to sacrifice a stable Android install for a chance to toy around with the newest \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phablet\"\u003ePhablet\u003c/a\u003e phenomenon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut is that a wise thing to do?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu’s Show-home\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eTomorrow’s preview releases will be a show home for the Ubuntu touch experience.\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen property developer’s are trying to sell houses on a plot of land prior to building them they create a ‘show home’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA show home is a real house that’s finished and furnished to a high standard – but only at face value. So while the bathroom may look great it’s probably not plumbed in, and those big spacious-feeling rooms won’t feel quite so spacious once they’re full of ‘real life’ clutter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe aim of a show-home is to give buyers an impression; a vision; something that’s easier to imagine living in than that offered by a styro-foam model and set of blueprints. It is an \u003cem\u003eexample.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTomorrow’s preview releases will be a show home for the Ubuntu touch experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough what will be available \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e working code it shouldn’t be taken as being finished code. Start scratching the surface you’ll find the code equivalent of waxed fruit…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eI Don’t Know These People!\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWriting this at 10 PM GMT on Feburary 20th, the day before the preview releases have even been built, I can’t definitively say what will or won’t be featured.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut I do know that current builds of the Touch Preview make heavy use of ‘dummy data’. The homescreen, lens and scopes are chock full of people, things and items that aren’t actually there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShould this data be removed from the Nexus images then expect your initial Ubuntu Phablet experience to seem less rounded than that from the videos.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, though the slick video demos and screenshots show off a launcher and app tray stuffed full of a variety of apps most of these are actually just prettified links to websites – something that might be disappointing to realise should you not know in advance!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotable app inclusions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDialler\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMessaging App (SMS)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBasic web-browser\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGallery App\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCamera App\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCalculator\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNotable app omissions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNo IM app\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNo music player\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNo e-mail client\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNo ‘App Store’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNo Ubuntu One app\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf the applications that are there be prepared to encounter bugs, quirks, and the odd performance issue (e.g. pinch to zoom in the web-browser is horrendous).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRelax, It’s Just a Preview\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo now I’ve lowered your expectations – and if I haven’t then proceed directly to the start of this post – let’s focus on the positives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAside from looking swish, and running pretty damn well, the intrinsic framework of Ubuntu Touch – the gestures – are in place and working. Vital stuff and it’s there from day dot.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo too are other core input methods like typing, speech recognition, selecting text, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe demo apps available – gallery, calculator, messages, etc – are first class and will serve as interactive inspiration for app developers and designers alike, whilst giving curious users a hint at the sort of app experiences they can expect in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd the unique interface features like ‘sidestage’, indicators, and task-switching are all present for developers to get to grips with.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe long story made short is that while tomorrow brings a release of Ubuntu Touch to the public it’s a very early, work-in-progress release that is not aimed at the general user.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTo borrow from the show-home analogy one last time: feel free to step inside and take a look around, but you won’t want to be making it your home for a while yet…\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d67-JW93C8f8:zgo5Yux46ew:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361353748621","timestampUsec":"1361353748621834","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/330f1d6ca2682815","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Video",
"accessibility","voice recognition"],"title":"Powerful Voice Recognition Demoed for Ubuntu","published":1361353728,"updated":1361353728,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/power-voice-recognition-demoed-for-ubuntu-video"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/n93hcXcZtwU/power-voice-recognition-demoed-for-ubuntu-video","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA powerful voice recognition tool has been demoed on Ubuntu by Linux developer James McClain.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing voice alone you will be able to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLaunch and close applications\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOpen websites\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePerform basic file management\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHandle dictation\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSend ‘Notes/Reminders’ to an e-mail address\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAnswer questions\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll of the above, and a few other tricks, can be viewed in the following video demonstration by McClain:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/HfrQrjH3AGw?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow It Works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA simple overview of how the tool works would look something like this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUser presses hot-key\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUser speaks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eVoice recognition ran (using Google)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eResults matched to app ‘dictionary’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCommands/Modes run if matched in dictionary\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRather neat is that ‘fuzzy searching’ is enabled in the utility, meaning that, potentially, users can launch an app, or open a website using different terms. For example ‘start firefox’, ‘open firefox’, ‘run firefox’ \u0026amp; ‘launch firefox’ would all result in the same action.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat’s smart. It allows you to express yourself in a more natural way. For example, I don’t say that i ‘run’ Firefox, but ‘open’ Firefox.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy not forcing you to remember a fixed set of commands the tool will feel more intuitive and helpful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcClain says that it will be easy for developers to add their own commands and functions to the app dictionary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA private beta will be released to a small number of developers shortly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dn93hcXcZtwU:42nvtY5kSdE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg "Video","android"],"title":"Introducing the Best Way to Read OMG! Ubuntu! on the Go","published":1361305247,"updated":1361305247,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/omgubuntu-android-app-download"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/INAbZr6jis8/omgubuntu-android-app-download","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/phone.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"phone\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/phone.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOne of the easiest ways to get notified of new posts by your favourite websites is to add their RSS feed to a feed reader.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut while RSS feeds are versatile - and the #1 choice for those keeping tracks of hundreds of websites – they do have flaws.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike in presentation, for example. RSS feeds can’t be ‘styled’ meaning that themed elements - including text, image captions \u0026amp; alignment, and buttons – don’t appear how they should.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, being Linux users, we’re fans of choice. And one of the choices that we think you folks deserve is a way to get all the benefits of our full-article RSS feed but without losing any of the design gumption on the main site, or sacrificing mobility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOMG! Ubuntu! for Android\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/N8zHLtojasA?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur new Android app offers the best way to read posts from OMG! Ubuntu! while in bed, on the commute, in a queue, or wherever else you want to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe application offers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNotifications of new posts\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOffline cache\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAbility to ‘star’ posts for easy access later\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNative Android design\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e‘Web intents’ will let you open links to OMG! in app\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBrowse by category\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eComment support\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCategory browsing\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHomescreen \u0026amp; Lockscreen widgets\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOther Ways to Read OMG! Ubuntu!\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow we know that not everyone wants to install a sole app dedicated to one site. And we totally understand that; we’re all about the choices, remember?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe offer a variety of ways to read and be notified of new posts on OMG! Ubuntu! including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"OMG! rss\" href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/d0od\"\u003eRSS\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGoogle Currents\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAny web-browser on any OS on any device\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChrome Extension\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYour local neighbour hood psychic.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, we might be lying about the last one, but you get the picture. These are in addition to following us on \u003ca href\u003d\"http://google.com/+omgubuntu\"\u003eGoogle+, \u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://facebook.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eFacebook\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"http://twitter.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eTwitter\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFuture ways to digest our tasty content will include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Phone App\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFirefox Extension\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGet the App\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst things first: if you have our old Android application installed we advise that you remove it pronto. Not only is it broken, but it won’t be getting updated any time soon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe new app is brand spankin’ new. It’s been built from the ground up to look and work better than our old one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id\u003dcom.ohso.omgubuntu\" title\u003d\"download omgubuntu android app\"\u003e OMG! Ubuntu! for Android on Google Play \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOMG! Chrome! readers don’t need to panic – we’ll be launching a Chrome-coloured version of the app in the coming weeks…\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dINAbZr6jis8:ZyxOX1J3m2Y:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/INAbZr6jis8\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"Video","canonical","ubuntu-tablet"],"title":"The Official Ubuntu Tablet Videos","published":1361303325,"updated":1361303325,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/the-official-ubuntu-tablet-videos"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/lfk9DXRzGjs/the-official-ubuntu-tablet-videos","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIts announcement may only be a few hours old, but the new Ubuntu Tablet interface is already being met with a phenomenal level of praise from users and developers alike.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"font-family:Raleway,Ubuntu,\u0026#39;Helvetica Neue\u0026#39;,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif;font-size:14px;line-height:24px\"\u003eAlongside the who, what, why and when that was \u003ca style\u003d\"font-weight:bold\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu Tablet Unveiled By Canonical\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-for-tablet-unveiled-by-canonical-nexus-7-download-coming-thursday\"\u003erevealed earlier today\u003c/a\u003e Canonical published two slick presentation videos to demonstrate its features and behaviour.\u003cb\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first of these, the ‘trailer’ version, is short and ‘to-the-point’. It touches on the core interface quirks and is great for giving a – and don’t hate me for using the word – swish overview.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/5_4fXQcxFRs?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, as was the case for the Ubuntu Phone announcement back in January, Canonical also have also produced a longer video.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClocking in at some 6 minutes, this one goes into greater detail about the tablet interface, its new ‘Side-stage’ multi-tasking feature, and a host of other bits and pieces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361290593965","timestampUsec":"1361290593965960","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/52780a61090e79c5","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","News","Ubuntu Tablet",
"convergence","multidevice","ubuntu","ubuntu-tablet"],"title":"Ubuntu Tablet Unveiled By Canonical","published":1361289828,"updated":1361289828,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-for-tablet-unveiled-by-canonical-nexus-7-download-coming-thursday"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/4aFZ-ZULxTQ/ubuntu-for-tablet-unveiled-by-canonical-nexus-7-download-coming-thursday","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/tablet-media-player-large.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"tablet-media-player-large\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/tablet-media-player-large.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"474\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConfirming the expected, Canonical have unveiled a new ‘tablet’ face for Ubuntu as part of their focus on \u003cem\u003econvergence \u003c/em\u003eacross devices.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tablet-orientated version of Ubuntu is based on Ubuntu Touch – the same version used on Ubuntu Phones – so is gesture-heavy in use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNexus 7 and Nexus 10 owners will be able to download and ‘flash’ Ubuntu Touch onto their devices this coming Thursday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut \u003ca title\u003d\"HTC Making Ubuntu Tablet? Countdown Sync Fuels Speculation [Squashed]\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/htc-ubuntu-countdown-sync-fuels-tablet-speculation\"\u003edespite last-minute speculation\u003c/a\u003e no hardware partners intending to pre-install the device have been announced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInterface \u0026amp; Features\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/5_4fXQcxFRs?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Tablet is based on the same code that powers the Phone version of Ubuntu – so strong emphasis is placed on gestures. The edges of the device are the principle means of navigations as demoed in the video above; like Ubuntu phone, the tablet interface doesn’t require hard or soft keys to be present for use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOren Horev, lead designer for the Ubuntu tablet experience, says that tablet interface \u003cem\u003e‘fits perfectly between Phone and PC in the Ubuntu Family’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Not only do we integrate phone apps in a distinctive way,’ \u003c/em\u003ehe says,\u003cem\u003e ’[but] we shift from tablet to PC very smoothly in convergence devices.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eConvergence\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, Canonical have placed some emphasis on business-orientated applications, touting tablets running Ubuntu as “convergence devices”, offering a full desktop experience when connected to a keyboard and mouse, as well as a business-friendly “thin client” that supports existing enterprise solutions for running Windows applications.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs with the “convergence” feature on the Ubuntu Phone, only “high-end” devices can make use of this feature. Canonical have \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.ubuntu.com/devices/tablet/partner\"\u003eoutlined\u003c/a\u003e minimum tablet specifications for partners to target both “entry level consumer” and these “high-end enterprise” audiences.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEntry Level\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDual-core Cortex A15\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e2GB RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e8GB Flash Storage\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e7-10″ Screen\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHigh-End \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eQuad-core A15 or Intel x86\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4GB RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e8GB Flash Storage\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e10-12″ Screen\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eMultitasking\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMuch like Windows 8′s “Snap” feature, the Ubuntu Tablet interface introduces a new feature called ‘Side Stage’. This feature allows you to run both “tablet apps” and “phone apps” side by side, resizing each on the hop as and when you need to see more of them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/multitask.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"multitask\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/multitask.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"255\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eMulti-user Support\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntroduced only recently on Google’s Android operating system, multi-user support arrives out the door with Ubuntu on tablets. Full disk encryption ensures accounts on both a family and enterprise device stay secure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOther\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAside from the shiny stuff, the tablet interface will support screen sizes from 6″ to 20″, placing it firmly between the Phone and PC form factors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownloads\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownloads for the Google Nexus 7 and Google Nexus 10 will be available alongside Ubuntu Phone images on February 21st.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Touch for Tablets Announced\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduces new multi-tasking feature \u0026amp; security options\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDownloads for select hardware available Thursday \u003cstrong\u003e21st February\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSource code available Thursday \u003cstrong\u003e21st February\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d4aFZ-ZULxTQ:uZ9pnKOnYcw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/4aFZ-ZULxTQ\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361276396993","timestampUsec":"1361276396993765","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/6a383750d8d69e37","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","News","htc",
"rumour mill","ubuntu-tablet"],"title":"HTC Making Ubuntu Tablet? Countdown Sync Fuels Speculation [Squashed]","published":1361274291,"updated":1361274291,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/htc-ubuntu-countdown-sync-fuels-tablet-speculation"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/xLY2ZWpehag/htc-ubuntu-countdown-sync-fuels-tablet-speculation","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/clocks.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"clocks\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/clocks.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"231\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e The HTC media event has passed without mention of anything Ubuntu. This rumour is therefore squashed. \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt’s either a masterstroke of timing or an unfortunate coincidence but both Canonical and Taiwanese smartphone \u0026amp; tablet makers HTC are to make important new product announcements later this evening.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt 4PM GMT Canonical will be taking the wrapper off of what is widely expected to be a tablet version of their ‘Ubuntu Touch’ OS. Meanwhile, HTC are due to announce their new flagship \u003ca href\u003d\"http://phandroid.com/2013/02/18/htc-one-teasers/\"\u003eHTC One\u003c/a\u003e Android handset – and a \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.brandonholtsclaw.com/blog/2013/ubuntu-tablet-is-the-hardware-htc\"\u003enew mystery tablet-sized device\u003c/a\u003e - to a legion of mobile journalists.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCould these events somehow be related?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSerendipitous Timing\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe short answer is we don’t know. Prior to Canonical’s countdown going online few were expecting an announcement from them. And the usual ‘industry sources’ close to HTC and their ilk have yet to breathe word of some sort of tie-up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLack of rumour isn’t proof that nothing is happening of course, but it does nudge hope of a HTC Ubuntu Touch tablet into ‘unlikely’ territory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut does that mean that it’s out of the realm of possibility? Certainly not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe already know that \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" title\u003d\"First Ubuntu Phones ‘Available October’, Says Shuttleworth\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/first-ubuntu-phone-available-october-says-shuttleworth\"\u003ethe first Ubuntu Phone handsets will be coming later this year\u003c/a\u003e so at least one hardware manufacturer and/or carrier has taken a punt on the upstart OS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThankfully the suspense won’t be drawn out for much longer. Both companies are staging press conferences later this evening.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSo whether we see the reveal of a physical Ubuntu tablet or just a tablet-focused OS, today is certainly going to be an exciting one for Ubuntu users…\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dxLY2ZWpehag:N7wEUrIVqeE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361213099522","timestampUsec":"1361213099522326","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/8f71cb11a89a23af","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","News","Ubuntu Tablet",
"ubuntu phone","ubuntu-tablet"],"title":"Ubuntu Gearing up For Tablet Announcement Tomorrow","published":1361210380,"updated":1361210380,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-gearing-up-for-tablet-announcement-tomorrow"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/6ebVYz_3KjE/ubuntu-gearing-up-for-tablet-announcement-tomorrow","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu-website-tablet-countdown.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"ubuntu-website-tablet-countdown\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu-website-tablet-countdown.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"357\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Ubuntu website is once again displaying a countdown - \u003ca title\u003d\"All-New Ubuntu Product to Launch Jan 2nd – But What Is It?\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/all-new-ubuntu-product-to-launch-jan-2nd-but-what-is-it\"\u003esimilar to the one \u003c/a\u003eshown ahead of January’s Ubuntu Phone announcement.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext to the clock sits a not-so-subtle clue about the purpose of the countdown that reads: ‘\u003cem\u003eTick, tock, tablet time!\u003c/em\u003e‘\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnless Canonical decide to throw a curveball into the mix here by announcing the release of an Ubuntu-powered graphics tablet I think we can all\u003cem\u003e safely\u003c/em\u003e assume that the reveal will concern the next step in Canonical’s ‘multi-device strategy’ – namely, tablets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu Touch \u003d Tablet, Too?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAside from the presence of a countdown there is, for now at least, little else to go on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf\u003c/em\u003e Canonical are announcing a tablet version of Unity then what form is it likely to take? Will it be based on the Ubuntu Phone OS code? Or will it be some form of rejigged Compiz-powered Unity?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMy money is on the former.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the same way that Android powers both smartphones and tablets (albeit with marginal interface differences between the two) so too do I imagine that the ‘Ubuntu Phone OS’ – more accurately known as Ubuntu Touch – will.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt makes sense, after all. Ubuntu Touch has been designed from the ground up to be gesture-centric. Confining such an experience solely to small smartphone screens would be a waste.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu Tablets Aren’t New\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu isn’t a stranger to tablets. Over the years it has been ported to run across a wide range of devices – \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/category/ubuntu-tablet-2\"\u003eas a quick browse of our Ubuntu Tablet category will show.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost recently it was \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Nexus 7 Installer App Released to Devs\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/ubuntu-installer-for-nexus-7-tablet-made-available-for-devs\"\u003eshoehorned on to the Google Nexus 7\u003c/a\u003e so that developers could tune Unity and the Ubuntu desktop to be more performant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSignificant performance boosts have already landed on the Ubuntu 13.04 desktop because of this decision. Unity (and Ubuntu in general) have never felt so fluid and lightweight.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut none of these ‘Ubuntu Tablet’s’ have actually been an Ubuntu tablet. They’ve been ‘Ubuntu desktop on a tablet’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTomorrows announcement will likely rectify that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTablet Timing\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe timing of the tomorrows announcement is also curious. It’s being made just days \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Downloads To Be Released Next Week\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-phone-downloads-to-be-released-next-week\"\u003ebefore the source code for “Ubuntu Phone OS” is released\u003c/a\u003e alongside installable images for the Samsung Galaxy Nexus and LG Nexus 4.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the Nexus 7 already having history with Ubuntu development could it be likely that an install image for it, – and it’s bigger sibling the Nexus 10 – also see release on that date?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe good news is that we won’t have to wait long to find out. 6PM GMT will reveal all… \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6ebVYz_3KjE:KwovTVuExkM:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d6ebVYz_3KjE:KwovTVuExkM:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6ebVYz_3KjE:KwovTVuExkM:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6ebVYz_3KjE:KwovTVuExkM:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "raring ringtail","shopping lens"],"title":"Ubuntu to Add ‘Incognito’ Mode to Unity Dash \u0026amp; Legal Notice to Installer","published":1361193930,"updated":1361193930,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-dash-to-add-private-incognito-mode-add-legal-notice-to-installer"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/MrlsT5TrU1c/ubuntu-dash-to-add-private-incognito-mode-add-legal-notice-to-installer","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/original-shopping-lens.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"original-shopping-lens\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/original-shopping-lens.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu founder Mark Shuttleworth has revealed how the OS will address the on-going privacy concerns around its online searching feature in Unity.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost notably amongst his plans is the introduction of an incognito-style mode for ‘anonymizing’ Dash sessions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBest Way to Handle it\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrivacy concerns \u003ca title\u003d\"Shopping Lens Fuore\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/tag/shopping-lens\"\u003ehave dogged\u003c/a\u003e Ubuntu since the introduction of the ‘Shopping Lens’ in Ubuntu 12.10.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral concessions were made shortly after its arrival to appease critics, including an off-switch and legal notice link on display in the Dash at all times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/unity/+bug/1111808\"\u003ein a bug report\u003c/a\u003e concerning where the Legal Link opens, Shuttleworth has revealed a three-step plan for ‘handling’ the feature in future Ubuntu releases:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePutting Legal notices in one place (as well adding one to the installer)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdding an ‘incognito’ style toggle in the Dash for anonymous browsing\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIncluding individual toggles for scopes and lenses for customisation\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe second of these options will likely disable all online searches/results in the same way as as the current “on/off” toggle located in the \u003cem\u003ePrivacy\u003c/em\u003e pane of \u003cem\u003eSystem Settings \u003c/em\u003edoes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Toggle it, right there in the Dash, and you are totally certain you are not sending network traffic,” \u003c/em\u003eShuttleworth explains, going on to add that, for total peace of mind, this network-halting toggle will ‘be enforced at the kernel level’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJoining the toggle will be what many Privacy proponents have been seeking: an up-front message in the installer. It’s as yet unclear whether this will have an “opt-out” toggle clearly displayed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese two new approaches join the one we already know about: per-scope toggling.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis feature, announced alongside \u003ca title\u003d\"Unity to Ship with Smarter Dash Search in 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/unity-to-ship-with-smarter-scope-searching-in-13-04\"\u003ethe new ‘Smart Scope’ service\u003c/a\u003e that turns the Dash into an intelligent and relevant ‘search hub’, will allow Ubuntu users to pick and choose which services, scopes and lenses are used in the Dash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu 13.04 intends to ship with around \u003ca title\u003d\"IMDb, GrooveShark, eBay and More to Be Searchable from Unity in 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/100-scopes-list-ubuntu-13-04\"\u003e100 scopes by default\u003c/a\u003e, the relevancy of which will be ‘crowd-sourced’ from users own behaviour.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMrlsT5TrU1c:xkrca1UYuqo:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361100665757","timestampUsec":"1361100665757844","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/63c2b1a792397396","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Editorial",
"community","opensource"],"title":"Motivation, Community and the Cost of Disagreeing","published":1361096996,"updated":1361096996,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/motivation-community-and-the-cost-of-disagreeing"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/aVqj2M308aQ/motivation-community-and-the-cost-of-disagreeing","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA vast portion of the people in the open source community are folks who volunteer their time, effort \u0026amp; ideas, freely and without hesitation  - but why?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe thing that motivates people, more than wealth (not that they’ll admit as such), is self-direction – the drive to take their own ideas and sculpt them into something worthwhile – and the open source community is the perfect example. As such it’s rife with innovation and ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Pursuit of \u003cdel\u003eHappiness\u003c/del\u003e Autonomy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘…self-determinism is what draws some people to [open source]…’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat I believe people strive for – contrary to how our society (and, not to sound all anti-capitalist, economy) operates – is \u003cem\u003eautonomy\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis unspoken motivation has even gone so far to influence some companies, who embrace this fact and allow their employees to devote part of their time to pursue special projects outside their workload, resulting in more innovation (albeit still within the company).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMy theory is that this self-determinism is what draws some people to the open source community.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘freedom allows for a greater scope of collaboration’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur community is great in its pragmatism, there is no ‘clear’ governance and it has the simple philosophy that things ought to be free to investigate and modify (to the core).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch freedom allows for a greater scope of collaboration and development of ideas through understanding.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis openness also lets people collaborate globally with people of similar ideologies and ideas and it results in a wealth of productivity and innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, let’s not be mistaken, the open-source community is still a meritocracy; people who are known for doing good work and being constructive become more trusted and ascend.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘…the open-source community is still a meritocracy…’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy judge on the basis of ability? To achieve a higher quality product you’d want the best people you can get and trust working on it, no?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLook at how Linux was built, nearly half of the code contributions to the kernel were done by volunteers, it wasn’t (entirely) built by paying people to do so –the \u003cem\u003ecarrot and stick\u003c/em\u003e approach, as it were, \u003cstrong\u003eisn’t\u003c/strong\u003e the foremost motivator for these people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/tux-donkey-carrot.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Tux on a Donkey - by Sam Hewitt \" alt\u003d\"Tux on a Donkey - by Sam Hewitt \" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/tux-donkey-carrot.png\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"544\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat happens when we disagree?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, like any open forum, there are instances when people’s ideas and opinions oppose, and as such division and disputation erupts and our community sees (and continues to see) its fair share of controversy and head bashing. So as we begin to segregate and divides erupt, collaboration begins to fragment and the skies go dark and the Earth’s rotation slows to a halt and all hope is lost…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘pointless arguing and infighting gets us nowhere’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot really – we simply constrain innovation and energy is wasted. If efforts are used simply to naysay and nitpick at the opposition or berate someone or a group, rather than towards coming together to collaborate and constructively discuss our differences, then nothing is gained.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUltimately where all the \u003cstrong\u003epointless\u003c/strong\u003e arguing and infighting gets us is nowhere; each project will still continue on it’s track and all that will be wasted is time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘…so long as we are constructive in our disagreement it’s healthy.’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, what I think the beauty of this community is, is that we are free (not as in beer) to hold opposing and contradictory ideas and so long as we are constructive in our disagreement it’s healthy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe other great thing is that if we disagree with the direction our favourite projects take, usually the open nature of its surrounding community allows us to take our disagreement to the related forums, mailing lists, etc. to engage in a dialogue and voice our concerns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHaving said that, disagreeing is also based on merit, an opinion is not valued in and of itself, it needs to be somewhat trustworthy or helpful –i.e. don’t go all incendiary in the comments, forums, etc., being polite and constructive would be met in kind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSo what?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI guess my overall point is: instead of getting annoyed (or whatever), get excited and make things!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemember, we’re all in this free/open source thing together and we’re all trying to spread it as far as and to as many as possible!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6 style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e*The views expressed in this editorial are of the author and may not reflect those of OMG! Ubuntu! \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daVqj2M308aQ:CJqTd9z77CQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/aVqj2M308aQ\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1361042223806","timestampUsec":"1361042223806155","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4acdc33b66ade945","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","News","Ubuntu Tablet",
"kde","ubuntu phone"],"title":"KDE Dev Says Ubuntu Phone Fans Being ‘Duped’","published":1361014377,"updated":1361014377,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/kde-dev-says-ubuntu-phone-devs-being-duped"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/Lr4JKSo1FPM/kde-dev-says-ubuntu-phone-devs-being-duped","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"The Ubuntu Phone\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone1.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"412\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDevelopers interested in the Ubuntu Phone are being ‘duped’ by Canonical, a leading KDE developer has said.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a rant on Google+, \u003cem\u003eKDE Plasma Active\u003c/em\u003e developer Aaron Seigo takes Canonical to task over a statement made in the press release for the \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Downloads To Be Released Next Week\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-phone-downloads-to-be-released-next-week\"\u003eUbuntu Phone downloads\u003c/a\u003e, in which they say:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e“When complete, the same Ubuntu code will deliver a mobile, tablet, desktop or TV experiences depending on the device it is installed on, or where it is docked.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis Segio argues, is a ‘hollow claim’ by Canonical. In a post to his 1000+ followers he writes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Unity currently does not use QML at all [and] \u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003eUbuntu Phone is pure QML So, no, it is not the same code, it is not the sort of seamless cross-device technology bridge that they are purporting,” \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGoing on to call the wording of the announcement ‘a bit cagey’, Seigo tries to read between the lines of what he thinks Canonical mean:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e‘Perhaps if we define “same Ubuntu code” to mean “Ubuntu the distribution with all versions of the UI installed” we can cover this with a great amount of fudge factor. Perhaps Unity will eventually be merged with Ubuntu Phone, and that’s what they mean by “when complete”.’\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut he doesn’t buy his own reasoning, saying that the message being sent out by Canonical – the one he takes issue with – is both clear and ‘not accidental’:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘The Free software community is being told a fairy tale in hopes that they will believe it and as a result support Canonical …under what amounts to false pretenses (sic).’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘If you’re a Free software developer, user and/or supporter and buying into these claims, I don’t know how else to put it other than this: you’re being duped.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFair?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDevelopers are entirely right to be dubious of claims, particularly when it’s hard to to weight those claims against “bricks and mortar” reality (in this case, code).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it’s a fine line between being realistic and being flat-out cynical.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe know that Canonical are aiming for a ‘convergent’ future with Unity, and we know that this will encompass phones, TVs, tablets and the good ol’ fashioned desktop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQuite \u003cem\u003ehow\u003c/em\u003e it will do this is a bit less clear because of the way Canonical development happens: things are only made available to the wider world when in a usable, worthwhile state.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, even in light of this, Canonical have yet to give us a reason to doubt sincerity of aim. Picking apart a \u003cem\u003epossible\u003c/em\u003e inference from one phrase of one paragraph in one press release is a little hasty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Warms My Insides’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDebates about the semantics of ‘same code’ aside, Seigo is a fan of the Ubuntu Phone, as he says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e“…I think Ubuntu Phone a great thing to see; more Free software mobile efforts, particularly ones using Qt/QML, warm my insides like a good bowl of soup on a cold winter’s night. We’ve even been discussing how to harmonize QML APIs in future between Plasma and Ubuntu Phone …”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd this isn’t won’t be a surprise to those who know of him.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAaron Seigo is a principle driving force behind the KDE Plasma Active environment which, much like Unity aims to, seeks to work across a variety of different devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dLr4JKSo1FPM:h22szH2Q4-0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/Lr4JKSo1FPM\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"News","steam","teamfortress"],"title":"Canonical Host Weekend ‘TeamFortress 2′ Server","published":1361022256,"updated":1361022256,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/canonical-host-weekend-teamfortress-2-server"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/0JLR_9U0TT0/canonical-host-weekend-teamfortress-2-server","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/team.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"team\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/team.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"250\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eCalling all gamers: Canonical are hosting a TeamFortress 2 server this weekend to mark \u003ca title\u003d\"Steam Added to Ubuntu Software Center, Celebrates With Big Sale\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/steam-added-to-ubuntu-software-center-celebrates-with-big-sale\"\u003ethe arrival of Steam for Linux on the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTeamFortress 2 is free to download and play, so if you fancy some free fragging fun with fellow Ubuntu gamers here’s how:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow to Connect to Canonical TF2 Server\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith Steam open head to the ‘View’ menu and choose the ‘Servers’ option:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/VIDEO.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"VIDEO\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/VIDEO.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"394\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the ‘Servers’ window opens click on the the ‘Favourites’ tab, then the ‘Add a Server’ button near the bottom of the window.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"serverss\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/serverss-750x291.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"291\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the IP address field enter the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e54.243.8.249\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdd the server by clicking the ‘Add this Address to Favo…” button to the right of the entry area.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll now see the Canonical TF2 server listed. Double click on it to begin play.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/canonical-server.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"canonical-server\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/canonical-server.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"503\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you don’t have TeamFortress Installed prior to this you will be prompted to download it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor gaming stats from the server head over to \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"http://www.gametracker.com/server_info/54.243.8.249:27015/\"\u003egametracker.com/server_info/54.243.8.249:27015/\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeploy Your Own Server\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurther more, thanks to Canonical’s JuJu team, it’s now incredibly simple to get a TeamFortress server of your own up and running.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore information on that can be found hiding behind the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://jujucharms.com/~marcoceppi/precise/teamfortress2\" title\u003d\"team fortress 2 server for ubuntu\"\u003e TeamFortress 2 JuJu Charm \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0JLR_9U0TT0:sgdM4GsNc04:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0JLR_9U0TT0:sgdM4GsNc04:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0JLR_9U0TT0:sgdM4GsNc04:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0JLR_9U0TT0:sgdM4GsNc04:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0JLR_9U0TT0:sgdM4GsNc04:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "ubuntu phone"],"title":"Ubuntu Phone Downloads To Be Released Next Week","published":1360950391,"updated":1360950391,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-phone-downloads-to-be-released-next-week"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/zt8tY0QXE2c/ubuntu-phone-downloads-to-be-released-next-week","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:258px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/twitter-app.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"twitter-app\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/twitter-app.jpg\" width\u003d\"258\" height\u003d\"223\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Phone\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInstallable Ubuntu Phone images for the Galaxy Nexus and Nexus 4 handsets will be available to download from next week, Canonical \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.canonical.com/content/touch-developer-preview-ubuntu-be-published-21-february-2013\"\u003ehave today announced\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.canonical.com/content/touch-developer-preview-ubuntu-be-published-21-february-2013\"\u003e.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom February 21st two pre-compiled images will be available for anyone with either supported handset to download.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe preview will allow fans and app developers alike the chance to get to grips with the Ubuntu Phone experience ahead of its official release later this year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut if the thought of ‘flashing’ your phone scares you then relax: Canonical have got you covered. Accompanying the preview will be a desktop app that downloads, updates and install Ubuntu Phone on to supported handsets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s likely that the tool will be similar to the\u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu Nexus 7 Installer App Released to Devs\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/ubuntu-installer-for-nexus-7-tablet-made-available-for-devs\"\u003e ’Nexus 7′ installer\u003c/a\u003e  released by Canonical last October, which enabled owners of the Google Nexus 7 to quickly install Ubuntu on to their device.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSource Code \u003d More Support\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e“More important than the release of pre-compiled images will be the mass of un-compiled code…”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut more important than the release of two pre-compiled images will be a mass of un-compiled code. On the same day that Nexus owners face an ‘Android of Shiny New Preview’ dilemma, the Ubuntu Phone source code will also be made available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis ‘milestone’ will be significant for the Ubuntu Phone project as it will mark the first that developers can dive in to the code. As an open-source project, devs will able to fix, refine and add features, as well as port it to run on other devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“€œOur platform supports a wide range of screen sizes and resolutions. Developers who have experience bringing up phone environments will find it relatively easy to port Ubuntu to current handsets”€,\u003c/em\u003e  says Canonical’s  Pat McGowan, who heads up the team producing the images.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith Ubuntu Phone designed to run well on low-end smartphones expect to see a zombie-style reawakening of dead handsets from the dark and dank depths of forgotten drawers the world over…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDetails\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDetails on install Ubuntu Phone, and the devices supported, will be listed at \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TouchInstallProcess\"\u003ewiki.ubuntu.com/TouchInstallProcess\u003c/a\u003e in the coming week.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEarlier this week Canonical \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone App Design Guidelines Go Live\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-phone-app-design-guidelines-published\"\u003epublished design guidelines\u003c/a\u003e for interested developers. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzt8tY0QXE2c:FAGEtXXgvS8:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg "News","steam"],"title":"Steam Added to Ubuntu Software Center, Celebrates With Big Sale","published":1360871579,"updated":1360871579,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/steam-added-to-ubuntu-software-center-celebrates-with-big-sale"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/x-DSRKZsSDI/steam-added-to-ubuntu-software-center-celebrates-with-big-sale","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/steam1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"steam\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/steam1.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"278\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eValve’s Steam for Linux client is now available to install on Ubuntu directly from the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe app, which has been in various beta stages since November 2012, is available on both Ubuntu 12.04 LTS and Ubuntu 12.10 on either 32bit or 64bit installs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the client itself can be installed (and uninstalled) from within the Ubuntu Software Center all future updates to the app will be handled by the Steam client’s built-in updater, linked to the official Steam for Linux repository.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUp to 80% Off Sale\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo mark the release, gamers can save between 50-80% off the price of every Steam Linux title – of which there are over 50 to choose from – until Thursday February 21st.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t forget to join the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://steamcommunity.com/groups/omgubuntu\"\u003eOMG! guidelines for developers looking to create apps for the Ubuntu Phone.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDescribed as a ‘living resource’ that will ‘organically grow’ over time – \u003cem\u003eand for that read: eventually cover more than just the Ubuntu Phone\u003c/em\u003e – the current set of documentation aims to provide all the information needed to craft consistent and user-friendly interfaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCore Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe launch of the resource couldn’t have come at a better time. \u003ca title\u003d\"12 Default Ubuntu behaviour, patterns and visual design to ensure their apps provide a solid, clean and enjoyable user experience.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eContent\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt double-checking your buttons, double-click speed and scroll wheel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca Test Your Mouse Settings\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe changes come from the upstream ‘GNOME Control Center’ on which Ubuntu’s System Settings is based.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompared to the current crop of settings to be found in Ubuntu 12.10, the new set are greatly refined:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv tweaked\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you’re using Raring give the new mouse settings tester a go then zip back here to let us know what you think of "kde","themes"],"title":"Ambiance Theme for KDE [Download]","published":1360702823,"updated":1360702823,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-ambiance-plasma-theme-kde"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/qdQeXxqo6FA/ubuntu-ambiance-plasma-theme-kde","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEver wished that your Kubuntu desktop looked a little bit more like Ubuntu, with its warm tones and orange highlights?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you answered no then you’re free to return to whatever it was you were doing before following a link here.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut if you answered yes, read on…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAmbiance Theme for KDE\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThanks to KDE’s theming versatility, and the work of prolific Linux designer Half Left, we can achieve an Ambiance-style look relatively easy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePart 1\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/kde4ubuntu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"kde4ubuntu\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/kde4ubuntu.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"422\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first part is simple enough. Just download the following Ambiance theme for the KDE Plasma desktop:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://half-left.deviantart.com/art/KDE4-Ubuntu-Ambiance-346399730\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ambiance Theme for KDE Plasma \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstall them theme by extracting the contents of the .zip file to your \u003cem\u003e~/.kde/share/apps/desktoptheme/\u003c/em\u003e folder.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter installation, select the theme from the \u003cem\u003eSystem Settings \u0026gt; Workspace \u0026gt; Appearance \u0026gt; Desktop Theme\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis will re-style the main desktop elements, along with many of KDE’s widgets, to look Ambiance-y.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePart 2\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/dolphin-ambiance.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"dolphin-ambiance\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/dolphin-ambiance.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"514\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe second part themes other elements of the KDE4 interface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownload the .Zip file from the following link:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://half-left.deviantart.com/art/KDE4-Ubuntu-Ambiance-Suite-347719015\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ambiance Plasma for KDE \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eNext, you need to check that you have the \u003cstrong\u003eQtCurve Widget Style\u003c/strong\u003e installed. You’ll find it listed under the ‘\u003cem\u003eStyle\u003c/em\u003e‘ section of \u003cem\u003e‘Application Appearance\u003c/em\u003e‘ in settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eIf you don’t have it installed just click the following button:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"javascript:void(0);\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Click to Install QtCurve in Kubuntu \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePart 3\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe last – and easiest part – is to set GTK apps to use the Ambiance Theme.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have the Ubuntu desktop installed alongside KDE you can do this by running the ‘gnome-settings’daemon’ from a Konsole in KDE.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you don’t then you’ll need to install a few extra packages, including the Ubuntu Light Themes packages and an appropriate settings tool capable of setting GTK themes (unsettings, etc).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqdQeXxqo6FA:m0222sWEcGc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg
