},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360700502850","timestampUsec":"1360700502850503","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/874bdfa44eb36e97","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","App","musicplayers",
"rdio","web meets desktop"],"title":"Spotify Rival Rdio Gets New Ubuntu App","published":1360697528,"updated":1360697528,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/rdio-app-for-ubuntu-desktop"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/t7Nw_7t0pW4/rdio-app-for-ubuntu-desktop","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/rdio-icon.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"rdio-icon\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/rdio-icon-300x300.png\" width\u003d\"180\" height\u003d\"180\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eMusic streaming service, and major Spotify rival, \u003ca title\u003d\"Rdio Website\" href\u003d\"http://rdio.com\"\u003eRdio\u003c/a\u003e recently upped its ‘free’ offerings for international users.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the cost of an e-mail address users in a multitude of countries, including the UK, Germany and France, can now get 6 months of free on-demand access to Rdio’s library of music.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith over 18 million tracks on offer – albeit 3 million less than Spotify – most major artists, labels and songs are available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlongside the 6 month ‘trial period’ free users are also subject to a monthly playback limit. There’s no set-rate for how many songs this is but there is a green ‘tracks remaining’ meter at the top of the Rdio page to let you know how much free music you have remaining for the present month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:600px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/meter.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Track Remaining Meter on Rdio\" alt\u003d\"meter\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/meter.jpg\" width\u003d\"600\" height\u003d\"139\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eTrack Remaining Meter on Rdio\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor contrast, Spotify offers six months of\u003cem\u003e unlimited\u003c/em\u003e but ad-supported playback for free. After this free users are subject to a 2.5 hour listening limit per week thereafter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRdio’s hope is, of course, that by offering a relatively lengthy free trial with few limits, users will be such fans of the service they’ll be chomping at the bit to sign up to one of the two premium accounts on offer when their free trial ends.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith Rdio, $4.99/£4.99 per month gets you unlimited web/desktop app playback, while £9.99/$9.99 a month extends this access to smart-phones, tablets and media devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAvailability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRdio is currently available to users in the USA, New Zealand, Australia and much of western Europe, including Germany, France, Sweden and the UK.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA roll-out to Japan on the cards for later this month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAccessing Rdio on Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo that’s \u003cem\u003ewhat\u003c/em\u003e Rdio offers for free and \u003cem\u003ewhere\u003c/em\u003e it offers it – but how well supported is it in Ubuntu?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike Spotify, Rdio provides desktop applications for various platforms but, unlike Spotify, this doesn’t include Linux. Worse still, Rdio say that \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e“wider Linux desktop support isn’t currently on the roadmap.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that\u003cem\u003e Rdio\u003c/em\u003e‘s primary playback spot is via its gorgeous web player. This can be accessed from any web-browser that supports Flash, and on any platform. Just log-in and away you go.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUnity Web App\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:300px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/unity-rdio.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Unity web app rdio\" alt\u003d\"unity-rdio\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/unity-rdio-300x145.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"145\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eA Unity Web App is Already Available\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurther still, Rdio is one of the few third-party websites to support Unity’s (much maligned) Web Apps feature. Visit the web-site in Firefox or Chromium and you’ll be prompted to enable integration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhilst this approach integrates the web plater with Ubuntu’s Sound Menu it doesn’t support track change notifications, quick-list controls, or media key support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, here at least, it also lacks an icon…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that, thanks to a third party developer, we can now go one better on Ubuntu…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew Rdio Desktop App for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e‘\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/sgringwe/rdio\"\u003eRdio\u003c/a\u003e‘ by developer \u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eScott Ringwelski \u003c/strong\u003eis an unofficial Rdio app for Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt runs the Rdio website interface in a dedicated windowed ‘wrapper’ on the desktop, hooking into the Ubuntu Sound Menu, notification system and Unity Quicklists.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/rdio-app.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"rdio-app\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/rdio-app.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"368\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eRdio Desktop App for Ubuntu – Unity Support Baked In\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese minor additions turn what is, essentially, a ‘web-app’ into something that feels more native than running the Rdio site in a browser tab.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimple things, like being able to hit the ‘Next’ or ‘Pause’ keys to control playback really aid this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve been looking for a reason to give Rdio a go – now seems the perfect time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eFeatures\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Sound Menu Integration\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Notification System Support\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUnity Launcher Quicklist\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMedia Key Support\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDrawbacks\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClicking ‘x’ will exit the app\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdobe Flash is required for playback\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDoesn’t support music download\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Rdio for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstalling Rdio in Ubuntu 12.04, 12.10 \u0026amp; 12.10 is as easy as adding the following PPA:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo add-apt-repository ppa:sgringwe/rdio\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install rdio\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr download and install one of the following .deb installers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://code.launchpad.net/~sgringwe/+archive/rdio/+packages\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download Rdio (.Deb) Installers \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eFor more information on Rdio for Ubuntu head over to the project’s Github page:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/sgringwe/rdio\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Rdio on GitHub \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dt7Nw_7t0pW4:TsZalQzHa08:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360624782321","timestampUsec":"1360624782321860","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/9104d3b52df0da78","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Gaming",
"Review","mindlabyrinth","strange masks"],"title":"Is ‘Strange Masks’ The Strangest Game On Ubuntu? [Review]","published":1360624467,"updated":1360624467,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/strange-masks-ubuntu-game-review"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/x4SMzBT43Lc/strange-masks-ubuntu-game-review","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLet’s face it: when most games describe themselves as a ‘mental challenge’ they’re saying it in earnest hope rather than actual truth.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut \u003cem\u003eStrange Masks\u003c/em\u003e, the latest gaming title from indie outfit \u003cem\u003eThinkSlow\u003c/em\u003e, would live up to such a claim – if it chose to make it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor behind its simplistic-seeming game-play and cutesy 2D graphics lays a game mechanic packed with enough fraught potential to put your PC’s well-being in jeopardy from a flailing frustrated fist…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMind Melting Madness\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStrange Masks is the third release from indie-developers ThinkSlow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the name rings a bell then you be recalling their the 52-level strong puzzle game ‘\u003ca title\u003d\"Mind Labyrinth – Ubuntu’s First Mind-Controlled Game\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/02/mind-labyrinth-ubuntus-first-mind-controlled-game\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMind Labyrinth\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e‘ – designed to played with a neuro-interface controller – that they brought to the Ubuntu Software Center just under a year ago.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike Mind Labyrinth, Strange Masks was developed entirely on Linux first, before being ported over to Windows and OS X.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:748px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/open.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Strange Masks Start Screen\" alt\u003d\"open\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/open.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"371\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eStrange Masks Start Screen\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGameplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe premise of Strange Masks is simple: As you navigate through a “maze” of masks you must find and ‘activate’ the coloured ones in sequence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/eg2.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"eg2\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/eg2.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"422\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce all colour masks have been activated you then zip back through the maze activating ‘fire masks’, and finding the way out, all against a not-so-liberal countdown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat is, essentially, it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘The brain becomes engaged. The memory cells spark with activity.’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut as fond as I was of the game during my time playing it I am not blinkered. Strange Masks is not a classic in the making; it’s not an undiscovered indie gem; nor is the game going to redefine any genres.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, to be frank, the first few levels are more like an interactive slideshow presentation than a storied brain-teaser. There’s a bit too much ‘shuffling left-and-right between some faces, hitting space every now and then’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut after a few levels things pick up pace. The brain becomes engaged. The memory cells spark with activity. Your fingers smoke from the frenetic tap-mashing required to keep pace and beat the countdown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe “challenge” comes less from the game and more from overestimating your own reflexes and faculties.\u003cem\u003e ’But this game is so easy!’\u003c/em\u003e, you’ll cry after losing one of the later levels for the 5th time in a row.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo stave off repetition there are over 50 levels across ’2 great labyrinths’, each with three levels of difficulty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e‘Challenge’ modes let you replay levels individually to best your own scores.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game auto-saves throughout play so you can quickly close it when the phone rings – or the boss looks over your shoulder!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStrange Masks can be played using a keyboard (default) or using a game-pad – assuming you have one set-up in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eVideo\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/qL9EJSIKrSE?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStrange Masks is such an apt title. It is a strange, peculiar little game. It straddles the line between straightforward and challenging – and for only $2.99 that’s not a bad place to be.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePerfect for\u003c/strong\u003e those with a middling memory in need of testing\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBest skipped by \u003c/strong\u003ethose easily bored by sedate, sedentary gameplay\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuy \u0026amp; Demo\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStrange Masks is available to buy from the Ubuntu Software Center on Ubuntu 12.04 \u0026amp; 12.10.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s priced at $2.99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/strangemasks/\" title\u003d\"Strange Masks on Ubuntu\"\u003e Buy Strage Masks on Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA 15-level demo is available from the developers website @ \u003ca title\u003d\"Strange Masks Homepage\" href\u003d\"http://strangemasks.com\"\u003estrangemasks.com\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dx4SMzBT43Lc:-1JLLFIvpX0:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dx4SMzBT43Lc:-1JLLFIvpX0:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" "type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/how-to-theme-android-to-look-like-the-ubuntu-phone"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-g-theme.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"ubuntu-g-theme\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-g-theme.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"449\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho ever decreed that ‘patience is a virtue’ clearly underestimated the power of ‘want’ when faced with an Ubuntu Phone. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that we inch ever closer to getting hold of one. Mark Shuttleworth recently announced that \u003ca title\u003d\"First Ubuntu Phones ‘Available October’, Says Shuttleworth\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/first-ubuntu-phone-available-october-says-shuttleworth\"\u003eit’ll the first Ubuntu Phone’s will arrive in October\u003c/a\u003e, and an \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Download, Source Will Arrive ‘February’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-download-will-be-ready-late-february\"\u003einstallable image for the Galaxy Nexus\u003c/a\u003e (along with the phone source code) will drop late February/early March.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut what are we supposed to do in the mean time? \u003cem\u003eWait?!\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThankfully not. Enter graphic designer Alex Miller and his ‘\u003cem\u003eUbuntu G Theme Project\u003c/em\u003e‘ for Android…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu G\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt’s all smoke and mirrors, of course…\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu G – \u003cem\u003ewhich, in my mind I keep pronouncing as ‘Ubun-tug\u003c/em\u003e – is a small project aimed at making an existing Android-powered smartphone look like an Ubuntu-powered one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo do this is takes a variety of pre-existing Android apps, including \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id\u003dcom.anddoes.launcher\u0026amp;feature\u003dnav_result#?t\u003dW251bGwsMSwxLDMsImNvbS5hbmRkb2VzLmxhdW5jaGVyIl0.\"\u003eApex Launcher\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"http://tasker.dinglisch.net/\"\u003eTasker\u003c/a\u003e \u0026amp; \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id\u003din.vineetsirohi.customwidget\u0026amp;feature\u003dsearch_result#?t\u003dW251bGwsMSwxLDEsImluLnZpbmVldHNpcm9oaS5jdXN0b213aWRnZXQiXQ..\"\u003eUCCW\u003c/a\u003e, then themes and/or configures them until they resemble parts of the Ubuntu Phone interface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s all smoke and mirrors, of course. While the end result looks like an Ubuntu Phone it doesn’t behave like one. The gesture support so key to the Ubuntu Phone experience, for instance, isn’t replicated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut as far as aping the interface goes it’s pretty spot on, allows plenty of room for customisation and is bar far the easiest – and cheapest – of the various ‘Ubuntu Phone Theme’ guides floating around cyberspace.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll find Alex’s full guide, along with links to everything you need, behind the button below. Do note before heading over that you will need to buy one app - \u003ca href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id\u003dcom.teslacoilsw.widgetlocker\u0026amp;feature\u003dsearch_result#?t\u003dW251bGwsMSwxLDEsImNvbS50ZXNsYWNvaWxzdy53aWRnZXRsb2NrZXIiXQ..\"\u003eWidgetLocker LockScreen\u003c/a\u003e - in order to fully replicate the look.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://arandompackage.blogspot.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-g-tutorial.html\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ubuntu G Tutorial for Android \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dC87qR0aRmyo:FbSyfpfSiSg:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360500374870","timestampUsec":"1360500374870364","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/008247f708bf14c8","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"How To","gnomeshell","mate"],"title":"[How To] Run MATE Desktop In GNOME Shell","published":1360495227,"updated":1360495227,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/njZj2OTRIRg/how-to-run-mate-desktop-in-gnome-shell","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/how-to-run-mate-desktop-in-gnome-shell"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis being Linux, we have the good fortune of having our choice of desktop environment \u0026amp; nobody says that it has to be one at a time.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMATE, as some of you will know/remember is the fork of the long deprecated GNOME2, but still retains all the look \u0026amp; feel of the “good ol’ days”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what was initially a jump into nostalgia for me became an unintended discovery; as accident would have it, MATE runs flawlessly in tandem with GNOME Shell (and consumes next to no extra resources).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/gnomemate0.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"gnomemate0\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/gnomemate0.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRunning this dualism –mixing an old paradigm with a new one– has it’s advantages, you get all the shiny, new features \u0026amp; improvements of a modern desktop environment but you’ll still have a 24px strip of the old (and possibly still familiar) functionality. (Plus the return of all those quirky panel applets).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHaving a whole other shell can be useful too. Say GNOME Shell were to crash, MATE would still be there giving you easy access to your entire system and apps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/gnomemate1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"gnomemate1\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/gnomemate1.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNeither environment inhibit one another and everything still operates as would expected. MATE panel even adopts the GNOME dynamic workspaces’ behaviour –switching to an empty workspace via the panel applet and opening an application will cause another workspace to appear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eI like to think of this unassuming panel along the bottom as the best unofficial addition GNOME Shell. ;-)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGetting MATE Desktop\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstalling MATE is as easy as running a few one-line commands. First, add the MATE repository to your system \u0026amp; update your repository information:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u0026quot;deb http://packages.mate-desktop.org/repo/ubuntu $(lsb_release -sc) main\u0026quot; \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get update\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstall the MATE keyring to avoid any future authentication errors, and update again:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get install mate-archive-keyring \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get update\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen install MATE:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get install mate-core # This installs the base environment\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get install mate-desktop-environment # This installs the whole environment\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow it’s as easy as logging into a MATE session and run GNOME Shell atop the MATE environment, or running MATE Panel from within GNOME Shell or Unity for that matter:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/unitymate0.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"unitymate0\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/unitymate0.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eDespite a little overlap, with auto-hide and a matching theme, no one would know.\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dnjZj2OTRIRg:TvUGx-bGzgc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "Dev","News","quicklist","raring ringtail","unity"],"title":"New Window Switching Method Added to Unity","published":1360444093,"updated":1360444093,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/faERUQuZG7E/new-window-switching-method-added-to-unity","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/new-window-switching-method-added-to-unity"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRemember that \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/quicklist-window-switching-patch-proposed-for-unity\"\u003eUnity Quicklist window switching patch\u003c/a\u003e we mentioned at the end of January? It arrived as default in Ubuntu 13.04 earlier today.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProposed by \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~lukas-vacek\"\u003eLukas Vacek\u003c/a\u003e, the small feature adds a list of an application’s open windows (note the plural) in its associated Unity Quicklist.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, with a right-click on the launcher icon, you can switch to a window without needing to use the keyboard or invoke the Spread animation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Quicklist Window Switching\" alt\u003d\"Right-Click Listing of App Windows in Unity\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/qiiclis.jpg\" width\u003d\"740\" height\u003d\"356\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdmittedly it’s not a major usability change, nor one that everyone will use, but some mouse-heavy users may find it preferable to Unity’s two other methods of switching between multiple windows of the same app:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe first uses the universal keyboard shortcut for switching: \u003cem\u003eAlt+Tab.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe second is a keyboard-free solution: left-click on the App Launcher item itself to reveal windows as a ‘spread’.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eScroll Switching Coming Soon?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnity developers are also debating whether to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/unity/+bug/1081843\"\u003eadd another new method of switching\u003c/a\u003e between multiple windows of an application – this time by using a mouse’s scroll-wheel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf implemented – and that’s not a given right now – it will allow you to ‘\u003cem\u003e…hover over [an open app icon] and scroll with the mouse wheel to switch and highlight between the windows of that app\u003c/em\u003e.’\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfaERUQuZG7E:S9C2FYV_RlE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg "News","indicatorapplets","notifications","raring ringtail"],"title":"Raring Retires System Tray Whitelist","published":1360326769,"updated":1360326769,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/AxDwkPktD_4/raring-retires-system-tray-whitelist","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/raring-retires-system-tray-whitelist"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn option allowing applications lacking App Indicator support to show in the system tray has been removed from \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eUbuntu 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eApplications and services not using the feature were hidden by default in Ubuntu 11.04 – but \u003ca title\u003d\"How to re-enable notification area applets in Ubuntu 11.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/03/how-to-hide-or-show-app-tray-applets-in-ubuntu-11-04\"\u003ecould be manually re-enabled\u003c/a\u003e through a hidden settings option.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, in requesting the removal of this configurable ‘whitelist’ from the up-coming Ubuntu 13.04, Ubuntu’s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~mpt\"\u003eMatthew Paul Thomas\u003c/a\u003e argues that developers have had enough time to adopt the App Indicator spec.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/notification-area.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Whitelisting Apps in Ubuntu 12.10\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/notification-area.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"270\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhitelisting Apps in Ubuntu 12.10 – Now Gone in 13.04\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eApp Indicators were formally introduced in Ubuntu 10.04 LTS to create a consistent user-experience when interacting with items in the System Tray.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Good News\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that while the whitelist itself is going away support for applications run under Wine, or those built with Java, will remain visible. This, MPT says, is because ‘…\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003etheir developers don’t necessarily know that Ubuntu even exists.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut not everyone is happy with the plan.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/974480/comments/6\"\u003eCommenting on the bug\u003c/a\u003e report to remove the whitelist, user \u003cem\u003eEd Guenter\u003c/em\u003e rants:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Thanks for breaking the 5000+ Ubuntu users within our company that ”enjoy” using such ancient applications like Sametime, Lotus Notes or Symantec Antivirus. Maybe, in 5 years from now, such applications will accept that unity exist and provide indicators. Today, they dont. Or maybe unity is history in 5 years from now\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e“\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOff the top of my head I’m finding it difficult to think of a single mainstream-application that doesn’t already make use of the App Indicator spec.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSkype, VLC, Opera, and Spotify for Linux all do. While Shutter, whose developers long resisted adding support for it, \u003ca title\u003d\"Shutter Screenshot App Finally Adds an App Indicator\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/shutter-screenshot-app-finally-adds-an-app-indicator\"\u003eadded App Indicator support late last year.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you currently whitelist any applications that would be affected by this switch? Or do you agree that developers have had enough time to adapt? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dAxDwkPktD_4:-G5rMWsKi3U:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/AxDwkPktD_4\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"unity-tweak-tool"],"title":"Introducing ‘Unity Tweak Tool’","published":1360320289,"updated":1360320289,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/d04UzmS9Ysk/introducing-unity-tweak-tool","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/introducing-unity-tweak-tool"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor the power-user in you, Unity Tweak Tool fills the void of the one-stop-shop configuration tool for the Unity desktop.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike other tools of its ilk, Unity Tweak Tool provides users access to a plethora of features and configuration options not (obviously) accessible to the average user, and brings them all together in a polished \u0026amp; easy-to-use interface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Screenshot-2013-02-06-135448.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Screenshot 2013-02-06 13:54:48\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Screenshot-2013-02-06-135448.png\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eUnity Tweak Tool – Main Window\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the many features Unity Tweak Tool offers users, one will find plenty of Unity-related settings, options to configure window management settings –including hotcorners and workspaces– theming \u0026amp; appearance tweaks and other miscellaneous desktop settings like scrolling behaviour and security.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstalling Unity Tweak Tool\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnity Tweak Tool can be easily installed by adding the daily build PPA to your software sources, simply by pasting the following in your favourite terminal application:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:freyja-dev/unity-tweak-tool-daily\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px;line-height:18px\"\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install unity-tweak-tool\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e Unity Tweak Tool is currently in active development. Install at your own risk. \u003c/div\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGetting Involved\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eContributions to the Unity Tweak Tool project are also welcome! Translations and report bugs can be done over on our \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/unity-tweak-tool\"\u003eLaunchpad page\u003c/a\u003e or if you’re more of a coder and want to help, you can visit the project on \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://github.com/freyja-dev/unity-tweak-tool\"\u003eGitHub\u003c/a\u003e and submit code for review.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have a question, concern or suggestion you can hop over to our IRC channel: #freyja-dev on Freenode.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360244251082","timestampUsec":"1360244251082393","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/ee024bf63362c363","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"News","libreoffice"],"title":"LibreOffice Hits 4.0, Adds Unity Integration \u0026amp; ‘Persona’ Theming","published":1360243369,"updated":1360243369,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/6j3PVDH7HEo/libreoffice-hits-4-0-adds-unity-integration-persona-theming","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/libreoffice-hits-4-0-adds-unity-integration-persona-theming"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/personas.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"personas\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/personas.jpg\" width\u003d\"700\" height\u003d\"296\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\nLibreOffice 4.0, the first release of the open-source office suite said to truly reflect the project’s objectives, has hit the web.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLibreOffice was forked from the OpenOffice code-base back in 2010 with the aim of speeding up development, adding new features, and improving interoperability with other office apps (read: Microsoft Office).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“LibreOffice 4.0 is a milestone in interoperability and an excellent foundation for our continued work to improve the User Interface,”\u003c/em\u003e says Florian Effenberger, Chairman of the Board of Directors at The Document Foundation – the hands steering the project.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.libreoffice.org/download/4-0-new-features-and-fixes\"\u003enew features and fixes\u003c/a\u003e are listed in detail on the official website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, for those of you with more pressing things to do than read the minutiae of a change-log, here is a quick overview of the more notable new additions…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew In LibreOffice 4.0\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLibreOffice (or ‘Lurching-Into-Life-Office as I call it) has a reputation for being a bit slow when loading and saving various document types. This release puts the kibosh on that nickname with serious \u003cstrong\u003espeed gains\u003c/strong\u003e when working with  large ODS and XLSX spreadsheets and RTF files.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor Ubuntu users this release finally brings support for Unity’s App Menu baked in. No more extra plugins or packages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-07-at-13.19.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Screen-Shot-2013-02-07-at-13.19\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-07-at-13.19.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"409\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSupport for Firefox’s Personas has been added. This allows you to customise LibreOffice to suit your tastes. You’ll find this feature hidden under \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eTools \u0026gt; Options \u0026gt; Personalize\u003c/em\u003e .\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(Pro-tip: use one of the ‘ambiance’ persona’s for a seamless look in Ubuntu)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/personas.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"personas\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/personas.jpg\" width\u003d\"700\" height\u003d\"296\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDOCX and RTF documents are now better supported. Ink annotations can now be imported, and comments added to sections of text.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHeading Styles chooser has been updated to display previews:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/previews.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"previews\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/previews.jpg\" width\u003d\"651\" height\u003d\"342\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLibreOffice Calc charts can now be exported as images – a long sought feature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd the template chooser has gone from resembling a relation of Office 97 to a thumbnailed wonder:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/templates.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"templates\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/templates.jpg\" width\u003d\"530\" height\u003d\"340\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAndroid App\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso accompanying this release is the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Impress/Remote\"\u003e launch of an Android app for controlling ‘LibreOffice Impress’ presentation\u003c/a\u003es. For now, this is only supported on a handful of Linux distributions (Ubuntu is included). Support for Windows, OS X and other Linux distros will be coming later this year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLibreOffice 4.0 will rock up as default in Ubuntu 13.04. For anyone using Ubuntu 12.10 or prior you can download and upgrade manually. Be sure to uninstall any existing version of LibreOffice prior to doing this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore information on doing this can be found behind the following button…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.libreoffice.org/download/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download LibreOffice 4.0 \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d6j3PVDH7HEo:IM72YRQIMvs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/6j3PVDH7HEo\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"ubuntu phone"],"title":"First Ubuntu Phones ‘Available October’, Says Shuttleworth","published":1360190312,"updated":1360190312,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/vbjouG6JkPo/first-ubuntu-phone-available-october-says-shuttleworth","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/first-ubuntu-phone-available-october-says-shuttleworth"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mark-mit-phone.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Ubuntu Founder Mark Shuttleworth With the Ubuntu Phone\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mark-mit-phone.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"500\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Founder Mark Shuttleworth With the Ubuntu Phone\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe first Ubuntu-powered mobile phones will be reportedly be available from October this year.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReporting on a meeting Shuttleworth attended in New York earlier this week, \u003cem\u003eMichael Hickins\u003c/em\u003e of the Wall Street Journal writes that the Ubuntu founder announced plans for the Phone to ship in ‘\u003cstrong\u003etwo large geographic markets’\u003c/strong\u003e come October of this year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOctober is a lot nearer than the ‘early 2014′ date previously proffered by Canonical – a date that many critics deemed to be ‘too late’ if the OS wishes to gain traction against rivals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMozilla will \u003ca title\u003d\"Firefox OS Powered Smartphones Launching Early Next Year\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/07/firefox-os-powered-smartphones-launching-early-next-year\"\u003elaunch the first handset running their web-friendly Firefox OS\u003c/a\u003e in South America later this year. Other handset manufacturers, including ZTE, and over 7 major national network carriers have also announced plans to ship devices running it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Shuttleworth is not reported as confirming either of the two territories targeted, he is on record as having stressed that North America is ‘a key market for Ubuntu’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOctober aside, details on specifics are scant. Mark ‘declined’ to name any handset partners or network carriers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Download, Source Will Arrive ‘February’\" developers,\u003c/a\u003e alongside an installable image for the Samsung Galaxy Nexus handset.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eWould an October release suit "office"],"title":"Microsoft Bringing Office to Linux? [Rumour Mill]","published":1360173045,"updated":1360173045,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/kxbSMmALRoA/microsoft-to-bring-office-to-linux-rumour-mill","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/microsoft-to-bring-office-to-linux-rumour-mill"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:300px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Office.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Microsoft Office Running Under WINE\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Office-300x223.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"223\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft Office Running Under WINE\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft are considering a native Linux port of their popular \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eMicrosoft\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eOffice\u003c/em\u003e software – or so a rumour circulated at an recent open-source conference alleges. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the gossip, born at last weeks Free Open-Source Developers’ European Meeting (FOSDEM), is correct – and it is far from that at present – the increasing ‘commercial viability’ of Linux on the desktop is to be credited with piquing Microsoft’s interest.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eValve’s \u003cem\u003eSteam\u003c/em\u003e port and Canonical’s OEM tie-ups putting Ubuntu preinstalled on millions of laptops around the world have all helped to drag Linux out of the fringes of computing. Something that won’t have gone unnoticed by Microsoft.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft is not averse to porting their flagship office suite to new platforms. As well as crafting a special version for ARM-powered Windows 8 devices, ‘Office Mobile’ versions \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.zdnet.com/microsoft-office-coming-to-android-and-apple-devices-in-early-2013-7000005563/\"\u003eare planned\u003c/a\u003e for Android and iOS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft Office is already able to run on Ubuntu by way of Wine (or, for better results, using the ’CrossOver’ tool from CodeWeavers).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Linux port supposedly being trialled by Microsoft is a ‘fully native’ version.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePinch of Salt Needed\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"seasalt4\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/seasalt4-300x243.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"243\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore anyone pulls a muscle in celebration remember that this is a \u003cem\u003erumour\u003c/em\u003e from an unnamed ’\u003cem\u003esource\u003c/em\u003e‘.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis doesn’t preclude it from being true, of course. But it does mean that such news is best taken with a grain of salt.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHelp yourself to some from the bowl on the right. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven if it the ‘source’ is real and reliable it doesn’t mean the message is. We’ve seen mixed messages from companies on Linux ports before - just browse our \u003cem\u003eNetflix\u003c/em\u003e or \u003cem\u003ePhotoshop\u003c/em\u003e archives to see more company flip-flopping than jelly on a treadmill.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6 style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eTop Image Credit: \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/115851497099470446107\"\u003eDaniel Nadeau\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360161025213","timestampUsec":"1360161025213641","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/8e379de12962c33c","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","App","News",
"lastfm"],"title":"Is Last.FM’s New Linux App A Hit?","published":1360160039,"updated":1360160039,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/9mXh1pudwa4/is-last-fms-new-linux-app-a-hit","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/is-last-fms-new-linux-app-a-hit"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:300px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screenshot-from-2013-02-06-013935.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"The New Scrobbler from Last.FM\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screenshot-from-2013-02-06-013935-300x270.png\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"270\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe New Scrobbler from Last.FM\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLast.fm recently released a new version of their scrobbling app — including a \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.last.fm/download?showplatform\u003dLinux\"\u003enative version for linux\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eNo longer is it a second class citizen with a nasty, sub-par interface, but rather a ‘proper’ desktop app — just as you would expect to find on OSX or Windows.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilt on WebKit, the app unsurprisingly runs very smoothly. When you click on the tabs in the sidebar, you’ll glide between the panels, much like in Gwibber.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour \u003cem\u003eScrobbles\u003c/em\u003e are displayed in a list, and clicking on one takes you to an overview of the track and its artist.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eProfile\u003c/em\u003e section shows statistics about yourself: how many tracks you have Scrobbled, how many tracks you have ‘Loved’, and who your top-listened artists are.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen did you last have an urge to see what your contacts were listening to in real time? Now, you can — without even opening your web browser. The \u003cem\u003eFriends\u003c/em\u003e section shows who you are connected to on the service and what they are listening to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Bum Note\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, the main reason you might want to use this on your desktop is not yet available for Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn my testing \u003cem\u003enone\u003c/em\u003e of the usual media apps are detected by thew new Scobbler, and there are no settings pertaining to which apps should be scrobbled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe downloads page doesn’t actually say the Linux app will scrobble tracks from your local media players, so short of trying to shake some loose change out of Linux users pockets, you might wonder what the point of even making a Linux client was…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor now, the Linux Last.fm app isn’t useful for much more than looking shiny on your desktop unless you use the Radio feature:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePersonal Radio\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eRadio\u003c/em\u003e pane is the real boon of this app – \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.last.fm/subscribe\"\u003eLast.fm subscribers (£3/m)\u003c/a\u003e are able to listen to their radio directly in the desktop. Rhythmbox and a couple of other music apps support this as well, but options are always welcome — especially when provided by the official vendors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstalling Last.fm Scrobbler\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe app is distributed as an archive which needs to be manually built and installed. You can grab a tarball with everything you’ll need by hitting the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.last.fm/download?showplatform\u003dLinux\" title\u003d\"Go to Last.fm\u0026#39;s Linux download page\"\u003e Download Last.fm for Linux \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you are running a Debian or Ubuntu based distribution (which you probably are!) then you can use Last.fm’s \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"http://apt.last.fm/\"\u003eapt repository\u003c/a\u003e to install the app ‘the lazy way’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdding this isn’t quite as straightforward as adding a PPA, but it will ensure you are automatically updated to the lastest version as soon as its available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAlternative Scrobbling Methods\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eDoes it scrobble? The answer is almost always Yes!”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe majority of media applications these days support scrobbling out of the box, or via a plugin.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBanshee, Rhythmbox, Nuvola, VLC, Amarok, Clementine, Spotify for Linux are by some of the apps that come with Scrobble support built in. Check \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.last.fm/group/Does+It+Scrobble\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e to see if your favourite media player can scrobble.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll you need to do is enter your username and password, and the app will take care of the rest. Every track that gets played is submitted to your Last.fm profile.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBenefits of Scrobbling\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:300px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screenshot-from-2013-02-06-124852.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Last.fm can generate personalised music channels\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screenshot-from-2013-02-06-124852-300x208.png\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"208\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eLast.fm can generate personalised music channels\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKeeping a record of all the music you’ve listened to may seem a bit odd and pointless, save for nostalgic reasons and perhaps ‘showing off’ how much you listen to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you use the radio service, the channels can be tailored to what you like the most, whilst introducing you to new content at the same time. It uses a Love/Ban mechanism, where if you ‘Love’ the track then it will play more alike music, and if you ‘Ban’ it it will blacklist other music like it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLast.fm also has tight integration with music events. Through partnerships with organisations all around the world, events are pulled into their database. Using a combination of your music tastes and location, the events are promoted to those who Last.fm believe the music will appeal to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTry Last.fm’s new Linux scrobbler and see if it works for you. Not already scrobbling? \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.last.fm/join\"\u003eSign up\u003c/a\u003e and give it a go.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d9mXh1pudwa4:RIFCWKIJMug:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/9mXh1pudwa4\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1360006340260","timestampUsec":"1360006340260034","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/faba2cd0fbdfb58b","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"News","tomboy","ubuntuone"],"title":"Ubuntu One Turning Off Tomboy Note Sync Late February","published":1360006295,"updated":1360006295,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/VR-9Wf5Pei0/ubuntu-one-announce-tomboy-note-sync-to-stop-working-late-february","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/ubuntu-one-announce-tomboy-note-sync-to-stop-working-late-february"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu1-.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"ubuntu1-\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu1--300x171.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"171\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eTomboy note syncing through Ubuntu One will stop working at the end of February’s, the Ubuntu One team have announced. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe change will mean that new notes added to Tomboy \u003cem\u003eafter\u003c/em\u003e this date won’t sync to Ubuntu One, nor will existing notes ‘restore’ on a new installation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhy will it stop working?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLast year Ubuntu One began to roll out a number of infrastructure changes designed to improve performance of the service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese changes resulted in many niche features, such as Facebook \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Contacts Loses Facebook Sync\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/07/ubuntu-one-contacts-looses-facebook-sync\"\u003econtacts import\u003c/a\u003e and an \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/02/ubuntu-one-notes-feature-written-off\"\u003eonline notes app\u003c/a\u003e, discontinued. Their resources needed to maintain/port them on new infrastructure wasn’t justified given their low usage among Ubuntu One users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTomboy Sync meets this same fate, with an ‘upcoming database change’ being the catalyst for its cessation, with the ‘\u003cem\u003ehigh costs’\u003c/em\u003e involved in running the notes sync in its current state as another factor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBut the story doesn’t end here – at least not yet.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu One developers say that they are ‘\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003econtacting the Tomboy developers to help them support our new APIs which utilizes our new U1DB data sync service.’ \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough this ‘contact’ offers little in way of guarantee that Tomboy sync will return to Ubuntu One, it \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e great to see the Ubuntu One team trying to get it back despite only a ‘small number’ of folks making use of it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the mean time, if you’re looking for an Ubuntu One-friendly syncing alternative try Nitro tasks – available free from the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/nitro/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Nitro Tasks on Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dVR-9Wf5Pei0:sk6NNYuWrjQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg "scopes","unity"],"title":"IMDb, GrooveShark, eBay and More to Be Searchable from Unity in 13.04","published":1360000817,"updated":1360000817,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/9sygmdDZg0w/100-scopes-list-ubuntu-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/100-scopes-list-ubuntu-13-04"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/scopes11.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"scopes1\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/scopes11-300x143.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"143\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eAs part of the\u003ca title\u003d\"Unity to Ship with Smarter Dash Search in 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/unity-to-ship-with-smarter-scope-searching-in-13-04\"\u003e recent announcement that a smarter Scopes API\u003c/a\u003e is to debut in Ubuntu 13.04 came word that as many as \u003cem\u003e100\u003c/em\u003e new data sources could ship by default.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy so many? Ubuntu hope that providing more sources for queries to be searched against you’ll be able to find more of what you want without leaving the Dash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu wants to be more helpful and more relevant than it is at present – as well as faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eToggle On/Off\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike Ubuntu 12.10, these Scopes won’t continually be running in the background. They will only be ‘triggered’ if they’re going to provide ‘relevant’ results to whatever it is you’re searching for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re online then this judgement is made by an intelligent ‘Smart Scope Service’, which learns what is relevant based on users behaviour.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu call it ‘crowdsourcing relevancy’. I’m just going to call it the beginning of Skynet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChances are not everyone will need all 100 scopes, so Raring will, developers say, make it easy to toggle off those you don’t need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut what Scopes might we see shipped in Ubuntu 13.04? What sort of results can we expect to see filling up the Dash for certain queries?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e100 Scopes – A Work in Progress\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we see what we might be able to search, let’s take a moment to doff our digital caps to both Mark Tully \u0026amp; David Callé. This pair of prolific developers are responsible for the majority of Lenses and Scopes already available on Ubuntu, as well as those listed beneath.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis list is\u003cem\u003e still\u003c/em\u003e growing so don’t take it as exhaustive just yet. By the same token, some Scopes listed may (for one reason or another) not ship as default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCaveats aside, here’s a look at some of the services we can expect to search with the tap of the Super key later this year…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOnline Music Sources\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSoundcloud\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGrooveshark\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRadios\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu One Music\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMusic Players\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAudacious*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClementine*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGuayadeque*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003egMusicBrowser*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMusique*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRhythmbox*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNews, Weather \u0026amp; href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu20for20android20video20capture20-100012626-medium.jpeg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"ubuntu20for20android20video20capture20-100012626-medium\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ubuntu20for20android20video20capture20-100012626-medium.jpeg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"165\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCanonical are evaluating different options for improving the display server in Ubuntu as it seeks to span multiple devices, Ubuntu Community Manager Jono Bacon has recently confirmed. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe news comes by way of response to questions raised on the status of Ubuntu’s adoption of alternative display server ‘\u003cem\u003eWayland’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before we jump to precisely what Jono has said – and what it might mean for us – let’s go over the basics of what a display server is and what Ubuntu currently uses…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDisplay Servers, Serving You\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt present Ubuntu’s Unity interface runs atop \u003cem\u003eX server,\u003c/em\u003e a sort of ‘middle-man’ used to draw the UI, and user interaction with it, on screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eX is efficient at doing what it does but it has a problem: it is built upon code that’s almost 30 years old.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA mature code-base brings with it legacy support for features and functions that are no longer needed on modern desktops, much less phones and tablets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntending to address this is \u003cstrong\u003eWayland\u003c/strong\u003e – a relatively new display protocol that integrates features (like compositing) directly into the display server rather than adding them on as an afterthought.\u003cem\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu founder Mark Shuttleworth expressed an interest in using Wayland as Ubuntu’s display server \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/551\"\u003eback in 2010.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNewer Needs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e Ubuntu’s needs from a display server are now different… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the intervening years since Ubuntu’s initial interest in Wayland their needs have change considerably.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe project has has gone from being solely focused on the desktop market to one spanning multiple form-factors, like Phones and TVs. With each form factor boasting different screen-sizes  hardware configuarations, input-devices, and more it’s efficiency, performance, and adaptability that are most prized.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStressing that \u003cstrong\u003eno decision has yet been made\u003c/strong\u003e, Jono Bacon encompassed the dilemma as thus:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“What we don’t want to do is say: ‘Let’s move away from X which includes a tonne of functionality that we don’t need, that drags us down’ and move to something else that includes a tonne of functionality that we don’t need and drags us down.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e‘Things are still very much up in the air right now, nothing is finalized.’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdding that\u003cem\u003e ’the simple reality is that X doesn’t meet those needs, Wayland doesn’t meet those needs.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral weeks back, Bacon\u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"http://youtu.be/sZv7aoiq1Kw?t\u003d24m32s\"\u003e mooted that one possible solution on the table\u003c/a\u003e was the ’….\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003elikelihood …of building our own display server’ - \u003c/em\u003ebut stressed that such a decision, and all of the complexities it would entail, was yet to be made.\u003cem\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘Things are still very much up in the air right now,’\u003c/em\u003e he emphasised,\u003cem\u003e ’Nothing is finalized.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe ‘What If?’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:270px\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Ubuntu phone in Hand\" alt\u003d\"phone\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/phone-300x171.jpg\" width\u003d\"270\" height\u003d\"154\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhat Display Server Powers the Ubuntu Phone?\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf Ubuntu don’t decide to go with either\u003cem\u003e X\u003c/em\u003e or \u003cem\u003eWayland\u003c/em\u003e – and, again,\u003cstrong\u003e no such decision has yet been taken\u003c/strong\u003e – what options might we see them use?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAndroid is powered by an open-source display driver that is neither X or Wayland, but is capable of working work across mobile, tv, tablet and laptop interfaces. Could a fork of this be one solution?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother option would be to create their own – either from scratch or based on an existing project. But the quagmire of complexity that would go with such an effort is vast – even for a company as seemingly well-resourced as Canonical.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that we don’t have long to wait before we find out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirstly, Bacon says that more information on the decision making process ahead will be available in the ‘next couple of weeks’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecondly, we can expect the first installable image of \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Phone\u003c/em\u003e - along with its source code – sometime towards the latter part of February/Early March. This will allow developers to go hands on in assessing the needs and realities of creating a pan-device display server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIt Doesn’t Even Matter\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRegardless of what Ubuntu do choose to use – be it their own, Wayland, or Android’s display server – one thing is certain: the graphics performance will be better than what we have now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhatever Canonical/Ubuntu end up deciding on we can be assured that they wouldn’t jump ship from what currently works unless a speedier boat was waiting in the water… \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003debQpTDE1bJY:ym8x-BgcH14:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "Dev","News","indicator sync","raring ringtail","ubuntuone"],"title":"New Sync Menu Added to Ubuntu 13.04 by Default","published":1359838050,"updated":1359838050,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/bApcXziKie8/new-sync-menu-added-to-ubuntu-13-04-by-default","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/02/new-sync-menu-added-to-ubuntu-13-04-by-default"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-02-at-20.11.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Screen Shot 2013-02-02 at 20.11\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-02-at-20.11.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn update to the Ubuntu One desktop client in 13.04 has brought with it a new ‘Sync Menu’.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe panel-based menu provides quick access to common Ubuntu One service features, including an ‘On/Off’ toggle; list of recent transfers; and links to online information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/sync-menu-1.jpg\" width\u003d\"250\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn keeping with a design decision introduced in Ubuntu’s previous release, the Sync Menu will only appear \u003cem\u003eif \u003c/em\u003ean Ubuntu One account has been set-up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t use Ubuntu One? That doesn’t mean you might not use it. Ubuntu One may be supported by default, but other ‘cloud’ services, like Dropbox and podcast downloaders , are mentioned in the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SyncMenu\"\u003edesign spec\u003c/a\u003e for the indicator.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne thing the menu isn’t designed to do is monitor \u003cem\u003eall\u003c/em\u003e downloads; it’s not a ‘download menu’. Torrent apps, browser downloads, etc are all outside the scope of the utility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTeased in 12.10\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe indicator was originally targeted for inclusion in Ubuntu 12.10. And although i\u003ca title\u003d\"Take A Look At Ubuntu’s New Sync Menu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/have-you-seen-ubuntus-new-sync-menu\"\u003et did find a place on the desktop for a few weeks\u003c/a\u003e it was pulled before release due to a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/indicator-sync/+bug/1053482/comments/3\"\u003elack of testing\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy landing the menu in 13.04 early developers are hoping to avoid this problem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbApcXziKie8:Wc3p_TGWM-w:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbApcXziKie8:Wc3p_TGWM-w:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbApcXziKie8:Wc3p_TGWM-w:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg
