},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1359582009032","timestampUsec":"1359582009032610","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/c0623e88c7ca6216","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"Dev","lenses","raring ringtail","scopes","unity"],"title":"Unity to Ship with Smarter Dash Search in 13.04","published":1359581958,"updated":1359581958,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/lMik6LdgRSw/unity-to-ship-with-smarter-scope-searching-in-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/unity-to-ship-with-smarter-scope-searching-in-13-04"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/brain.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"brain\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/brain.jpg\" width\u003d\"184\" height\u003d\"200\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eChanges to the way results are delivered into in Unity’s Dash are on their way to Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn an attempt to both broaden the types of data that can be searched from the Dash and increase the relevancy of results, Ubuntu and Canonical are to introduce some major improvements to the Scopes API.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“‘We want to expand the number of installed scopes so when you search something in the dash it can pull back a variety of results – but results that a relevant to you,’\u003c/em\u003e explains Jono Bacon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘In 13.04 we will have a much more diverse search experience.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo how will it do this?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow It Works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChiefly, queries made in the Dash will now pass through a central server maintained by Canonical, along with a list of the Scopes (‘search engines’) you have installed on your computer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe server will then pair up your query with the most relevant Scopes – be they remote or locally installed – and pass this information back to Unity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnly the Scopes suggested by the Smart Scope Service will be triggered to deliver results, making the Dash perform quickly \u003cem\u003edespite\u003c/em\u003e as many as 100 Scopes being available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll Scopes are ‘terminated’ when the Dash closes; none are left running in the background to sap on bandwidth or memory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLocal results – your files, photos and documents, etc – are given greater priority in results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCrowd Sourcing Relevancy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Dash will learn what results from what scopes are most relevant to users… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe interesting bit in these changes is the way in which relevancy is deduced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Smart Scope Service – the remote brain of the Dash – will ‘learn’ what results from what scopes are most relevant based on what you and other users click on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThink of it as ‘crowd-sourcing’ relevancy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut what if you have installed a brand spankin’ new Scope that the server might not yet know about?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgain, the server is able to learn about it. And if it proves relevant, and other users have it too, results for it will be triggered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBeing Specific\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou don’t have to solely rely on a remote brain to decide what is relevant and what isn’t. Say you want to search for ‘Doctor Who’ but \u003cem\u003eonly\u003c/em\u003e in music.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Dash, in a Google-esque way, allows you to prefix a search term with the Scope name to be specific:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, for example you would search:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003emusic: doctor who\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis would only return results from the Music Scope.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e100 Scopes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs many as 100 Scopes will with Ubuntu 13.04 by default, with \u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eeBay, Etsy, Soundcloud, Yelp, DeviantArt, Grooveshark, Google Drive, IMDb \u003c/strong\u003eamongst them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResults from many of these will integrate with \u003cem\u003eUnity Previews, \u003c/em\u003eallowing you to preview an image, watch a trailer, or listen to a track without needing to open a browser.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemember, Scopes are best through of as little ‘Search Engines’. They are not lenses. So if this news made you gulp with fear as the thought of 100 mini-icons straddling the bottom of the Dash, take a breath and relax.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePrivacy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf this all sounds like a privacy time-bomb waiting to happen you can relax. The furore surrounding the ‘Amazon Lens’ in 12.10 has seen privacy placed at the forefront of this development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrivacy proponents will be glad to hear:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eControls for turning off specific scopes on a one-by-one basis\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eData collected by the Scope Server (and where it’s sent to) is fully documented online\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOnly IP address is logged, but not in a way that makes it identifiable (or useful) to developers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt’s claimed\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e that Scope searches will be ‘more private than Googling’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOpt-out option for Smart Scope Service.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCanonical are also making the ‘Online’ element of Unity more explicit:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe Dash search box will read: “search your computer and online sources”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe BFB shows a similarly worded tool-tip\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhen Can We Try it?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re itching to try the new and improved Dash out you don’t have long to wait. Ubuntu developers have said that the new API and default Scopes will be uploaded to Ubuntu 13.04 Daily in the next few weeks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eDo you like the sound of these changes? Is the Dash finally becoming what you’d hoped? Share your thoughts in the comments below. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFurther technical information on the changes can be read on the \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SmartScopes1304Spec\"\u003eUbuntu Wiki\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp "Dev","Idea","raring ringtail","unity"],"title":"Quicklist Window Switching Patch Proposed for Unity","published":1359566467,"updated":1359566467,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/jJ_LBVsmfsM/quicklist-window-switching-patch-proposed-for-unity","type":"text/html"}],"enclosure":[{"href":"http://killem.al/windowlist.ogv","type":"video/ogg","length":"9612464"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/quicklist-window-switching-patch-proposed-for-unity"}],
"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/switcher1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"switcher\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/switcher1.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn additional way of switching between application windows in Ubuntu’s Unity desktop has been proposed.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~lukas-vacek\"\u003eLukas Vacek\u003c/a\u003e‘s idea is to add application window entries to an app item’s quicklist.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis, he argues, will allow users to switch between windows ‘more rapidly’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike most idle ‘would like to have’s’ thrown out in to the ether Lukas \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/unity/+bug/1107866/comments/10\"\u003ehas filed a fully-implemented patch\u003c/a\u003e of his suggestion against Unity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe’s also created a video showing off his patch in action which you can see by pressing the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://killem.al/windowlist.ogv\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e View Video of Patched Switcher \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDefaults Are Slicker but Slower\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnity currently provides two methods of switching between multiple windows of the same application.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe first uses the universal keyboard shortcut for switching: \u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eAlt+Tab.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe second is a keyboard-free solution: left-click on the App Launcher item itself to reveal windows as a ‘spread’.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese ‘visual’ approaches are slick. Very slick. And if you’re a keyboard user there is nothing faster than a quick slam-dunk of the Alt+Tab, or Alt+` keys.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut is the mouse-centric method the fastest? Perhaps not. The effect used to draw the spread, and animate the window back to normal size, is slower –  albeit marginally - than that of a simple ‘right click’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/spread.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"spread\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/spread.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"327\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNot Accepted – Yet\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we all get too excited (or riled) about the idea it’s important to stress that \u003cstrong\u003eit is only a patch\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis feature was \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e created by the Ubuntu Design Team, and it has \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e been accepted into Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWould you like to see an option for this behaviour added? \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003djJ_LBVsmfsM:27KJQ2QZB3E:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003djJ_LBVsmfsM:27KJQ2QZB3E:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003djJ_LBVsmfsM:27KJQ2QZB3E:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003djJ_LBVsmfsM:27KJQ2QZB3E:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1359487711681","timestampUsec":"1359487711681547","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/f8a9bdd7d19082ce","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","How To",
"lovefilm","lucid","netflix","precise","redbox instant","technolotics","wine"],"title":"[How To] Watch LOVEFiLM, Redbox Instant or Netflix on Ubuntu","published":1359487676,"updated":1359487676,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/p_OTa7O3yuo/how-to-watch-lovefilm-redbox-instant-or-netflix-on-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/how-to-watch-lovefilm-redbox-instant-or-netflix-on-ubuntu"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:748px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/doctor.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"LOVEFiLM running in Ubuntu 12.10\" alt\u003d\"doctor\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/doctor.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"481\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eLOVEFiLM running in Ubuntu 12.10\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e‘They’ are a handful of the world’s most popular on-demand video services, whilst ‘it’ is the third largest desktop operating system around.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetween them they boast tens of – if not hundreds of – millions of users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn theory they should love one another, right? Sadly ‘\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003etechnolotics’\u003c/em\u003e ( ‘technology politics’) chose to intervene in this otherwise fated relationship…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eVoD Services\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Netflix website\" href\u003d\"http://netflix.com\"\u003eNetflix,\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca title\u003d\"LoveFILM Website\" href\u003d\"http://www.lovefilm.com/\"\u003eLOVEFiLM\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca title\u003d\"Redbox Instant Website\" href\u003d\"https://www.redboxinstant.com/\"\u003eRedbox Instant\u003c/a\u003e don’t officially work on Ubuntu. And if their respective companies are to be believed \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" title\u003d\"Netflix: ‘No Change in our plans for Linux’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/netflix-no-change-in-our-plans-for-linux\"\u003ethey have no plans to do so\u003c/a\u003e anytime soon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut saying ‘no’ to the Linux crowd is like waving a red flag to a bull, or a backstage pass for a One Direction concert in the face of a tween horde – one side will get what they want, pain or no pain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe ‘Silverlight’ Issue\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e“Microsoft have refused to provide Linux users with a native version of Silverlight.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo be fair to Netflix, Amazon and Verizon/Redbox, it’s only partly their fault that they don’t support Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSomewhere along their respective development timelines their engineers (or middle-management) were swayed by the piracy-protected lure of Microsoft’s Silverlight plugin.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis one-time Flash competitor gives them a blanket of security with which they can use to warm up otherwise icey media conglomerates, thereby defrosting access to their chest of TV shows and movies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e“Linux developers are used to being told ‘no’. Then doing it anyway.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo-one can blame them for seeking out a secure, well-documented way to deliver content from the amorphous mass of the cloud to users’ desktops. That’s just technology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘-\u003cem\u003eolitics\u003c/em\u003e‘ comes into play because of Microsoft. They, for various legit-sounding but not entirely faithful reasons, have refused to provide Linux users with a native version of their Silverlight plugin.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause of this Silverlight-streamed content cannot legally be streamed on Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThat Red Flag…\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLinux developers are used to being told ‘no’, then doing it anyway. “\u003cem\u003eIt can’t be done”\u003c/em\u003e translates as \u003cem\u003e“You should give it a go…”\u003c/em\u003e in the Linux mindset.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo the (comparatively) good news for movie buffs and couch potatoes is that content from Netflix, LOVEFiLM and Redbox Instant \u003cstrong\u003ecan be viewed on Ubuntu\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s made possible using a custom build of WINE – a set of software libraries that allow native Windows apps, libraries and components to run on Linux – maintained by Erich Hoover.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHoover’s \u003ca title\u003d\"More about Erich Hoover\u0026#39;s WINE\" href\u003d\"http://www.compholio.com/\"\u003eversion of WINE\u003c/a\u003e (named ‘Compholio’) is built with patches specific to making Sliverlight (and a handful of other apps) play nicely out of the box.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlongside this he also \u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~ehoover/+archive/compholio/\"\u003eprovides a PPA\u003c/a\u003e (‘Personal Package Archive’) containing pre-built packages for Netflix, LOVEFiLM and Redbox that install everything needed to run the respective services with zero fuss.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese ‘Desktop Packages’ comprises of:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA patched version of WINE*\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFirefox for Windows (with custom settings)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMicrosoft Silverlight Plugin V4\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eParticular work has gone on tweaking Firefox so as to provide as native an experience as is possible on Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:748px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"netflix1\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eNetflix running on Ubuntu 12.10\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAdd the Netflix WINE PPA\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first step to getting one of the VoD services up and running is to add Erich Hoover’s PPA to your System. It supports Ubuntu 9.10 through 13.04 – so no matter which version of Ubuntu you’re on you’re covered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis can be done in a number of ways but the easiest is to use the following command in a new \u003cem\u003eTerminal\u003c/em\u003e window:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ccode\u003esudo apt-add-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:ehoover/compholio\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Netflix/LOVEFiLM/Redbox Instant Apps in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the PPA added the next step is to install the ‘VoD Service’ you require. Remember that\u003cstrong\u003e all of these services are subscription based\u003c/strong\u003e. They are not free.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install \u003cstrong\u003eLOVEFiLM \u003c/strong\u003erun the following command in a new Terminal window:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ccode\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install lovefilm-desktop\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install\u003cstrong\u003e Redbox Instant\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003er\u003c/strong\u003eun the following command in a new Terminal window:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ccode\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install redbox-desktop\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install \u003cstrong\u003eNetflix \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003erun the following command in a new Terminal window:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ccode\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install netflix-desktop\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce installed open the Unity Dash and search for the item using the service name. Click on its icon to open it and you’re all set – just log in and start watching!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e*Installing this version of WINE will uninstall the ‘standard’ version.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dp_OTa7O3yuo:sm3k35aACuc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/p_OTa7O3yuo\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1359398303229","timestampUsec":"1359398303229093","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/8286a11f57eff733","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Dev","ubuntu developer week",
"udw"],"title":"Ubuntu Developer Week Starts Tomorrow","published":1359394281,"updated":1359394281,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/0ZzRv7mEf-Q/ubuntu-developer-week-is-back","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-developer-week-is-back"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe times for Ubuntu have never been more exciting. Cloud, server, desktop, laptop, TV, tablet, phone – everything runs Ubuntu or is soon going to. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis makes developing Ubuntu very special, because fixes which go into Ubuntu in one place will benefit all form factors and all circumstances where it’s used. By improving Ubuntu you make millions of people around the globe happy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring every 6 month release cycle we run \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuDeveloperWeek\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu Developer Week\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. It’s back and we’re going to have it from \u003cstrong\u003e29th January (tomorrow!)\u003c/strong\u003e to \u003cstrong\u003e31st January\u003c/strong\u003e. During the event we will have online sessions where seasoned Ubuntu developers introduce you to their respective area of expertise or to Ubuntu Development in general.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe will have many great sessions, from hands-on introduction to packaging and Ubuntu development to talks about how to quickly get involved in certain teams and interact with other projects. We will talk about tools and infrastructure, fixing bugs, finding memleaks, working with apps, create Ubuntu images and much much much more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is the best opportunity to get a feel for how Ubuntu development works, get to know people and ask all the questions you might have.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI talked to a few session hosts, read below what they had to say.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Martin Pitt\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/pitti.png\" width\u003d\"156\" height\u003d\"200\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eMartin Pitt\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMartin Pitt\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMartin Pitt, who will talk about Automated Testing, says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“We\u003cem\u003e have been, and are changing the Ubuntu development process to employ automated testing and avoid introducing regressions, and to improve confidence, focus, and development speed. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn the first talk I will give an overview about \u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003ethe various kinds of tests that we do, so that you know where to watch out for failures and get debugging information. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe second talk focuses on how to write tests, i.e. which technologies are available for e.g. hardware and GUI \u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003erelated behaviour or system-wide integration checks.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Stefano Rivera\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/tumbleweed.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eStefano Rivera\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStefano Rivera\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStefano Rivera, who will talk about Upstreams and Debian in particular, said:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eSo, working effectively in Ubuntu means also working with the teams and people upstream who wrote the software we distribute. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eI’ll talk about why this is important, when it’s necessary, and how to go about it. In particular, our most important upstream is Debian. Debian has a rather unusual (though powerful) bug-tracker. We’ll cover finding, submitting, and modifying bugs on it.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Chris Wilson\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/notgary.jpeg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eChris Wilson\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e Chris Wilson\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChris Wilson, project leader of the Hundred Papercuts Team, says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eUnity may be the shiny new thing that everyone loves, but style without substance is only so much fluff, and the substance of Ubuntu is still its GTK-based apps. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOnce Hundred Paper Cuts focuses it’s attention on that substance, rubbing out the little annoyances that get under our skin every day we’re using Ubuntu. This session will introduce you to the project, how it works, and how to get involved. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you want to contribute to Ubuntu in a way that has the biggest impact on the quality of experience for the end user, then don’t miss this.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBhavani Shankar\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Bhavani Shankar\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/coolbhavi.jpeg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eBhavani Shankar\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBhavani Shankar, said about his talk about patch systems:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eMany a time we wonder how to integrate a particular fix a particular part of the code in a program and upload into repositories without having to change code each time by hand and making it clumsy. In this session I’m going to show how to use different patch management systems that are in practice now.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAbout his talk about the app review process in Ubuntu he says: “\u003cem\u003eIn this session I’m going to explain the present workflow of reviewing apps and give an introduction into the new app dev upload process to automate reviews.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/bd.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Benjamin Drung\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/bd.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\" height\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eBenjamin Drung\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBenjamin Drung \u0026amp; Michael Bienia\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBenjamin Drung and Michael Bienia (of whom the internet does not seem to have any pictures whatsoever) are going to lead the Developers Roundtable and have this to say:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eDo you have questions about Ubuntu development? Here you have the best opportunity to ask everything you want to know, because we will have a number of developers there who can answer your questions for you.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMichael Hall\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Michael Hall\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mhall.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eMichael Hall\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMichael Hall never gets enough, so he’s giving two sessions at UDW this time around. Here’s what he has to say about Ubuntu App Developer tools:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eUbuntu provides a variety of tools to help you write and manage your applications. This session will cover everything from bootstrapping a new project, to making the final packages installable through the Software Center and everything in between.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe will also talk about Unity integration: “\u003cem\u003eThe Unity desktop provides many opportunities for your application to integrate with the full user experience. Learn how to add your Application to the Unity messaging or sound indicators, add your own indicator, extend the Unity Launcher and much more.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"David Planella\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/dpm.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\" height\u003d\"150\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eDavid Planella\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDavid Planella\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDavid Planella, who will talk about “Writing apps for Ubuntu”, says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eLearn how to use the best open source tools and technologies to write your apps on Ubuntu, both on the desktop and on the phone. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou’ll be able to get your first app running in a matter of minutes!\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOliver Grawert\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ogra.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Oliver Grawert\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ogra.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eOliver Grawert\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’re excited to have Oliver Grawert here, who will talk about Creating Ubuntu images and the Nexus7 images in particular.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe will talk about “\u003cem\u003e[t]he Ubuntu image build infrastructure at a glance, what tools do we use, how do they interact and how is the hardware set up for building the official Ubuntu images\u003c/em\u003e” and “\u003cem\u003e[h]ow are the nexus7 images different from “normal” Ubuntu images, what can be hacked to make small modifications, how can they be re-packed or supplied with a different root file system\u003c/em\u003e“.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAlex Chiang\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Alex Chiang\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/achiang.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eAlex Chia\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlex Chiang will introduce us to the world of memory leaks and says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eAs we polish and prep Ubuntu for mobile devices, a key activity will be hunting down and squashing memory leaks. This session will discuss the basic theory of leaks, introduce valgrind and our brand new apport-valgrind wrapper, and how to analyze a valgrind log file. A C/C++ background will be helpful to get the most out of this session, but is not strictly required.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNicholas Skaggs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:156px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Nicholas Skaggs\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/balloons.jpg\" width\u003d\"156\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eNicholas SkaggsM\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eQA mastermind Nicholas “balloons” Skaggs will talk us through “Automated Testing with autopilot” and says:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eLearn about how autopilot is utilized by the unity team and quality team to test the ubuntu desktop. We’ll also provide an overview of what autopilot can do, show and run some example testcases, and give you the knowledge needed to get started writing your own autopilot testcases.\u003c/em\u003e”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eJoining In\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe forum we use for this is IRC, as it makes it easy to interact for many people without losing track, you can easily copy/paste and we can save the logs as searchable docs afterwards. You join in by simply \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuDeveloperWeek/JoiningIn\"\u003econnecting to #ubuntu-classroom\u003c/a\u003e on irc.freenode.net.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCheck out the \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuDeveloperWeek\"\u003eschedule\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e and find more info on the Ubuntu wiki. We hope to see you all there, please let you friends know too. :-)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0ZzRv7mEf-Q:l1EOkHs675o:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/0ZzRv7mEf-Q\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Daniel Holbach","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1359373115474","timestampUsec":"1359373115474573","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/e633152e9d093cb1","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","Dev","News",
"raring ringtail"],"title":"Ubuntu 13.04 Wallpaper Contest Opens for Entries","published":1359373069,"updated":1359373069,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/Crd3Hb9lpaI/ubuntu-13-04-wallpaper-contest-now-open","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-13-04-wallpaper-contest-now-open"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"wallpaper-tile\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/wallpaper-tile-300x171.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"171\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCameras at the ready – the contest to choose 10 new wallpapers for Ubuntu 13.04 has kicked off.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe bi-annual competition is open to anyone who thinks that their photographic or illustrated design is good enough to feature on the desktop of millions of Ubuntu PCs around the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs in the past, submissions are to be collected via a special Ubuntu Wallpaper pool \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.flickr.com/groups/ringtailwallpaper/\"\u003eon photo-sharing site Flickr.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eQuality not Quantity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs with the last contest for Ubuntu 12.10, only \u003cstrong\u003eone wallpaper\u003c/strong\u003e can be submitted per person.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe only need to look back at last release’s beautiful bounty of backgrounds to see that this \u003cem\u003e“quality not quantity”\u003c/em\u003e approach has paid off.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnly 10 images will be selected as winners to ship in Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003ci\u003eRules\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Ubuntu Design Team’s Otto Greenslade offers a few pointers on creating a potentially winning entry:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDon’t create busy images, or fill them with too many shapes and colors\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse a single point of focus; a single area that draws the eye in\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAvoid having anything on the left and top edges as this will clash with Unity interface elements\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTest your image at different aspect ratios to make sure it ‘works’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFurther composition guidelines can be found on the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Artwork/Documentation/Backgrounds\"\u003eUbuntu Wiki\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeadline\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlanning on taking part? You need to make sure that you have added your submission to the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.flickr.com/groups/ringtailwallpaper/\"\u003eFlickr group pool\u003c/a\u003e by 6pm GMT on 8th March.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter this deadline the judging panel – once again made up of the previous release’s winning artists’ – will begin the unenviable process of sifting through and selecting prospective images for inclusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe results will be announced later that month before being uploaded to and installed in Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOne entry per winners\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnter via \u003ca "App","News","Wallpaper","android","livewallpaper","ubuntu phone"],"title":"New Options Added to ‘Ubuntu Phone Live Wallpaper’ for Android","published":1359308026,"updated":1359308026,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/JIy3HXBWwVE/ubuntu-phone-live-wallpaper-android-update","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-live-wallpaper-android-update"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMinor customisation options have been added to Ubuntu Phone Live Wallpaper – an Android app that apes the look of  the Ubuntu mobile lock screen.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough none of the new additions are of the brain-melting variety they will be welcomed by tweakers looking to tailor the drape to suit their tastes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:720px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/live-wallpaper-resize-preview.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Resizing and Reposition Options Added\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/live-wallpaper-resize-preview.jpg\" width\u003d\"720\" height\u003d\"449\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eResizing and Reposition Options Added\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChanges\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe major change concerns the “circle” centre-point of the wallpaper. This can now be resized and repositioned from the ‘\u003cem\u003eLive Wallpaper Preview\u003c/em\u003e‘ screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePinching in and out will make the circle smaller and bigger respectively; whilst a simple tap and drag on it will allow you to move it anywhere on the screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘Clock’ and ‘Date’ formats can be adjusted, too. When previewing the Live Wallpaper press the ‘Settings…’ item to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet Clock display to 12 hour or 24 hour mode\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet Date format to DD/MM/YYYY or MM/DD/YYYY\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Phone Live Wallpaper is a free download for Android 2.2 and higher, available from the Google Play Store. You can see our video review of the previous release \u003ca style\u003d\"font-size:14px\" title\u003d\"OMG! on YouTube!\" href\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v\u003dqQMhg_QFuNA\u0026amp;list\u003dUUIiSwcm9xiFb3Y4wjzR41eQ\u0026amp;index\u003d2\"\u003eon our YouTube channel.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1359123130072","timestampUsec":"1359123130072011","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/9d27791ef9387f73","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"News","lts","rollingrelease","ubuntu"],"title":"Ubuntu Not Switching to Rolling Release Model","published":1359123027,"updated":1359123027,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/aDbg6eeYx1Q/ubuntu-not-switching-to-rolling-release-model","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-not-switching-to-rolling-release-model"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu will not be switching to a ‘Rolling Release’ model anytime soon, despite recent reports to the contrary.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut Ubuntu’s Jono Bacon has revealed that \u003cem\u003epieces are being put into place\u003c/em\u003e‘ to allow such a decision to be made at a later date.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLTS to LTS\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/rolling-icon.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"rolling-icon\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/rolling-icon2.jpg\" width\u003d\"300\" height\u003d\"308\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eA rolling release model would see Ubuntu \u003cstrong\u003econtinually updated\u003c/strong\u003e with new apps and features as it ‘rolled’ along rather than, as is the case at present, them only arriving in one go every 6 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch a change would also mean fewer releases, or so says \u003cem\u003eLeann Ogasawara\u003c/em\u003e of the Ubuntu Kernel Team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a video Q\u0026amp;A session earlier this week she suggestion that, should Ubuntu switch to a rolling release in the future, ‘interim releases’ would be ditched. Instead, Ubuntu would “roll” between \u003cem\u003eLong\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e Term Support\u003c/em\u003e versions, currently released once every two years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis isn’t a new revelation. \u003ca title\u003d\"We Interview Leann Ogasawara, Canonical Kernel Team Manager, Marathoner and Mother\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/omg-interviews-leann-ogasawara-canonical-kernel-team-manager-marathoner-and-mother\"\u003eIn an interview with us last summer\u003c/a\u003e Leann spoke of it:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e“We’re also trying to lay some ground work to support the idea of a rolling release model for the kernel beginning with the 14.04 LTS release.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow Ubuntu Currently Works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e ‘Our [current] release process is very complicated…’ \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo that’s what a rolling release is – but how does it differ to how Ubuntu works today?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu development currently happens to a set schedule: there are two releases a year, one every six months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis reliable schedule gives developers a backdrop against which they can accurately plan features, updates and so on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut a ‘long game’ is also in action.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘Some areas we want to improve take longer than six months,’\u003c/em\u003e Ubuntu Community Manager Jono Bacon explained in a video Q\u0026amp;A earlier this week,\u003cem\u003e ’So what we tend to do then is think in LTS’s’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLTS releases are made once every 2 years and are typically backed by 3-5 years of security and bug fix updates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut as focus has fallen to improving not only the quality of Ubuntu but that of the underlying engineering and maintenance processes a new approach, that of the Rolling Release, has been under discussion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“\u003cem\u003eDelivering apps is complex and hard; the way our archives are laid out doesn’t make a huge amount of sense; and another element is that our release process is very complicated,’\u003c/em\u003e Jono explains.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘That impacts our flavours (Kubuntu, Lubuntu, Xubuntu, etc). They should be able to have control over their own destiny.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“One of the overriding things that we want to improve going forward is ‘Daily Quality’,\u003c/em\u003e‘ he adds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“In the old days of Ubuntu the development release was a little shaky. We wanted to prevent against that happening; the development release of Ubuntu should be rock solid. It should feel stable. So the general goal has been ‘How can we keep the general development version of Ubuntu moving along, but continue to maintain the quality?’. That’s when the topic of rolling release comes up.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNot Happening Yet\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e A Rolling Release is the right step for us to make… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good/bad news (depending on your viewpoint) is that Ubuntu is not switching to a Rolling Release model yet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, Ubuntu Community Manager Jono Bacon goes as far as to say that ‘it would be a disaster’ should it happen right now!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut he does concede that switching to it at some point in the future is ‘\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003ethe right step forward for us [Ubuntu] to make.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“What we’ve done is identify all the work we need to do for 14.04… [and] to put together all the pieces we need, so that we can decide in at a later date’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e—\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWould you like to see Ubuntu switch to a rolling release model? Or are you happy with the way Ubuntu currently works? Let us know in the comments.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003daDbg6eeYx1Q:oSkBQ4qcqok:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/aDbg6eeYx1Q\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"softwareupdater"],"title":"‘Tweaked’ Software Updater Lands in Ubuntu 13.04","published":1359057818,"updated":1359057818,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/N94cOqvhSgY/update-updater-app-arrives-in-raring","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/update-updater-app-arrives-in-raring"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVisual refinements to Ubuntu’s system update app have been accepted into Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe new changes, \u003ca title\u003d\"Usability Tweaks Proposed for ‘Software Updater’ App\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/usability-tweaks-proposed-for-software-updater-app\"\u003ewhich we’re discussed earlier this week\u003c/a\u003e, aim to make the detailed information \u003cem\u003eSoftware Updater\u003c/em\u003e displays to users easier to digest.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:650px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/software-updater-in-raring.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"An Update to the Update App\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/software-updater-in-raring.jpg\" width\u003d\"650\" height\u003d\"545\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn Update to the Update App\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChanges see:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRelated updates are now ‘grouped’ together\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCore Ubuntu packages are grouped into ‘Ubuntu Base’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLibrary and dependencies display their description rather than the name\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePackage sizes moved to the right under ‘Download’ header\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e‘Install’ header above checkbox column\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRestart icon displayed next to updates requiring restart\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo match the new look Ubuntu’s Design Team \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Ask Community to Help Create New App Icon\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-ask-community-to-create-new-software-updater-icon\"\u003eare also looking to revamp \u003cem\u003eSoftware Updater\u003c/em\u003e‘s icon.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dN94cOqvhSgY:pMxsfecAPvU:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1358967101145","timestampUsec":"1358967101145669","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/5db534f9f9842d39","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh","News","Ubuntu Phone",
"core apps project","ubuntu phone"],"title":"12 Default Ubuntu Phone Apps to be ‘Community Created’","published":1358961235,"updated":1358961235,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/19lQNybKSWQ/12-default-ubuntu-phone-apps-to-be-community-created","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/12-default-ubuntu-phone-apps-to-be-community-created"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eCanonical are to seek community involvement in the design and development of 12 core apps for the Ubuntu Phone.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:258px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"twitter-app\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/twitter-app.jpg\" width\u003d\"258\" height\u003d\"223\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Phone Twitter App Design\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis initiative, they say, will give the wider community ‘a fantastic opportunity to create software that could run on millions of handsets.’\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut news of the project doesn’t come as a surprise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone OS Unveiled by Canonical\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-os-unveiled-by-canonical\"\u003eJanuary’s product launch for the Ubuntu Phone\u003c/a\u003e, Ubuntu founder Mark Shuttleworth spoke of his desire to engage the community in shaping its future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith Canonical having been criticised in the past for an alleged ”closed doors” approach to development, a “skunkworks” programme was announced late last year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis initiative aims to bring outside help in shaping otherwise ‘secret until ready’ projects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far, as part of this specific project, 12 applications are currently being sought. These will ship as default apps in the Ubuntu Phone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey include 8 “traditional” apps:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFile Manager\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCalendar\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eClock/Alarm\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWeather\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTerminal\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCalculator\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eE-Mail Client\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDocument Viewer\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd 4 “social” apps:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYouTube\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTwitter\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacebook\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRSS Reader\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese will sit alongside an as-yet unspecified number of other core apps (likely to Notes, Gallery, Music, Software Center, etc)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesigners Wanted\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach of the 12 applications listed above has a wiki page that details the purpose of the application; provide ‘user stories’ to define the requirements; and link to relevant design ideas submitted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterested designers then request access to the Ubuntu \u003cem\u003eMyBalsamiq\u003c/em\u003e mock-up site. Here existing designs can be viewed and commented on, or new designs added.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne important thing to note is that only wire-frame mock-ups are being sought, not final visual designs. This is because the “visual” element is provided by the SDK.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese designs will be used as “food for thought” when the applications come to be made into real working applications.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn summary:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePick an application\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRead the brief on the Wiki\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRead the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuPhone/CoreApps/Design\"\u003eDesign Guidelines\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eApply to join the collaborative mock-up board\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSelect a design and suggest improvements \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eor\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd your new design\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGetting Involved\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeel like you could help? You’ll find all the information you need on the Ubuntu Wiki.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuPhone/CoreApps/\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Development Initiative\"\u003e Ubuntu Phone Core Apps Project \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d19lQNybKSWQ:HSxcKTo6kfc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/19lQNybKSWQ\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"softwareupdater"],"title":"Ubuntu Ask Community to Help Create New App Icon","published":1358947660,"updated":1358947660,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/HQe3if_Un_E/ubuntu-ask-community-to-create-new-software-updater-icon","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-ask-community-to-create-new-software-updater-icon"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu’s Design Team are reaching out to the community to help design a new icon for Ubuntu’s \u003cem\u003eSoftware Updater\u003c/em\u003e application.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe icons in Ubuntu 12.10 and 13.04 are described by design team member \u003cem\u003eMatthew Paul Thomas\u003c/em\u003e as creating ‘a usability problem’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe says that neither provide the application’s dialog with ‘[a] visual clue that this is an official Ubuntu thing’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConfirming Authority\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis problem isn’t new, or without previous address.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn updated ‘\u003cem\u003eSoftware Updater\u003c/em\u003e‘ design, proposed for Ubuntu 13.04 back in \u003ca title\u003d\"New Dash Icons Proposed for Ubuntu 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/new-dash-icons-proposed-for-ubuntu-13-04\"\u003eDecember\u003c/a\u003e, attempted to address this lack of visible ‘authority’ by way of a shared visual motif with a new icon for the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Software Center.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:359px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/icons-watered.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/icons-watered.jpg\" width\u003d\"359\" height\u003d\"145\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMiddle Icon\u003c/strong\u003e: Current Software Updater Design for Ubuntu 13.04\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut Ubuntu’s Matthew Paul Thomas doesn’t think that the icon addresses the problem, saying that it ‘\u003cem style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e[has] nothing obviously to do with Ubuntu, and [is] a bit of a non sequitur too.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd so the hunt for is on for a new icon that \u003cem\u003e‘…communicates that these are official updates for Ubuntu’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eContributing Ideas\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIdeas and proposals should be posted to the Ubuntu Art Mailing List (see source link).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t forget to share your thoughts and designs here, too and we’ll highlight some of the best in a post.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"crawlTimeMsec":"1358938053000","timestampUsec":"1358938053000189","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/0d694105c66dc234","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/fresh",
"News","gnome-shell"],"title":"Improved Notifications, Smooth Scrolling Heading to GNOME Shell 3.7","published":1358937982,"updated":1358937982,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/ZhGrbrigXRo/improved-notifications-smooth-scrolling-heading-to-gnome-shell-3-7","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/improved-notifications-smooth-scrolling-heading-to-gnome-shell-3-7"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWith version 3.6 released –and in the Ubuntu in the repositories– GNOME Shell 3.7 paves the way for 3.8, receiving much attention with the ‘Every Detail Matters’ initiative.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the face of it, the shell the one it’s users know and recognize: that familiar black bar with the clock in the middle and the rounded corners. But work on GNOME Shell 3.7 brings many small but notable changes to the rest of shell’s interface and experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/desktop.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"desktop\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/desktop.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally (some would say) support for smooth scrolling is in GNOME Shell –with a “click and fling” behaviour for non-touch devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs one of the main features of the shell, changes have been brought upon the search box to make it more “noticeable”, as well as some visual improvements to the search results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/overview.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"overview\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/overview.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSearch itself is more capable, drawing in –not only local application and file results– but results from online services that you have granted GNOME to access –via GNOME Online Accounts (unrelated to Ubuntu Online Accounts), as well as displaying them more usefully.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/search.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"search\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/search.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eThe\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e message tray \u0026amp; \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003enotifications in this cycle are \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003ereceiving\u003cb\u003e some love; t\u003c/b\u003e\u003cb style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e\u003cb\u003ehe size of the interactive notification bubbles has been increased and chat integration improvements \u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eallow users to open the reply bubble for an incoming chat with \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u0026lt;Super+N\u0026gt;.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs well as being \u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e“pressure-sensitive”\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e–pushing the cursor against the bottom of the desktop reveals it–\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e the tray is now toggle-able with the \u0026lt;Super+M\u0026gt; key combo.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/gs-notifications-bar.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"gs-notifications-bar\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/gs-notifications-bar.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\nAlso new to 3.7, active windows in the overview now get highlighted when the cursor hovers atop them – perhaps a precursor to keyboard navigation in the shell.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/spread-highlight.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"spread-highlight\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/spread-highlight.jpg\" width\u003d\"493\" height\u003d\"368\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cb style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003e\u003cb\u003eInstalling Gnome Shell 3.7+ in Ubuntu\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eGnome shell 3.6 is available in the Ubuntu 12.10 \u0026amp; 13.04 repositories, however to get the latest (unstable) builds –a.k.a the 3.7 series\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003e–\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e you’ll need to add couple repositories to your software sources:\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:gnome3-team/gnome3\u003c/strong\u003e #The GNOME3 team PPA\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px;line-height:18px\"\u003eppa:gnome3-team/gnome3-staging\u003c/strong\u003e #The GNOME3 staging PPA\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen update your software repository information:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get update\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eIf you’re already running Gnome Shell, you can upgrade your packages:\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get upgrade\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eOtherwise it can be freshly installed via the Ubuntu Software Centre:\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/gnome-shell/\" title\u003d\"Install Gnome Shell in Ubuntu\"\u003e Install Gnome Shell via the Ubuntu Software Centre \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cb\u003e\u003cb\u003eOr by command line:\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003esudo apt-get install gnome-shell\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor more information about the current (or further) changes to GNOME Shell, or if you just want to check out the ‘Every Detail Matters’ project, you can hop over their site on the GNOME wiki:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://live.gnome.org/EveryDetailMatters\" title\u003d\"Every Detail "softwareupdater"],"title":"Usability Tweaks Proposed for ‘Software Updater’ App","published":1358891872,"updated":1358891872,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/L9MkefEnjeE/usability-tweaks-proposed-for-software-updater-app","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/usability-tweaks-proposed-for-software-updater-app"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA redesigned version of Ubuntu’s ‘Software Updater’ application is likely to arrive in Ubuntu 13.04 before April.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWriting about the UI tweaks on his blog, developer Michael Terry says that a patch containing the changes has been ‘proposed’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe change itself isn’t drastic but is an improvement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall the design looks cleaner, thanks in part to padding that is consistent with the rest of Ubuntu’s system application.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe redesign also adds headers to explain the purpose of the ‘checkboxes’to the left of listed items, and puts the ‘download’ size in a more obvious place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiple packages specific to a given application are now grouped under the application’s name by default (as can be seen with ‘Backup’ in the images below).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/software-updater.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"software-updater\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/software-updater.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"326\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterestingly the patch proposes removing the name of libraries and system packages from view, instead displaying a description of what they do.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI can see this change being something that a lot of developers aren’t going to be comfortable with, but it is something that will benefit users. When upgrading core system components, knowing what a package\u003cem\u003e is\u003c/em\u003e is more useful than knowing what it’s\u003cem\u003e called.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost desktop applications would retain their name in this new view, as can be seen in the image above with Ubuntu’s ‘\u003cem\u003eBackup’\u003c/em\u003e app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTerry says that he is ‘confident’ that the changes will make it into Ubuntu 13.04 before April.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dL9MkefEnjeE:1pQGyH0mgZI:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg "aerosnap","raring ringtail","unity"],"title":"New Icons, Window Snap Animation Land in Unity","published":1358882015,"updated":1358882015,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/gUViSFct1rY/new-icons-window-snap-animation-land-in-unity","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/new-icons-window-snap-animation-land-in-unity"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/new-window-snap.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"new-window-snap\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/new-window-snap.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"344\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003eA new window snapping effect is one of several changes to have recently arrived in Unity in Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDragging an application window to the left, right or upper-top of the Unity desktop previously invoked an orange ‘highlight’ box transition that denoted the space the window being snapped would fill when released.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut for Ubuntu 13.04 the transition has been tweaked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUpon dragging an app window to the left, right or upper top an expanding box still appears but, and this is the subtle bit, it’s now filled by a ‘ghost’ of the window to be ‘snapped’, as can be see in the image atop this post and in the video at the bottom.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v\u003dc7NBWPzFKYw\"\u003eAn effect similar to this\u003c/a\u003e one was proposed for Ubuntu 11.10 but was never implemented.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what was the problem with the orange box? According to user testing conducted by Canonical users found the the incumbent transitions to be ‘unpredictable’ and the orange expanding box to be ‘confusing’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ghost effect visually ties the application to the snap.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew Icons\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe new effect arrived alongside new icons for the ‘BFB’ (the Ubuntu button at the top of the Unity Launcher):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/bfbf.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"bfbf\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/bfbf.jpg\" width\u003d\"550\" height\u003d\"217\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd re-styled emblems for the default Lenses:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"lens-icons\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/lens-icons.jpg\" width\u003d\"550\" height\u003d\"250\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth of these changes use the same designs that we \u003ca title\u003d\"New Dash Icons Proposed for Ubuntu 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/new-dash-icons-proposed-for-ubuntu-13-04\"\u003ereported on in mid-December\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOther Changes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther changes to have landed over the last month or so include \u003ca title\u003d\"‘Unity Previews’ Animation Updated in Ubuntu 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/unity-previews-look-updated-in-ubuntu-13-04\"\u003erevamped ‘Unity Previews’\u003c/a\u003e; \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu 13.04 Adds New Launcher Options\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-13-04-adds-new-launcher-options\"\u003enew launcher options\u003c/a\u003e; and minor tweaks to the \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu 13.04 Login Screen Gets Minor Tweaks\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-13-04-login-screen-gets-minor-tweaks\"\u003eUnity Greeter.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can track our\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/tag/raring-ringtail\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e Raring Ringtail\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e tag for more information on Ubuntu 13.04 development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChanges in Action\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003csup\u003eA run-down of all of these, and a few extra, changes can be viewed in the following video we lovingly crafted for your viewing pleasure. \u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/Gd8LShbq1SE?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e Ubuntu 13.04 is in active development. Changes featured here are not complete or indicative of the final release, due April 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dgUViSFct1rY:qC7WUslKRiM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/gUViSFct1rY\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
