"china","raring ringtail","ubuntu"],"title":"Baidu Music Search Available for Ubuntu 13.04","published":1358857580,"updated":1358857580,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/cokQYX_gECE/baidu-music-search-available-for-ubuntu-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/baidu-music-search-available-for-ubuntu-13-04"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eC\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style\u003d\"font-size:14px\"\u003ehinese Ubuntu users will soon be able to find music from their favourite national artists straight from the Unity Dash.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSearch support for China’s largest music download site, \u003cem\u003eBaidu Music\u003c/em\u003e, has been been added to Ubuntu 13.04 and is likely to ship as default in the Chinese version of Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:748px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/baidu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"Baidu Music Website\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/baidu.jpg\" width\u003d\"748\" height\u003d\"273\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eBaidu Music Website\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBaidu Music\u003c/em\u003e is the latest, but fully legal, iteration of the infamous music searching service served up by China’s biggest search engine. It succeeds the previously un-licensed ‘pirate search portal’ that trawled the web on behalf of searchers for illegal music downloads.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownloads remain free to download or stream from the site for Chinese users but are now licensed from One-Stop China – the national representative of major international music labels like Universal and Sony.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before any non-China based users get excited: this lens \u003cstrong\u003edoes not work outside of China\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dcokQYX_gECE:riPsdCj-UYE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg Aren’t we all!\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough it will be \u003ci\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone Download, Source Will Arrive ‘February’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-download-will-be-ready-late-february\"\u003eanother month or so\u003c/a\u003e before an image of the real thing is made available, those of us with \u003c/i\u003e\u003cem\u003eAndroid\u003c/em\u003e\u003ci\u003e devices can appease our hunger pangs right this very second thanks to the work of some design-savvy ‘Droid developers.\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eAnd amongst their offerings is this slice of\u003c/i\u003e sugary sumptuousness: the\u003ci\u003e ’\u003c/i\u003e\u003cem\u003eUbuntu Phone Live Wallpaper’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLive Wallpaper, Live Information\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/qQMhg_QFuNA?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the wallpaper is based on Ubuntu Phone’s “Welcome Screen” – \u003cem\u003e‘lock screen’ in real world speak \u003c/em\u003e- the “animated” concept is that of concentric patterns quietly pulsing in and out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn front of that is a larger circle which displays the date and time by default, or can be set to show battery life as a percentage by double-tapping anywhere on the wallpaper.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTablets\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the Google Play listing for the app mentions that it works with tablets the reality is less than ideal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn my 10.1″ ASUS Transformer banding was clearly noticeable, especially during the animation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:748px\"\u003e\u003ca albeit with some banding\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePositives\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBanding issues aside, the application works flawlessly on my Galaxy Nexus. Animation is smooth, and the choice os battery or clock is welcome.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetter yet the wallpaper doesn’t actually ‘work’ in the background but remains ‘frozen’ until you return to the home screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Phone Live Wallpaper is a free download available for handsets running Android 2.2 or higher.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp "Dev","News","rhythmbox","ubuntumusicstore","ubuntuone"],"title":"Ubuntu One Music Store Plugin Dropped from Ubuntu 13.04","published":1358519987,"updated":1358519987,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/jD1c-LdF5vA/ubuntu-one-music-store-plugin-dropped-from-ubuntu-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-one-music-store-plugin-dropped-from-ubuntu-13-04"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu’s default music player won’t ship with the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu One Music Store\u003c/em\u003e plugin in 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the Ubuntu One Music Store \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Launches Online Music Store\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/ubuntu-one-music-store-launches-online\"\u003enow available via the web,\u003c/a\u003e and all Dash music recommendations linking there, the decision has been taken to retire the Rhythmbox plugin ‘\u003ca href\u003d\"http://launchpadlibrarian.net/127944616/rhythmbox-ubuntuone_4.1.2-0ubuntu1_source.changes\"\u003ein favour\u003c/a\u003e‘ of the web store.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut this change will make the store more discoverable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:500px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-one.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"No More Music Store in Ubuntu 13.04\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-one.jpg\" width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"457\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eNo More Music Store in Ubuntu 13.04\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePlugins, Schmugins\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Ubuntu One Music Store plugin debuted in Ubuntu 10.04, and since that time it’s not changed a great deal. It also limited itself to just two media players: Rhythmbox and Banshee.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut now that a link to the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu One Music Store\u003c/em\u003e is pinned on the launcher of Ubuntu 12.10 by default – and is likely to remain in place in 13.04 - \u003cem\u003eevery user\u003c/em\u003e of Ubuntu can see and access it without needing to open (or even use) Rhythmbox.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu One Features Remain\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the store bidding adieu other features of the Ubuntu One Rhythmbox plugin will remain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis includes the “auto-sync” feature that automatically adds purchased tracks to your library.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca professional-grade video editor Lightworks has been widened today – but only for a 2 hour window.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLightworks\u003c/em\u003e saw \u003ca title\u003d\"Video Editor ‘Lightworks’ Linux Release Limited to Select Few\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/video-editor-lightworks-linux-release-limited-to-select-few\"\u003ea limited Linux Alpha release back in October of last year\u003c/a\u003e, much to the \u003ca title\u003d\"Editshare Admit ‘Communication Issues’ Over Lightworks Linux Alpha\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/editshare-admit-communication-issues-over-lightworks-linux-alpha\"\u003edisappointment of many.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDescribing that initial Alpha test period as ‘extremely successful’, Lightworks are moving forward again with a new alpha testing period.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA public beta release of the editor is scheduled for early spring.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSigning Up\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSigning up to the alpha is easy though it does require you to create a \u003cem\u003eLightworks Community account\u003c/em\u003e first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEditshare, the company behind the video editor, do warn that inactive testers will be ‘removed’ – so if you sign up and use it, be sure to contribute!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.lwks.com/alphas-linux\" title\u003d\"lightworks linux alpha application form\"\u003e },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357833185656","timestampUsec":"1357833185656569","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/c6f260a371bc6175","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read",
"How To","dailybuilds","zsync"],"title":"[How To] Update An Ubuntu Daily ISO Using zsync","published":1357832102,"updated":1357832102,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/PCWsTMooga0/how-to-update-an-ubuntu-daily-iso-using-zsync","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/how-to-update-an-ubuntu-daily-iso-using-zsync"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ezsync is a nifty command-line utility that can keep files up-to-date with remote ones.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the most popular uses of zync on Ubuntu is for updating Ubuntu’s daily build image with the latest changes – saving the need to download the entire 800MB .iso again.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow It Works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ezsync allows you to download a file from a remote server, but by comparing with a local file it will only retrieve the newer parts, thereby minimizing the volume of your download.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot only does this save time, but is useful for people with download limits on their internet services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow To:\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you have zsync installed, one only need visit the Ubuntu daily builds \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Daily Builds\" href\u003d\"http://cdimage.ubuntu.com/daily-live/current/\"\u003ewebsite\u003c/a\u003e and copy the .zsync link for the architecture appropriate for your system.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen in a terminal, simply enter “zsync” plus the URL of the zsync link, for example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003ezsync http://cdimage.ubuntu.com/daily-live/current/raring-desktop-amd64.iso.zsync\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s as simple as that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you do not have a copy of the .iso already, don’t worry, zsync will download it automatically \u003cem\u003e(in a rather first-person manner)\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Screenshot-from-2013-01-08-133924.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Screenshot-from-2013-01-08-133924.png\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"388\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003ezsync automatically downloading the file\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall zsync for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ezsync is a free, open-source program and is available to download for Ubuntu via the Software Centre.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/zsync/\" title\u003d\"Download zsync from the Ubuntu Software Centre\"\u003e Download zsync from the Ubuntu Software Centre \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eOr via command line:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre style\u003d\"text-align:left;padding-left:30px\"\u003esudo apt-get -y install zsync\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eOr\u003c/em\u003e: if Ubuntu’s not your flavour, or for some other reason, the zsync can be downloaded via its official website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://zsync.moria.org.uk/downloads\" title\u003d\"Visit Official Site\"\u003e Visit Official Site \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dPCWsTMooga0:TPNsxay6-5Q:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dPCWsTMooga0:TPNsxay6-5Q:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dPCWsTMooga0:TPNsxay6-5Q:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dPCWsTMooga0:TPNsxay6-5Q:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "Gaming","Hardware","News","linux","piston","steam","steambox","xi3"],"title":"Steam-Powered Mini-PC Gets Detailed At CES","published":1357654262,"updated":1357654262,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/9PUwZZGyaio/steam-linux-console-gets-detailed-at-ces","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/steam-linux-console-gets-detailed-at-ces"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt might not be the strongly-rumoured Steambox games console itself, but on the floor of the Consumer Electronics Show 2013 a physical prototype of a Steam-powered mini-PC has been on show.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eValve have teamed up with hardware vendor Xi3 to build a modular, miniature PC, which is currently code-named ‘Piston’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/piston.jpg\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"piston\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/piston.jpg\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"281\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf the team-up Xi3′s founder and CEO Jason Sullivan called it ‘the beginning of a new era’ for his company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“This new development stage product will allow users to take full-advantage of their large high-definition TV displays for an amazing computer game experience.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“As a result, this new system could provide access to thousands of gaming titles through an integrated system that exceeds the capabilities of leading game consoles, but can fit in the palm of your hand.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs diminutive devices go the\u003cem\u003e Piston,\u003c/em\u003e even this early on, has a unique look of its own.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEngadget\u003c/em\u003e and gaming blog \u003cem\u003ePolygon\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.polygon.com/2013/1/7/3849284/piston-valve-steam-box-xi3\"\u003estopped by the Xi3 booth at CES and got chance to toy with the physical part of the console.\u003c/a\u003e But other than some educated guessing on its possible internals  - a quad core chip, low power draw, and 1TB HDD – there’s precious else to be had, especially on the software front.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWill It Run Linux?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo it’s not quite the Steambox, but it is a box capable of running Steam in your living room. But will it run Linux?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRumour has it that the Steambox will run Linux, which isn’t surprising given the investment and time that Valve have put into porting their client and game titles over to platform. A Windows-based console would come with licensing restrictions, overhead and, if it was to use Windows 8, a lock-in to the Windows Store.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven how closely Canonical and Valve have worked together over the last 12 months, and that Canonical have a vested commitment to Ubuntu as a platform, the logical choice would be Ubuntu. Ubuntu can be run free of a GUI (handy for Valve since it will likely use Big Picture Mode as its interface) but would also free Valve and Xi3 from the duties of distribution maintenance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.polygon.com/2013/1/7/3849284/piston-valve-steam-box-xi3\"\u003ePolygon\u003c/a\u003e, via Cesar\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357598890074","timestampUsec":"1357598890074830","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/5f40a20cb4083c95","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read",
"Editorial","photoshop"],"title":"Adobe Are Not Giving Photoshop Away Afterall…","published":1357598808,"updated":1357598808,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/5ystxHWYG2I/adobe-are-not-giving-photoshop-away-afterall","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/adobe-are-not-giving-photoshop-away-afterall"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/reeb.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"reeb\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/reeb.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"250\" height\u003d\"308\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Photoshop CS2 Now Available for Free, Works Fine in WINE\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/photoshop-cs2-available-for-free-works-fine-in-wine\"\u003eEarlier today\u003c/a\u003e we brought word that Adobe’s CS2 suite of apps were, rather suddenly, free to download and install.  It now transpires that we were misinformed.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdobe employee \u003ca href\u003d\"http://forums.adobe.com/people/Dov%20Isaacs\"\u003eDov Isaacs\u003c/a\u003e took to the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://forums.adobe.com/message/4974662#4974662\"\u003eAdobe forum\u003c/a\u003e earlier this evening to say that Adobe are\u003cstrong\u003e ’absolutely not’ giving away free copies of Photoshop CS2\u003c/strong\u003e, Illustrator CS2 or any other part of the Adobe Creative Suite – CS2 or otherwise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich is disappointing, but a better fit for the laws of reality as we know them!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA full statement on the drama is expected by Adobe execs in the coming hours.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWho’s To Blame?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you read about the news, spread the news, and got excited by the news via this site than I am to blame.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before you reach into your bag of rotten fruit, ready to unleash a messy, if healthy, form of vengeance at us I can take solace in the fact that we were not alone in getting caught up in the news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2013/01/grab-photoshop-and-cs2-for-absolutely-free-right-now/\"\u003eGizmodo\u003c/a\u003e, Forbes.com and CNet, along with a host of smaller tech and photography-orientated websites, also pimped news of the freebie to their readers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdmittedly, alarm bells should’ve rung. This is Adobe, after-all. They’re not known for their generosity, \u003ca title\u003d\"Adobe Abandons Flash on Linux\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/02/adobe-adandons-flash-on-linux\"\u003eespecially if it might benefit Linux users\u003c/a\u003e…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSo What Happened?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt seems someone, somewhere got confused by Adobe’s termination of the activation services for various parts of the CS2 suite. With these servers being taken offline those with existing valid serial numbers wouldn’t be able to re-install their paid-for apps on another computer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo prevent this happening Adobe created a new set of CS2 installers for existing customers should they ever need to re-install. These updated apps could be ‘activated’ by using the special serial number provided on the download page.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn short, only those who have already bought CS2, or are somehow in possession of a valid CS2 license number, were legally entitled to download the installers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rest of us were not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo how did a perfectly legitimate set of installers for existing customers end up engulfing the internet under the banner of a ‘free for all’?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChances are we’ll never know.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBut if this incident shows Adobe anything, it’s that their software, even when it’s 7 year old, is still popular.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d5ystxHWYG2I:K7szGjiL9Xw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg "News","ubuntu phone"],"title":"Ubuntu Phone Download, Source Will Arrive ‘February’","published":1357592116,"updated":1357592116,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/Yq9tanuejHk/ubuntu-phone-download-will-be-ready-late-february","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-download-will-be-ready-late-february"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-in-hand1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"ubuntu-phone-in-hand\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-in-hand1.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"500\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn installable image of Ubuntu for the\u003cem\u003e Galaxy\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eNexus\u003c/em\u003e handset, along with its source code, will be released ‘late February’, Canonical’s Alan Pope has said. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Phone OS Unveiled by Canonical\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-os-unveiled-by-canonical\"\u003elast weeks press event unveiling the device\u003c/a\u003e, Mark Shuttleworth had said that an image would be available ‘in the coming weeks’ – so why the delay?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCanonical’s Richard Collins has said that it’s to allow them time to “\u003cem\u003emaximize all the attention we want to gain [with it]\u003c/em\u003e“.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRead: make sure it works better when all eyes are on it.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA specific date in unknown but it’s probable that the release will coincide with Canonical’s appearance at the Mobile World Congress 2013, being held between 25 – 28th of February.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe downloadable image will be for the Samsung \u003ca title\u003d\"Read about the Galaxy Nexus on Wikipedia\" href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_Nexus\"\u003eGalaxy Nexus\u003c/a\u003e - the main device currently used by Canonical for demoing the OS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStill In Development\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor all its glitz and glamour, the Ubuntu Phone image due in February is unlikely to be feature complete – and it’s important that anyone contemplating installing it is aware of this beforehand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring our hands-on with the device we were impressed by its fluidity, touch-gestures, and designed. But there were gaps in its functionality.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, we found out that some key parts of the Ubuntu Phone experience, such as the ‘voice controlled HUD’ and an ‘app store’, don’t even exist yet; and many of those that do, such as the webkit-based web browser, are far from complete.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, reality check aside, the core features of the phone – messaging, calling, camera, etc – were all working during our play with it – and working very, very well, we might add.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357586492166","timestampUsec":"1357586492166843","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/fc9c3f1f0ff5b074","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list",
"How To","adobe","photoshop","wine"],"title":"[How To] Install Photoshop CS2 in WINE","published":1357584811,"updated":1357584811,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/JXIbO_Fe9ro/photoshop-cs2-available-for-free-works-fine-in-wine","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/photoshop-cs2-available-for-free-works-fine-in-wine"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv\u003e \u003cstrong\u003eWhoops!\u003c/strong\u003e Turns out this was an inadvertent hiccup that spread across the internet. See http://goo.gl/iH0zY for further details. \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdobe have apparently made Photoshop, along with several other Creative Suite 2 applications, free to download.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDetails of why the company are offering the applications for free, or how long the gesture will last, are currently unknown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut for now at least, Photoshop CS2 can be downloaded legally for zilch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd the best bit? Photoshop CS2 will even run on Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e“Why Not The GIMP?”\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhotoshop’s ‘Free Alternative’ has been The GIMP.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe GIMP\u003c/em\u003e is a remarkable piece of software. The fact that it is can match features from the heavily-funded Photoshop on a like-for-like basis is a testament to the power of open-source development and organisation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, like it or not, for new users there is an unenviable learning curve involved in using the app at proficient level. A curve that takes some time adjusting to if you were raised , trained or taught using Adobe’s “professional grade” photo manipulation app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd let’s face it: we’re all lazy in one way or another.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo with Photoshop CS2 now free (even if for a limited time) we can indulge our creative sparks without the need to wobbly uncertainly around an unfamiliar interface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhotoshop CS2 may be 7 years old but it’s still a capable tool.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the notable features introduced in CS2 were an improved Spot Healing Brush; new Vanishing Point and Image Warping tools; and better handling of RAW image files.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOther Creative Suite Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s worth my noting that Photoshop is not alone in being offered for free. Mac and Windows users will also find the following apps available for download:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePhotoshop CS2\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIllustrator CS2\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePremier Pro 2.0\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInDesign CS2\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAuditions 3.0\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf these \u003cem\u003eonly\u003c/em\u003e Photoshop CS2 is the only one to be given a \u003ca href\u003d\"http://appdb.winehq.org/objectManager.php?sClass\u003dversion\u0026amp;iId\u003d2631\"\u003eGold rating on the Wine Database\u003c/a\u003e, meaning it ‘…works flawlessly with some special configuration’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Links\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo we know what’s available for free, and why you might want to use it. But how do you get it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe process of getting the download is simple. Click the link below and login with (or sign up for) your Adobe Account.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.adobe.com/cfusion/entitlement/index.cfm?pid\u003d4485850\u0026amp;e\u003dcs2_downloads\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download Photoshop CS2 For Free \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter logging in successfully, you’ll be presented with a long list of downloads in one column, with serial-numbers in the next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/phpotoshop-cs2-downloads.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"phpotoshop-cs2-downloads\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/phpotoshop-cs2-downloads.png\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"134\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBe sure to double-check you’re downloading the correct app – a Mac Installer for\u003cem\u003e InDesign\u003c/em\u003e won’t be of any use on Linux!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInternational readers should be aware that, at the time of writing, only english versions of CS2 applications are being offered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUpdate\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResponse to this offer has been so immense that the portal page offering the download has been knocked offline (for now, at least). Thankfully one enterprising chap managed to snag the links from the portal before it went down, and has put the direct download links and the accompanying serial numbers \u003ca href\u003d\"http://noelchenier.blogspot.ca/2013/01/download-adobe-cs2-for-free.html\"\u003eon his blog.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/adobe-are-not-giving-photoshop-away-afterall\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download Link Removed \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eThe serial number proffered with this download is: 1045-1412-5685-1654-6343-1431\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003e[How To] Photoshop CS2 in Linux\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFirst Step\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhotoshop CS2 is one of the few versions of Photoshop that will work on Linux using the WINE compatibility layer – though getting it up and running isn’t quite as straightforward as opening the .exe installer in WINE.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst things first: make sure you have WINE installed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"javascript:void(0);\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Click to Install WINE \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstalling WINE from the Ubuntu repositories will also install the ‘Winetricks’ script needed in the next part.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpen Winetricks \u003cem\u003e(Open the Unity Dash \u0026gt; Search ‘winetricks’)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/windwotric.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"winetricks in Ubuntu\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/windwotric.png\" alt\u003d\"winetricks in Ubuntu\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"234\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the window that appears select \u003cem\u003e‘Select a wineprefix’\u003c/em\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/wine.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"wine\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/wine.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"290\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFollowed by ‘\u003cem\u003eInstall a Windows DLL or Component’\u003c/em\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/windows.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"windows\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/windows.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"184\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the next window scroll through and check (click the box next to) the following apps:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003egecko\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003evcrun6\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext, click ‘Ok’. Several installer prompts will appear (possibly in German!) click through to install these.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen all those parts have completed installation open ‘winetricks’ again but choose the \u003cem\u003e‘Install a Font’\u003c/em\u003e open after ‘\u003cem\u003eSelect a wineprefix\u003c/em\u003e‘.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"fonts\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/fonts.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"512\" height\u003d\"216\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the font selection screen check and install ‘\u003cem\u003ecorefonts’\u003c/em\u003e. Press OK to continue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou will need to agree/click through a few bits and bobs to install the package – but Photoshop won’t run without it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e To save time run the command \u003cem\u003e‘winetricks gecko corefonts vcrun6′\u003c/em\u003e from the command line. \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSecond Step\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith all of the kerfuffle out of the way we can proceed to install \u003cem\u003ePhotoshop CS2 \u003c/em\u003eitself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRight click on the photoshop.exe file you downloaded earlier and select \u003cem\u003e‘Open with \u0026gt; WINE Windows Program Loader’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003eFollow the on-screen prompts as they appear, not forgetting to input your serial-number (present on the download screen) when asked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen all has completed you can launch Photoshop CS2 via the Unity Dash.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThanks to Paul Fawcett\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJXIbO_Fe9ro:sN4vMjfOkYM:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dJXIbO_Fe9ro:sN4vMjfOkYM:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca Daily.","continuation":"CJzVoo21_rMC","self":[{"href":"http://www.google.com/reader/api/0/stream/contents/feed/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2Ffeed?r\u003dn\u0026c\u003dCNXA8dao1rQC\u0026n\u003d40\u0026ck\u003d1361446148796\u0026client\u003dscroll"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk","type":"text/html"
}],"updated":1357564182,"items":[{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357564182552","timestampUsec":"1357564182552661","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/698b6ac9e2199fd0","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list","Dev","News","lightdm","raring ringtail"],"title":"Ubuntu 13.04 Login Screen Gets Minor Tweaks","published":1357564159,"updated":1357564159,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-13-04-login-screen-gets-minor-tweaks"
}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/G0tDBm3ydJY/ubuntu-13-04-login-screen-gets-minor-tweaks","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSupport for timed login is amongst recent minor changes made to Ubuntu 13.04′s login screen.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTimed login is popular with users wishing to automatically set a given user session to login \u003cem\u003ebut\u003c/em\u003e also allow for enough time to choose a different account.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve never thought you needed it then its arrival won’t be of consequence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far there is no \u003cem\u003euser-visible\u003c/em\u003e option by which to configure the feature, though it can be manually through a LightDM configuration file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut with support for it explicitly mentioned in the latest LightDM update to Ubuntu 13.04 daily, one of the various third-party Unity tweaking tools, such as \u003cem\u003eUnsettings\u003c/em\u003e or \u003cem\u003eMyUnity\u003c/em\u003e, could well choose to support it in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOther Changes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAppeasement of the patient isn’t the only change arriving in this update.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘OK button has been removed from the\u003cem\u003e Session Chooser\u003c/em\u003e screen. Clicking on a session now automatically selects it and returns you to the login prompt.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:462px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/session-chooser.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"session-chooser\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/session-chooser.jpg\" width\u003d\"462\" height\u003d\"308\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eUbuntu 13.04 Session Chooser – Not ‘OK’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe focus/hover state of the session chooser icon (the Ubuntu logo by default) has been removed. It’s entirely possibly that this is a temporary decision as, when you think about it, how will keyboard users or those with accessibility needs know they’ve selected it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the padding and spacing of the back button and session chooser have been tweaked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThese are not massive changes, nor are they the only changes we will see before April, but big houses are built from small bricks. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e Ubuntu 13.04 is in active development. Changes featured here are not complete or indicative of the final release, due April 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dG0tDBm3ydJY:SqzDs0E_uIs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/G0tDBm3ydJY\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357505481346","timestampUsec":"1357505481346243","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/212139ee0dede530","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list",
"Interview","mechanig","unity"],"title":"Interview With Devs Behind New Ubuntu Tweak Tool ‘Mechanig’","published":1357505461,"updated":1357505461,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/we-interview-the-mechanig-development-team"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/UMBrm3b2qrI/we-interview-the-mechanig-development-team","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003cimg alt\u003d\"mechanig for Ubuntu\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mechanig.png\" width\u003d\"750\"\u003e\u003cp\u003eMechanig\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you’re an Ubuntu User that enjoys pushing their desktop customization to the limits, then you may have  heard of new desktop configuration tool by the name of ‘\u003cem\u003eMechanig’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough desktop-tweaking tools aren’t scarce, Mechanig aims to equip users with a fast, easy-to-use tool.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI recently had the opportunity to interview the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~freyja-dev\"\u003eFreyja Development Team\u003c/a\u003e which consists of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/106827958460661610404\"\u003eBarneedhar Vigneshwar\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://phanimahesh.wordpress.com/\"\u003eJ Phani Mahesh\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/114006041993005248291\"\u003eAmith KK\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/100530892038948253747\"\u003eGeorgi Karavasilev\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/111008502832304483939\"\u003eSam Tran\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/116597364982833470829/posts\"\u003eSam Hewitt\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/109850922864204625308/posts\"\u003eÁngel Araya\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWho came up with the idea for Mechanig? What inspired you?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe idea to kickstart the project was Barneedhar’s. After the announcement of Ubuntu Tweak’s end of development, he approached us with the message, “Let’s fork Ubuntu Tweak”. The few omnibus Unity configuration tools that exist are daunting and still difficult to use. Some were missing important settings – like hot-corners configuration – and others felt out of place in the very environment they were tweaking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe wanted something immensely useful for both technical and non-technical users who were looking for a one-stop configuration tool that was light on dependencies and simple to use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e Does your team have some form of leadership and how does development work? Are tasks delegated?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBarneedhar is the project leader, though the team is small enough and specialized enough to fall into natural design and development roles. All the development work happens in a single git repository with commits that have spanned every hour of the day. Real-time collaboration happens in IRC, but we stay in contact across three continents and multiple time zones through several social networks as well. Most of us have enough experience with Python or Gtk to work on small issues as they crop up on IRC; but we all know our limitations and who to go to when we hit odd issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eI see Mechanig is currently available as a PPA but do you have any plans for it to be offered in the Ubuntu Software Center?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact we have spoken with Ubuntu MOTU about releasing the application in the Ubuntu Software Centre, so once we have a stable release we plan on submitting the application to the USC. We’ll continue offering unstable builds through the daily PPA for users who are willing to help us with testing and bug reporting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e Have you guys considered proposing implementation of your features into mainstream system settings for Ubuntu or do you enjoy the current relationship of Mechanig being a third party tool?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere’s a significant process for applications looking to go upstream. We can’t just submit the app in its current state and, bosh, it lands in the next Ubuntu release.  It needs design (and sometimes even community) approval and needs to be well-integrated in Ubuntu. In Mechanig’s case this involves changing it from a standalone application to panes in System Settings and additional work to match the design specifications. At the end of this process, Mechanig will no longer be a tweaking tool, but a set of options in System Settings. Maybe once we have a stable release, we’ll approach the Ubuntu design team and talk with them. Until then it will still be a third party tool.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhy did you guys select Python 3 as the language you wrote Mechanig in?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVarious members have Java, C, C#, C++, and Perl experience, but almost the entire team has previous Python experience of one sort or another. Moreover, the ubiquity of the language and the profusion of Python applications on Ubuntu have created an attractive development environment and a helpful community of Python developers within the greater Ubuntu community. Also, Ubuntu would be switching to Python 3 completely soon enough.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat are your plans for Mechanig in the first part of 2013?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe are planning on releasing a stable version by the end of January and from there it’s all about polishing the user interface making it rock on 13.04.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHaving said that, additional manpower always comes in handy.  If anyone wants to contribute, they can join the #mechanig IRC channel on Freenode and talk to us there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also have \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/jokerdino/mechanig\"\u003eGitHub\u003c/a\u003e and\u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/mechanig\"\u003e Launchpad project\u003c/a\u003e pages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat encourages you guys to develop applications for Ubuntu versus other Linux Distributions? Have you received any help or encouragement from the Ubuntu Community Team?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe all use Ubuntu as our primary operating system, so it was only natural for us to develop a tool tailored to our particular needs on Ubuntu with Unity. Were Unity to gain significant traction on other distributions, the tool would probably be just as useful for those users as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/109919666334513536939/posts\"\u003eMichael Hall\u003c/a\u003e from the Ubuntu Community Team has shown interest in the project, which hopefully bodes well for the future integration of Mechanig into mainline Ubuntu. In general, the Ubuntu community has been quite encouraging as well. We’ve recorded numerous videos of Mechanig in action and the feedback has been overwhelmingly positive so far.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs far as further application development goes, we’re not just stopping with Mechanig; the team has a several projects planned for the future, among which are: a system-wide equalizer, a notification centre \u0026amp; a music player.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThanks again to the Freyja Team for taking time to do this interview with OMG! Ubuntu and also the Team is currently looking to re-name Mechanig and seeks the OMG! Ubuntu Community’s help in picking a name the options they are mulling are below:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://polldaddy.com/poll/6812470\"\u003eTake Our Poll\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dUMBrm3b2qrI:x-QWTkMo4mc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/UMBrm3b2qrI\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Benjamin Kerensa","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357320831147","timestampUsec":"1357320831147198","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/184252001c1cb3c7","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","user/00694065464150071004/label/Linux","user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/reading-list",
"Ubuntu Phone","ubuntu phone"],"title":"CNN Predict Ubuntu Phone ‘Won’t Make Inroads’","published":1357320427,"updated":1357320427,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/cnn-predict-ubuntu-phone-wont-make-inroads"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/CG6S1j3Rxac/cnn-predict-ubuntu-phone-wont-make-inroads","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Ubuntu Phone will fail to make ‘the tiniest of inroads’ against the mobile market dominant players, \u003ca href\u003d\"http://money.cnn.com/2013/01/02/technology/mobile/ubuntu-smartphone-linux/\"\u003eaccording to CNN Money’s Adrian Covert\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a post titled ‘”\u003cem\u003eThe Ubuntu smartphone (which no one will use) is a glimpse of the future\u003c/em\u003e“, Covert argues that the failure of Motorola’s ‘dockable’ Atrix device, and the tepid reception to Microsoft’s Windows 8 are indications that a fully convergent single ‘OS’ across devices isn’t something consumers have an appetite for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt least, not yet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mark-mit-phone.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"mark-mit-phone\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/mark-mit-phone.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"500\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eUbuntu Founder Mark Shuttleworth With the Ubuntu Phone\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, Covert doesn’t claim to be a psychic, but he is a journalist with years of experience in this sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut are his pessimistic assumptions accurate? Or has he missed the real lure of the Ubuntu Phone idea?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Duopoly’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s the nature of tech journalism that, at a mere 2 days post reveal, the fate of the Ubuntu Phone has already been called.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s an easy assumption to make, largely because the smartphone market is in the stranglehold of what Covert refers to as a ‘duopoly’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eiOS rules the high-end (not a critical judgement of mine, simply there isn’t a mid-range iPhone). Android, meanwhile, commands both a slice of high-end, and most of the mid-ranged market. Low-end Android devices are becoming more plentiful, but few (if any) get good reviews.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith a good year set to pass before an Ubuntu Phone goes on sale in a store, ready for us to exchange cash for, Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android will inevitably further cement their stranglehold on these respect smartphone segments during this time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it’s here where commentators like Covert are missing the point.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee, Ubuntu Phones aren’t really going to claw much market share away from Apple or Google. And this neat ‘dock your phone and use it as a desktop’ feature, whilst innovative, won’t be the main lure for many.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact chances are it won’t even feature on the majority of Ubuntu Phones…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Starter Smartphones’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003ePhrases like \u003cem\u003e‘starter smartphone’\u003c/em\u003e were used to describe it…\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring his keynote address earlier this week, Mark Shuttleworth continually referred to ‘emerging’ markets as the battleground on which an Ubuntu Phone would fight it out for impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePhrases like \u003cem\u003e‘starter smartphone’\u003c/em\u003e and\u003cem\u003e ‘feature-phone upgraders’\u003c/em\u003e were used to describe the device and its audience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s this sector, the low-end, that the battle for the hearts, minds and hands of the less tech-savvy will take place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign and engineering emphasis placed on providing a ‘crisper, sharper’ user experience on ‘low-end’ hardware than that currently offered. Focus is as every bit on the “phone” fuction as it is on the “smart”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo bolting on of traditional phone features as an afterthought to shiner, more fancy features. And these fancy features include the ‘desktop’ docking mode.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s this attention that I find the \u003cem\u003ereal key differentiator\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ex.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"ex\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ex.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"500\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eBalanced: The Ubuntu Phone is as much of a ‘phone’ as it is a ‘smartphone’\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRivals Yet to Arrive\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut Ubuntu is not alone in looking to conquer it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLater this year Mozilla will launch the first Firefox OS phones in Latin America. As will Jolla (made from the carcass of MeeGo). As will the Linux-based Tizen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShort of Android forking itself to run fantastically on low-powered phones (unlikely: carriers/OEMS make money from super-fast handsets capable of running the current-gen OS); and short of a mid-range iPhone appearing, Ubuntu is well placed against its expectant rivals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCovert summarises that:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e“At best, Ubuntu seems like a sandbox for the most enthusiastic early adopters and a cheap enterprise solution for companies on a tight budget.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow likely that proves to be true will depend on what Ubuntu’s rivals can bring to the table – and how soon they can bring it. It’s all to play for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTime, not the dominance of Android, will be the ultimate decider in this war.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dCG6S1j3Rxac:yo7ZHBh8c74:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/CG6S1j3Rxac\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357310720672","timestampUsec":"1357310720672774","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/78436830634ed722","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","Download","News","spotify"],"title":"Spotify Update Brings Linux Users New Features First",
"published":1357310637,"updated":1357310637,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/spotify-update-brings-linux-users-new-features-first"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/-mAJ7ukN92U/spotify-update-brings-linux-users-new-features-first","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpotify are giving Linux users a taste of new features first with their latest \u003cem\u003eSpotify for Linux Preview\u003c/em\u003e release.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before you get too excited these features aren’t anything particularly game-changing – that is unless you’re an avid Spotify user…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"spotify-main\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/spotify-main.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSpotify Goes Social\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpotify is the biggest music streaming site in the world. It boasts over 20 million users, 5 million of whom subscribe to one of the service’s paid plans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd it’s not just big in userbase. The company say that some 10,000 new tracks are being added to its online library each and every day, expanding on the 15 million tracks already available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat’s a lot of users. And a lot of music.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor Spotify the challenge is in getting users to know of and discover ‘new’ content.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo do this the service is rolling out a new Twitter-like\u003cem\u003e ‘Follow’\u003c/em\u003e feature that lets you keep tabs on their favourite bands, companies, magazines, and other so-called ‘influencers’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/follow.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"follow\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/follow.jpg\" alt\u003d\"An artist page on Spotify with the new \u0026#39;Follow\u0026#39; feature\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eAn artist page on Spotify with the new ‘Follow’ feature\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen someone you follow adds a new track, album or playlists to share you’ll be notified of it; no searching, no fuss.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it’s not just limited to those with music to share. You will also be able to follow other Spotify users and see their most recently listened to music in the ‘people’ side-bar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSounds similar to the ‘Facebook integration’ already baked into the app, doesn’t it? Coupled with the fact that you no longer need Facebook to sign up for the service, it this is the first step towards a ‘music-orientated social network’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDiscover\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSocial features aside, one other new feature is soon to be added: ‘Discover’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s not present in the app at the time of writing, so don’t know exactly what it will do, but from a recent press event held by Spotify we’re told that it will recommend new artists and tracks similar to that you’ve already listened to.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese features have only been available to a limited number of Windows and Mac users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu Software Center Bound\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSocial features aside, this release also sees an interesting change to the way the application is packaged.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpotify now installs to and runs from the ‘\u003cem\u003e/opt\u003c/em\u003e‘ directory. And?  This location is a requirement for apps wishing to be distributed through the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis seems to back up something I heard a few weeks back. Namely, that the Spotify client will be added to the Ubuntu Software Center later this month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow To Install Spotify in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpotify can be installed via a repository (the recommended way) or by download a .Deb installer from the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://repository.spotify.com/pool/non-free/s/spotify/\"\u003erepository web-page.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install from the repository – and thus automatically receive new updates to the app without having to re-install – follow the guide linked to below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/how-to-install-spotify-in-ubuntu-12-04-12-10\" title\u003d\"Install Spotify in Ubuntu\"\u003e How to Install Spotify in Ubuntu 12.04 \u0026amp; 12.10 \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d-mAJ7ukN92U:JFjwXPWLbyI:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/-mAJ7ukN92U\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357310632175","timestampUsec":"1357310632175981","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/052178e598da0aa1","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","How To","spotify"],"title":"[How To] Install Spotify in Ubuntu 12.04 \u0026amp; 12.10",
"published":1357310614,"updated":1357310614,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/how-to-install-spotify-in-ubuntu-12-04-12-10"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/bDi2xmCTjsc/how-to-install-spotify-in-ubuntu-12-04-12-10","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpotify is the king of music streaming. Every day tens of millions of users listen to thousands of tracks using it through a variety of different ways.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are mobile apps for Android, iOS, Windows Phone and Blackberry;\u003ca title\u003d\"[How To] Test Spotify’s New Web Player\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player\"\u003e a beta web-based player\u003c/a\u003e for browser-bound users; and dedicated desktop apps for Windows, Mac and Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s the last one of these that this guide will show you how to install.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow to Install Spotify Via Repository\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpen \u003cem\u003eSoftware Sources\u003c/em\u003e via the Unity Dash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/sofw.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"sofw\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/sofw.jpg\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"237\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSelect the ‘\u003cem\u003eOther Software’\u003c/em\u003e tab in \u003cem\u003eSoftware Sources [1]\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"this\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/this.jpg\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eClick\u003cem\u003e ‘Add’ [2] \u003c/em\u003eand p\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003easte the following the entry field of the box that appears:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e\u003cem\u003edeb http://repository.spotify.com stable non-free\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClick ‘\u003cem\u003eAdd Source’\u003c/em\u003e to confirm the change, then\u003cem\u003e c\u003c/em\u003elose \u003cem\u003eSoftware Sources.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAdd Spotify Repo Key\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe next step is to add the repository key to verify that packages installed from this PPA are by whom they say.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpen a new \u003cem\u003eTerminal\u003c/em\u003e window\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePaste the following, then hit return/enter:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-key adv --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys 94558F59\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/terminal.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"terminal\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/terminal.jpg\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"87\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat’s that! You can now install Spotify through the Ubuntu Software Center (after checking for software updates first) or by running the following command in the \u003cem\u003eTerminal\u003c/em\u003e window:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install spotify-client\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce installed you can launch Spotify from the Unity Dash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbDi2xmCTjsc:gnDsWsOA7mU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/bDi2xmCTjsc\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1357150735640","timestampUsec":"1357150735640607","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/c27794288b384a9c","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Exclusive","Hardware","News","mobile","multidevice","ubuntu phone"],"title":"Ubuntu Phone OS Unveiled by Canonical",
"published":1357149582,"updated":1357149582,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-os-unveiled-by-canonical"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/liucqqO2zkk/ubuntu-phone-os-unveiled-by-canonical","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn Ubuntu-powered phone has been unveiled by Mark Shuttleworth in London, today.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCalling the product launch a “significant next step in our history”, Shuttleworth demoed the device and spoke of Canonical’s plans for taking the device to an already saturated mobile market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd the interface of the OS is, possibly more than the brand-name behind it, going to drive adoption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:750px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"ubuntu-phone\" alt\u003d\"The Ubuntu Phone\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone1.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"412\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Ubuntu Phone\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDelivering a personalised full screen-to-screen experience  - with a ‘welcome screen, not a lock screen’ – the Ubuntu Phone proffers ‘more screen space for your apps than any other mobile OS’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“We also invited a way to use an app without having to use buttons at all via a voice-controlled ‘HUD’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAvailability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo when can you get one? Sadly not just yet. Although talks are taking place no major vendor has yet signed up to ship the device.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut there is hope.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCanonical are ‘confident’ a major manufacturer will ship Ubuntu for Android this year; that will be the first step. But the first pure Ubuntu  Phone devices will appear towards the end of the year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe device will be shown off later this month at the CES event.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-in-hand.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"ubuntu-phone-in-hand\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/ubuntu-phone-in-hand.jpg\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eThe Ubuntu Phone in Our Hand – a new OS, on an old Nexus\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLow-end Phones\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike Android, Ubuntu Phone OS has been designed from the ground up to deliver a \u003cem\u003e‘crisper, sharper’\u003c/em\u003e experience on low-powered devices – a market segment Shuttleworth sees as being key to adoption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese ‘starter smartphone’ users will, he says benefit from a leaner, ‘less complex’ user experience than rivals. Something he says emerging markets are calling out for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e …you will be able to download and install the Ubuntu Phone OS on certain device handsets \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Canonical’s ‘primary market’ will be selling Ubuntu Phones via retail, and making a cut from such sales, you will be able to download and install the phone OS on certain device handsets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far the ‘reference’ device appears to be the previous generation of Google’s Nexus handset. While it’s entirely likely that images for other devices will appear along the line, Shuttleworth told us that retro-fitting phones is not their ‘priority’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIt’s all about the OEM/Carrier deals. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSpecifications\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what sort of guts does it take to run the phone OS? Or, to put it another way, how ‘lean’ is ‘lean’?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is where things get interesting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA “low end” Ubuntu Phone will require, at a minimum:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDual-core A9 ARM Processor\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e1GB of RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4GB Flash Storage + SD\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e800×400 WVGA Screen\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMulti-touch\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo run the phone with ‘convergence’ enabled (a fancy way of saying ‘you can dock it and it will run a full desktop) the requirements are a bit higher:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eQuad-core A9 ARM Processor\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e1GB of RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e32GB Flash + SD\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMinimum of 720p screen resolution\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMulti-touch\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeveloping for the Ubuntu Phone\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA mobile development suite for Ubuntu Phone will be available later this week. This will allow developers without access to an Ubuntu Phone to run an ‘emulated’ version, and begin building and testing their apps for it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen targeting the ‘Super Phone’ version of Ubuntu Phone OS things get a bit more interesting. Developers will be able to create one app with two interfaces: a smartphone UI, and, when the phone is docked to run as a desktop, a fuller, less touch-centric desktop UI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeature Creep\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerhaps the most exciting part of the entire announcement is that many of the innovations shown off as part of the phone UI will be making an appearance in the forthcoming releases of Ubuntu – including changes to the dash, the voice-controlled HUD, and a new ‘snap decisions’ framework.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot all of these changes will appear in Ubuntu 13.04 but some will.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dliucqqO2zkk:-Zo9aZFtaa4:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg
