},"author":"Benjamin Kerensa","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356968772956","timestampUsec":"1356968772956112","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4332918c2e559eda","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Event","Hardware","News","canonical"],"title":"All-New Ubuntu Product to Launch Jan 2nd – But What Is It?",
"published":1356967092,"updated":1356967092,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/all-new-ubuntu-product-to-launch-jan-2nd-but-what-is-it"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/wn2G1oxUZEs/all-new-ubuntu-product-to-launch-jan-2nd-but-what-is-it","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"new-buntu\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/new-buntu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"146\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new Ubuntu product will be unveiled by Canonical on Wednesday, January 2nd.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDetails are scant on the ground at present at present. So far the only known ‘fact’ is that which is written on the press release: it’s an event to ‘launch an all new Ubuntu product’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news for\u003cem\u003e you\u003c/em\u003e is that you won’t have to scratch around the Internet to find out because we will be at the media event on Wednesday, armed to the teeth with fully-charged microphones, DSLRs paired with \u003cem\u003eclass-AWESOME\u003c/em\u003e SDHC cards and 3G-networked, bullet-proof armoured Chromebooks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, they’re not bullet-proof, but they do have 8 hour batteries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo keep your eye on this blog around 5-6pm GMT, or better yet, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/omg-ubuntu/nhmmlbjenhdockdgpklmdiamollflljn\"\u003etry our new Chrome extension.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eWhat Could It Be?\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat will this ‘launch product’ be? Well, it’s probably easier to guess what it \u003cem\u003ewon’t\u003c/em\u003e be.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor one, I think it’s safe to say that it won’t be an Ubuntu TV. Why not? Because the interface is still being ported over to Compiz, and the ’2D’ QML version hasn’t seen much activity for months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu Phone\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Unity Phone mock-up by eldron2323.deviantart.com/\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/phone_mockup_1_by_eldron2323-d4ie47k-150x150.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Unity Phone mock-up by eldron2323.deviantart.com/\" width\u003d\"150\" height\u003d\"150\"\u003ePerhaps the rank outsider of these three musings, but it shouldn’t be ruled out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, Mark Shuttleworth himself has said that \u003cem\u003e‘Unity in 2013 will be all about mobile – bringing Ubuntu to phones and tablets.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCould a \u003cem\u003ededicated\u003c/em\u003e Ubuntu-powered Unity-using smartphone be part of this?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu for Android Phone\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs exciting as the idea of an Ubuntu smartphone is we’re more likely to Ubuntu for Android arrive first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA hybrid of mobile – Android – and desktop – Ubuntu – computing contained within the once device, \u003ca title\u003d\"Meet Ubuntu for Android: The Next Step in Ubuntu’s Multi-Device Plan\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/02/ubuntu-for-android-announced\"\u003eUbuntu for Android was announced in early January of 2012\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘technology’ exists and works, as the countless desire-stoking demos at technology expos throughout the year has proved.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd with a \u003ca title\u003d\"New Animated ‘Ubuntu For Android’ Ad Hits the Web\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/canonical-release-new-ubuntu-for-android-commercial\"\u003enew Ubuntu for Android advert debuting just before Xmas\u003c/a\u003e, could an anniversary announcement be on the way?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu For Tablet\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Ubuntu \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Nexus 7 Installer App Released to Devs\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/ubuntu-installer-for-nexus-7-tablet-made-available-for-devs\"\u003ecan already run on the Google Nexus 7 tablet\u003c/a\u003e (\u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu 12.04 Firmware Released for SmartQ T20 Tablet\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/06/ubuntu-12-04-firmware-released-for-smartq-t20-tablet\"\u003eamongst many others\u003c/a\u003e) the interface isn’t suited to it. \u003cem\u003eAt all.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, despite the critics insistence that Unity is a touch OS, Ubuntu is actually a bit of a fail-bomb when used with a touchscreen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut this is going to change. A version of Unity suited to touchscreens in on the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCould it be ahead of schedule? \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWildcard: Ubuntu Games Console\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor my last guess I’m pushing to boat out. Pushing it out so far that it smacks into the shore of improbability.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut hear me out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eValve are rumoured to be working on a Linux-based Steam games console.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd, throughout the Steam for Linux beta, Canonical and Valve have been working ever-so well together – from engineering through to marketing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo could an Valve have opted to use Ubuntu as their base for a Steam console? It would certainly mean they didn’t have to fork and maintain an entire distribution themselves. And Canonical, as a business built around Ubuntu, are in it for the long haul…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat do you think the ‘product launch’ will entail? Let us know in the comment void below, or via Twitter \u003ca href\u003d\"http://twitter.com/omgubuntu\"\u003e@omgubuntu.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwn2G1oxUZEs:aMz-_IrxhvE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/wn2G1oxUZEs\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356801182978","timestampUsec":"1356801182978545","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/be8817e88b9227cf","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","How To","aldi","photo software"],"title":"[How To] Install Aldi Photo Software",
"published":1356797530,"updated":1356797530,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/how-to-install-aldi-photo-software"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/thgxpgkIj2s/how-to-install-aldi-photo-software","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003eDiscount supermarket chain Aldi offer a photo gift customization service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut they also cater to Linux users, with software download ready to install in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow to Install Aldi Photo App in Linux\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownload the software from the link below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/\" title\u003d\"download aldi photo software for linux\"\u003e Download Aldi’s Photo Gift Software \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eExtract\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eEnter folder and double click on the ‘install.pl’ file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eChoose ‘Run in Terminal’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eYou’ll see a long EULA. Scroll to the bottom of this and hit ‘q’ when done.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eAccept the EULA by typing ‘yes’ and hitting ‘return’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eAgree to the next few things.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eAfter install you’ll find an Aldi Print Software shortcut on your desktop. Double-clicking on this will open the app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eChris Hutchins \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dthgxpgkIj2s:0ZK5Jz8YFHA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/thgxpgkIj2s\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356799733886","timestampUsec":"1356799733886266","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/aae9a9929d9c92e2","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","News","ubuntuone"],"title":"Ubuntu One Adds Photo Sharing Features","published":1356799709,
"updated":1356799709,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/ubuntu-one-adds-photo-sharing-features"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/yoE234A2C7g/ubuntu-one-adds-photo-sharing-features","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA ‘\u003cem\u003ePhotos\u003c/em\u003e‘ feature was added to the Ubuntu One Web Dashboard earlier this month – but what does it offer?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a sky of closely matched competitors, the Ubuntu One cloud storage service has needed to differentiate itself from the competition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far it’s done this through offerings like its MP3 music store and sibling music streaming service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, in a move that will compliment the ‘auto-photo upload’ features found in its mobile apps, the web dashboard has added a new ‘Photos’ section.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"images\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/images.jpg\" width\u003d\"750\" height\u003d\"441\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePhotos in Ubuntu One Web\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn short the feature is simple: it lets you easily browse and views photos you have stored in your Ubuntu One account from the web interface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it adds a few extra features to the mix.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first is a simple slideshow feature. When you open a photo up for larger viewing you can hit ‘Space’ for it to auto-play through your collection.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/slideshow.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"slideshow\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/slideshow.jpg\" width\u003d\"563\" height\u003d\"294\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA nice touch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll also find a number of new options available when viewing photos. These include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLinks for sharing an image to Twitter and Facebook\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eQuick link button for sharing via e-mail or IM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePhoto sorting options\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/iptions.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"iptions\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/iptions.jpg\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFlaws\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s not perfect. The feature insists on hiding albums that it ‘doesn’t believe are relevant’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"hideden\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/hideden.jpg\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn theory it’s a smart feature. No-one wants to see their holiday snaps mixed with 150 weather forcast .pngs accidentally uploaded from Android.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in practice…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/overview.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"overview\" alt\u003d\"\" src\u003d\"http://omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/overview.jpg\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTry it Out\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t just sit here gawping at it – go try it now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll need an Ubuntu One account (free to sign up, don’t forget) with some images pre-uploaded. Then login, and hit the ‘Photos’ tab in the navigation bar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://one.ubuntu.com\" title\u003d\"ubuntu one photos\"\u003e Ubuntu One Web Dashboard \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dyoE234A2C7g:LzhCrITdFgs:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/yoE234A2C7g\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356697392778","timestampUsec":"1356697392778729","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/b0d04338c2b7798a","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Hardware","Video","system76"],"title":"System 76 Sable Complete PC Unboxing [Video]",
"published":1356697364,"updated":1356697364,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/system-76-sable-complete-pc-unboxing-video"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/0S4KobpOISo/system-76-sable-complete-pc-unboxing-video","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSince its launch \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/meet-the-799-all-in-one-ubuntu-pc-from-system76\"\u003eback in October\u003c/a\u003e, the System76 Sable Complete PC has been on the wishlist of a great many people – myself included.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust before xmas I was fortunate enough to get a hands-on with the sleek-looking all-in-one, and a full review n’ rundown of my thoughts on it will be coming up shortly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in the mean time – and not as a cynical test to check that our database is firing on all cylinders again – here is a video of myself unboxing the beauty…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"788\" height\u003d\"443\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/PFxGYiUHAOk?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d0S4KobpOISo:c3-zNKnngas:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/0S4KobpOISo\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356690905204","timestampUsec":"1356690905204941","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/d64845c4f2d9ea96","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Dev","How To","Pro User","chrome","chromium","google"],"title":"[How To] Install Daily builds of Chrome in Ubuntu",
"published":1356689912,"updated":1356689912,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/how-to-install-daily-builds-of-chrome-in-ubuntu"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/IkDar48VmZ8/how-to-install-daily-builds-of-chrome-in-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAccessing\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e daily builds of Google’s Chrome browser in Ubuntu is a bit of a fuss compared to that on Windows and Mac.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsers of those platforms can install the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.google.com/intl/en/chrome/browser/canary.html\"\u003eChrome Canary builds\u003c/a\u003e – a sort of pseudo-daily build that offers the latest bleeding edge features, but running insulated from any other version of Chrome installed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Ubuntu things are less clear cut.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile you could install a Beta or Dev build in Linux, that would replace your existing Chrome installation and bothering to extract the files from the .deb file is simply too much effort.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut now, however, I’ve found a directory of daily Chromium for Linux builds that offers bleeding edge goodness. And all from reporting a bug on Google Code…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIts important to note that these builds are not full Chrome builds: they’re merely Chromium, an open source project on which Chrome is based which misses out some proprietary stuff like Flash. However, in most cases it’ll do just fine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:600px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/omgchrome.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/omgchrome.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"600\" height\u003d\"421\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eTypical Chromium daily build – visually it’s much the same, but under the bonnet…\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Chromium Daily\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003e.zip\u003c/em\u003e, fresh from Google’s servers, can be simply extracted to reveal an already-build version of Chromium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is the \u003cem\u003eabsolute\u003c/em\u003e bleeding edge of Chromium development, and is quite prone to crashes and data loss, so for this reason we’re also going to \u003cstrong\u003eisolate it’s configuration files\u003c/strong\u003e in a different directory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e This guide is not recommended for beginners or those working on production machines. \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo start off, download \u003ca title\u003d\"Chromium daily builds download\" href\u003d\"http://download-chromium.appspot.com/\"\u003ethe daily build\u003c/a\u003e from http://download-chromium.appspot.com/. This will automatically select the latest available version of Chromium from Google’s servers. Once you’ve got the archive, extract chrome-linux to a folder of your liking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext, open a terminal in this directory. Since you definitely want to isolate the config of the Canary version from the stable version, but probably keep it the same for all the Canary versions, we’re going to use a different user data directory than the default one. On the first run of this command Chromium will create a fresh profile, but on subsequent runs it’s just going to use what’s already in that directory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExecute:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e./chrome --user-data-dir\u003d~/.config/chromium-canary\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis creates a chromium-canary folder in the hidden .config folder in your home directory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat’s about it. You have to update Chromium manually every now and then, but no matter where you place the updated version the config will still be there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dIkDar48VmZ8:BQtDeHKxFLg:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/IkDar48VmZ8\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Tom Slominski","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356625442336","timestampUsec":"1356625442336608","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4d830fdffbe83018","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","Review","torchlight"],"title":"Torchlight: Diablo-Inspired Action RPG [Review]",
"published":1356625397,"updated":1356625397,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/torchlight-linux-review"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/SO3nq5RItPM/torchlight-linux-review","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBetween all the \u003cem\u003eHumble Indie Bundle\u003c/em\u003e games to land on Linux thus far, few have a team as distinguished as Torchlight’s. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eDeveloped by Runic Games, Torchlight is an action RPG that follows the point-and-click model of the popular Diablo series.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eIndeed, the founders of Runic, Erich and Max Schaefer, co-founded the company responsible for the first two Diablo games.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-title.png\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"399\" height\u003d\"282\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGameplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike its spiritual predecessors, this title feels smaller from the start. The town of Torchligh establishes the medieval fantasy tone from the start. But whilst my early adolescent days of Diablo II took me across juxtaposed locales, the only way out of Torchlight is down. The entirety of the title’s hack-and-slash mayhem takes place in the nearby Ember mines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough the geographical limitation feels claustrophobic at times, the 35 dungeon offer a variety of environments and creatures to keep you occupied for several days. The first set of dungeons are the usual cavernous mines, but forested ruins and sinister fortifications loom even lower.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:614px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-mob.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-mob.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"614\" height\u003d\"378\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eA troll in a fiery dungeon.\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBipedal felines, electrocuting turtles, poisonous zombies, and gigantic spiders are amongst the wide variety of creatures you encounter along the way. As you descend through the Ember mines, loot chests await your greedy hands – some offering masses of gold, others triggering traps or filling the room with a nightmare-enducing swarm of spiders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a compulsive hoarder in role-playing games, I found loot drops somewhat problematic and further exacerbated by issues in the Linux port. The mass of loot makes it difficult to differentiate between dropped items or to outright notice them when hidden behind scenery or simply piled under tonnes of leather armour.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:614px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-loot.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-loot.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"614\" height\u003d\"338\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eExcessive loot drop.\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen defeating one of many bosses scattered across the dungeons, the game would freeze momentarily before a loot drop. Having never played this title on other platforms, I can’t say whether this is a bug specific to the platform, or even to my setup, but it \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e a jarring moment in otherwise smooth gameplay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a left-handed gamer who also uses the mouse in my left hand, customising keyboard shortcuts is always the first thing I do; but Torchlight offers no such customisation (at least not without rummaging through text configuration files). This in itself wouldn’t be a problem, as the click-heavy gameplay only depends on shortcuts for quick activation of potions and spells. The issue arises with the keybinding for showing and hiding labels on dropped items – the alt key. Unfortunately, pressing the key to toggle the obtrusive, but useful, labels activates the Unity HUD. A show/hide labels button is provided in the “hotbar”, but accidentally pressing alt is nevertheless a frustrating issue, especially when playing in fullscreen mode.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven with the labels enabled, mousing over items or their labels is a laboured process, often cycling through the various items indiscriminately. I also found myself losing the sometimes inconspicuous cursor when a horde of enemies surrounded my character. Directional attacks or those that need to target individual creatures suffer most from this issue, but the wide variety of spells and weapons offer a way out of any situation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike other RPGs, Torchlight features several distinct, albeit sparse, skill trees. Melee, ranged, and spell-oriented classes offer initial specialisation in character creation, but the skill trees are open for any character to explore. My melee-classed character became an adept ranged fighter in no time once the giant spiders showed up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-character.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/torchlight-character.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"614\" height\u003d\"337\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you level up and your fame increases, you can add points to your skill tree and to various character attributes. Adding points to strength, dexterity, magic, or defence permits the use of more powerful weapons and increases the damage for weapons that benefit from each skill. Dexterity, for example, increases damage to ranged weapons, whilst additional strength aids melee attacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut you won’t have to fight alone. Your character starts with a companion of your choosing. Between a dog, cat, and ferret, your faithful companion can carry additional loot and use its own set of spells to supplement your attacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf its health is too low, your pet will flee and return when it regenerates. Though not essential to the gameplay, the pet does complement it well. If you’re unwilling to leave the dungeon to sell your abundant loot, you can send your pet back on its own and continue exploring whilst your companion trades off-screen and returns with gold.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs for the impetus to explore the dungeons, the main storyline sees you tracking down a character corrupted by the Ember and occasionally listening to journal entries that offer a small glimpse at the rather unexciting plot.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe side quests are understandably limited given that you’re confined to the town of Torchlight. One characters opens portals and asks you to retrieve various items on the other side; a robot troubadour looks for fame by asking you to defeat bosses across the 35 levels; and a scholar seeks embers scattered in the dungeons below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough the quests themselves are rather banal in the rank and file of action RPG and dungeon crawlers, the otherwise pleasurable gameplay makes up for some of the creative elisions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGraphics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e Torchlight is neither breathtaking nor outdated \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOriginally released in 2009, Torchlight is neither breathtaking nor outdated. The town is the least visually appealing locale, but the dungeons that make up the majority of the game are well-designed and atmospherically impeccable. Overgrown forested areas feel natural and alive whilst the clean lines and restricted palette of bricked dungeons feel sterile and perfectly ominous.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCharacter design borders on the comical rather than formidable. This isn’t to the title’s detriment, as the visual tone of the game lends itself to the exaggerated, sometimes cartoonish, features of the character models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e …spiders are still as frightening here as they were in Diablo II \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRest assured, spiders are still as frightening here as they were in Diablo II with its much darker tone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlaying with the latest \u003cem\u003eNvidia 310\u003c/em\u003e drivers on a GTX 260, fullscreen and windowed mode both performed well at the highest settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs always, your mileage may vary, though a netbook mode can be enabled if performance is still an issue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSound\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCritically-acclaimed Diablo composer Matt Uelmen invigorates the soundtrack with a light medieval fantasy flare. The town’s theme mixes a bit of rustic nostalgia with a hint of the fantastical that complements the quaint town. The music throughout the rest of the game quickens as fighting ensues and dies down to an ominous undercurrent mixed with the eerie sounds of each unique landscape.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVoice acting is rather sparse aside from the journal entry voice overs. Characters in Torchlight tend to have a single phrase or set of catchphrases with any additional dialogue in a scrolling pop up. Creature sounds range from the laboured steps of giant bosses to the crackly joints of thin-legged spiders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWeapon sounds are also beautifully captured. The short delay between clicking and hearing the crack of a gun or twang of a bow is perfectly timed, whilst hitting most enemies results in a satisfying thud. When mayhem ensues, the cacophony is almost unbearable, but the chaos of the moment certainly comes across in the aural bombardment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFinal Thoughts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy the time I reached the conclusion of the main storyline, I was underwhelmed by the storytelling, but still charmed by the varied landscapes and satisfying gameplay. Though I wouldn’t replay the main storyline again, completing it opens a set of dungeons for every subsequent character that features limitless and randomised levels and creatures from every dungeon in the game.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven for an experience that lasts a single playthrough, Torchlight is a beautifully crafted, if small, action RPG that ranks among the best of the growing Linux gaming library.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAvailability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTorchlight was included as part of Humble Indie Bundle 6. Whilst the game itself is available on Steam, the Linux version has yet to be added.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e, however, available in the Ubuntu Software Center for $14.99. You can redeem a USC copy from the \u003cem\u003eHumble Bundle\u003c/em\u003e website as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/torchlight/\" title\u003d\"Torchlight in the Ubuntu Software Center\"\u003e Torchlight on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dSO3nq5RItPM:XzKZINsLGNU:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dSO3nq5RItPM:XzKZINsLGNU:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dSO3nq5RItPM:XzKZINsLGNU:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dSO3nq5RItPM:XzKZINsLGNU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dSO3nq5RItPM:XzKZINsLGNU:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "updated":1356543328,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/clock-time-app-for-ubuntu"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/BHVKosTk-HY/clock-time-app-for-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/clock-html5-app.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"clock-html5-app\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/clock-html5-app.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"334\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFinding out the time in Ubuntu isn’t exactly difficult: it’s displayed on the top panel at all times.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut new HTML5-based time-telling app ‘\u003cem\u003eClock\u003c/em\u003e‘ thinks there’s still room for a \u003cem\u003echatoyant chronometer\u003c/em\u003e on your linux desktop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re thinking “\u003cem\u003eWhat’s the point?” \u003c/em\u003eat this juncture I’d urge you to check your phone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAre you one of the hundreds-of-thousands of users who place a giant ticking timepiece on their homescreen, despite the time being discreetly displayed at all times in the Android status bar?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow that you’re willing to give \u003cem\u003eClock \u003c/em\u003ea fair hearing we’ll continue…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMuch like the real life variety \u003cem\u003eClock\u003c/em\u003e has one primary purpose: to tell you the time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor this the app and its developer, Micheal Harker, get full marks because it automatically detected my timezone and showed me the correct time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConversely, I also felt it was lacking; some form of timer or alarm would have been a worthwhile addition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut since this is a first release it’s better the basics are done well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLook \u0026amp; Options\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike the weather app \u003cem\u003eStormcloud\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eClock\u003c/em\u003e lets you change the colour of the background.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSadly ‘Ubuntu Ambience’ isn’t included within the colour options on offer, nor is a ‘chameleonic’ feature like that j\u003ca title\u003d\"Weather App ‘Stormcloud’ Adds Multiple Locations, More\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/weather-app-stormcloud-adds-multiple-locations-more\"\u003eust added to the desktop weather app \u003cem\u003eStormcloud.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/prefes.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Clock Ubuntu App Preferences\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/prefes.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"411\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003ePreferences in ‘Clock’ – A New Ubuntu App\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThree different clock stlyes can be chosen from: \u003cstrong\u003edigital, polar\u003c/strong\u003e, and \u003cstrong\u003eanalogue. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e24 Hour Time\u003c/em\u003e and a ‘\u003cem\u003eseconds\u003c/em\u003e‘ hand can also be enabled from the Settings area. The former of these is less well though out: it merely adds an ‘AM’ or ‘PM’ suffix to the right-hand side of the clock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload ‘Clock’ App for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eClock\u003c/em\u003e is free to download and install, built using HTML5 and WebKit.  For more information, or to download it, hit the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://michealhark.tk/applications/clock/\" title\u003d\"Download Clock for Ubuntu\"\u003e More info on Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356544098368","timestampUsec":"1356544098368041","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/e07974fe1d68bda4","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","News"],"title":"New Game Lands on Linux","published":1355852409,"updated":1355852409,
"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/dare-up-wing-suit-added-to-ubuntu"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/8cz0dStPMRw/dare-up-wing-suit-added-to-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWill \u003cem\u003eDare Up! Wingsuit,\u003c/em\u003e a new addition to the Ubuntu Software Center, take off with users?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike a lot of recent game arrivals on Ubuntu \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.vnvgamez.com/en/dareup2.php\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e makes it’s debut thanks to the game engine it uses, Unity3D, having added support for exporting games to Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/wingsuit.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"wingsuit\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/wingsuit.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFreefall Fun\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe premise of \u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e is straightforward: you control your character as they ‘glide’ over a varying mountainous terrain. The closer to the surface you fly the more points you score. The more ‘special moves’ you can pull off the more points you earn.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust don’t fly too close or you’ll crash!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/x-ewukCvmqU?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game doesn’t deviate from its simplistic-sounding set-up, though the challenge varies depending on your choice of ‘jump off’ point and the terrain near-by. One additional ‘mode’, an in-air Slalom with rings, is available – though I found the challenge an aneurysm waiting to happen!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomisation options include the ability to change the colour of your suit, and select a ‘gender’ body.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuying Dare Up! Wingsuit\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough \u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e is available for free on Mac OS X and Windows (by way of the Unity Web Browser Plugin) Ubuntu players will first need to buy it through the Ubuntu Software Center for $2.99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is the minium price at which Canonical allow developers to sell apps at.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/dare-up-wing-suit/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e DareUp WingSuit on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith no new levels, exclusives, or add-ons to speak of in this “paid” version it’s hard for me to recommend buying it. That isn’t to say that the game isn’t good; it’s an ideal title for those seeking quick, easy and carefree – albeit disposable – gameplay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it’s nothing that you won’t find available for free elsewhere.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d8cz0dStPMRw:ahqIKxtCx3g:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/8cz0dStPMRw\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"published":1356352752,"updated":1356352752,"canonical":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/fC6wNo_8o6U/weather-app-stormcloud-adds-multiple-locations-more"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/FGA_ln9pXn4/weather-app-stormcloud-adds-multiple-locations-more","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWeather app \u003cem\u003eStormcloud\u003c/em\u003e – which \u003ca title\u003d\"Top 10 Ubuntu Apps of 2012\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/top-10-ubuntu-apps-of-2012\"\u003efeatured in our re-written from the ground up, Stormcloud 1.2 now supports multiple locations, ‘chameleonic backgrounds’, and boasts some extra animations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Stormcloud multiple locations\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-29-at-12.20.19.png\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"358\" style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/stormcloudcamheloeon.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"stormcloud chameleon\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/stormcloudcamheloeon.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"233\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eStormcloud 1.2′s new chamelonic backgrounds in action\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne ‘removal’ I’m sad to see go is the Unity Launcher badge displaying the temperature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:296px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/unitystormcloud.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"StormCloud Launcher Item\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/unitystormcloud.jpg\" alt\u003d\"StormCloud Launcher Item\" width\u003d\"296\" height\u003d\"296\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eLauncher count: no longer included\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough incapable of displaying metrical units due to a limitation of Unity, it was still a handy feature to have, and one that made keeping the app open, albeit hidden, worthwhile.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePreferences\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is no longer a dedicated button for switching to the \u003cem\u003ePreferences\u003c/em\u003e pane.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstead it’s located as the very last slide in the carousel; keep hitting the ‘right’ button in the top-right hand corner, or hit your left-arrow navigation key until you get to it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmongst the settings here you can add or remove additional locations: -\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"width:499px\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/stprmcloid.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Stormcloud 1.2 Preferences\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/stprmcloid.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Stormcloud 1.2 Preferences\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"335\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cp\u003eStormcloud 1.2 Preferences – Simple To Use\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eChoose your temperature and windspeed units; set a custom background, or enable a ‘Chameleonic’ one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSmall Cost\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe biggest change in Stormcloud 1.2 isn’t to do with features at all, but price.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePreviously a free application, Stormcloud was available to install via downloadable .Deb installers and a PPA. These are now no longer available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom this release on the app has switched to a ‘paid’ model, though the source code remains freely available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStormcloud 1.2 costs \u003cstrong\u003e$2.99\u003c/strong\u003e on the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe price is perhaps a little bit more than I’d reasonably expect to pay for it, but the developer is hamstrung by Canonical in this regard: $2.99 is the lowest price at which they allow developers to sell their apps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, $2.99 does get you a gorgeous looking weather app for the desktop, and helps to supports one of Ubuntu’s most and accomplished developers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe hands behind Stormcloud also shaped to-do app \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNitro Tasks\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e; RSS app \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLightRead\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e; CSS gradient generator \u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGradiator - \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003eall of which they offer for free.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/stormcloud/\" title\u003d\"Buy Stormcloud on Ubuntu\"\u003e Stormcloud on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356181587342","timestampUsec":"1356181587342886","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/cc0130f546c7d730","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","List","best of 2012"],"title":"Top 10 Ubuntu Apps of 2012","published":1356181499,
"updated":1356181499,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/top-10-ubuntu-apps-of-2012"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/-JRWV0QvYw8/top-10-ubuntu-apps-of-2012","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe last 12 months have been some of the most tumultuous yet tremendous that \u003cem\u003eUbuntu\u003c/em\u003e has ever seen. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we look back at the highs and lows of Ubuntu in 2012 lets first pay some attention to the bits that help make it what it is: the apps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo here are some of the best app-shaped \u003cem\u003edebutantes\u003c/em\u003e of 2012.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStormcloud\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: October 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/storm.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/storm.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike flip-flops in mid winter, the usefulness of a ‘windowed’ weather app doesn’t seem immediately useful. If it’s going to rain, snow or hail we want to be able to see that at a glance, not have to remind ourselves to hunt around open windows to check.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut after downloading and installing Stormcloud, the first of three apps on this list by developers Caffeinated Code, those concerns were moot.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStylish, slick and informative, Stormcloud showed that weather apps don’t have be droll, drop-down menu affairs. Its Unity launcher integration, striking visuals and customisation options mean that, for this app, the  is looking very bright indeed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/stormcloud/\" title\u003d\"Stormcloud\"\u003e Stormcloud on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNitro\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: April 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/new-nitro-linux-theme.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/new-nitro-linux-theme.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo-do apps are, it’s fair to say, hardly on the ‘urgent’ list when it comes to things Linux users long for on the desktop. In fact, a quick search in the Ubuntu Software Center \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vomiting\"\u003ethrows up\u003c/a\u003e a veritable post-xmas dinner quantity of options.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd most of them are about as good looking as the aforementioned metaphor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo \u003ca title\u003d\"Post about Nitro\u0026#39;s first release\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/04/task-management-app-nitrotasks-debuts-on-ubuntu\"\u003ethe launch of Nitro\u003c/a\u003e, an app by the folks at caffienated code, didn’t exactly make me giddy, particularly since Wunderlist – the ‘darling’ of task managing – was available for Linux in one form or another.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut I was proved wrong.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSporting Dropbox and Ubuntu One syncing, as well as apps for Windows, OS X and the web, Nitro gave Linux users a gorgeous looking and well featured app that made accessing our to-do’s a must-do!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/nitro/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Nitro on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSteam for Linux\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: November 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"steambeta\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/steambeta.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFew apps on this list are will leave an indelible mark on the history of Linux. The launched of a native Steam client for Ubuntu, however, is the exception.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReleased in early November to a select number of testers, before opening up to anyone who wants it earlier this month, Steam for Linux is not a shoddy, half-bake implementation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNor is it\u003cem\u003e “just”\u003c/em\u003e an app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee, Steam for Linux is a milestone. It’s arrival has been like a bat-signal to other developers, telling them that the Linux desktop \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e commercially viable and \u003cem\u003eshould\u003c/em\u003e be taken seriously.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, since its announcement most major graphics card vendors have stepped up their support for Linux, bringing features long since missing to their binary blob drivers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo whether a gamer or not; whether you use Steam or its social features or don’t, everyone on Linux has benefitted from its arrival. And, in my guess, will continue to benefit for some time to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://store.steampowered.com/about/\" title\u003d\"Download Steam for Linux\"\u003e Download Steam for Linux \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGeary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: May 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/geary-full.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/geary-full.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRefining and streamlining the desktop e-mail experience was on the minds of Yorba, the makers of photo app \u003cem\u003eShotwell\u003c/em\u003e, when they launched \u003cem\u003eGeary \u003c/em\u003eback in spring of 2012.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough \u003ca title\u003d\"New E-Mail Client ‘Geary’ Launches on Linux\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/05/new-e-mail-client-geary-launches-on-linux\"\u003ethis early version was rough around the edges\u003c/a\u003e it showed promise – promise that was delivered on by its \u003ca title\u003d\"New Version of Linux E-Mail App ‘Geary’ Released\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/new-linux-e-mail-app-geary-updates\"\u003esecond release this past October.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith some nifty Ubuntu integration and a healthy, though not exhaustive, feature set, Geary is shaping up to be the one e-mail client available on Linux that’s worth writing, or in this case e-mailing, home about.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/geary/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Geary on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInSync\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: Still in Beta)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/indicator.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/indicator.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"303\" height\u003d\"268\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGoogle launched their much anticipated \u003ca title\u003d\"Google Drive Launches, Lacks Linux Client\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/04/google-drive-launches-without-linux-support\"\u003ecloud storage service “\u003cem\u003eGoogle\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eDrive\u003c/em\u003e” earlier this year\u003c/a\u003e – but failed to provide a desktop client for Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThankfully it didn’t take long for the community solutions to pop up, the most capable (and usable) of which being \u003cem\u003e‘InSync’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with instantaneous syncing of your \u003cem\u003eDrive\u003c/em\u003e contents to and from Ubuntu, InSync lets you edit your Google Docs files offline; integrates with Nautilus; and alerts you to any changes or errors via an indicator applet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe company who make the app claim to store nothing themselves (bar authentication token and metadata info on your files). All uploads, edits and deletions occur natively on your device and are ‘synced’ to Google Drive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe “bad” news is that the app is only ‘free to use’ during its beta period (which it is still in). After this time a subscription model will be introduced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut don’t fear: a free\u003cem\u003e Google Drive for Linux\u003c/em\u003e app is being made by Google, and I’m told it should make its way out into the wild in the first quarter of 1213.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://s.insynchq.com/builds/insync-beta-ubuntu_0.9.30_amd64.deb\" title\u003d\"Download InSync for Ubuntu\"\u003e Download InSync Beta 12 (64bit, .deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://s.insynchq.com/builds/insync-beta-ubuntu_0.9.30_i386.deb\" title\u003d\"Download InSync for Ubuntu\"\u003e Download InSync Beta 12 (32bit, .deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLightread\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: July 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/lightread2.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"lightread2\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/lightread2.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"700\" height\u003d\"431\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eBefore the Ubuntu App Showdown RSS fans had to stick with Google Reader in the browser, or use one of a handful of bloated and unsightly ‘native apps’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eRealising that something needed to be done Lightread was born.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eIn fact it’s something of a misnomer to call LightRead an RSS client. It’s not; it’s a Google Reader client.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eYes it looks very similar to a certain OS X app, but so what? imitation is the sincerest form of flattery\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/lightread/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Lightread on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUberWriter\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: August 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/uber.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"uber\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/uber.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eUberWriter\u003c/em\u003e, created as part of the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu App Showdown\u003c/em\u003e, is a nitfy ‘lightweight’ text editor designed specifically for \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown\"\u003ewriting Markdown\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot being a user of Markdown (\u003ca href\u003d\"http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/\"\u003esee here for more on using it\u003c/a\u003e) I can’t attest to its usefulness in that area, but it does work brilliantly as a ‘distraction free’ text editor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘Focus’ mode is worth praising in particular. With it enabled you can better concentrate on the sentence you’re writing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/uberwriter/\" title\u003d\"download UberWriter for Ubuntu\"\u003e UberWriter on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUnity News Lens\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: May 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/news-lens1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/news-lens1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e2012 may not have seen any booms of the apocalyptic variety, but it did see one in the creation of Unity Lenses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eMost of them the work of one developer:\u003cem\u003e David Callé.\u003c/em\u003e Amongst his multiple creation was this, the Unity News Lens.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eEasily my favourite of his releases this year – I’m a news junkie, don’t hate – it brought\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eA healthy smattering of filters to narrow down search results; the use of your location to display local stories; and handy options for sorting made it a useful tool for those who, like me, are news junkies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/07/unity-news-lens-adds-updates-with-local-features\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e How to Install Unity News Lens in Ubuntu \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCuttleFish\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: August 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Cuttlefish_003.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Cuttlefish_003.png\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"456\" height\u003d\"370\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re not immersed in marine life then figuring out what Cuttlefish does from its name alone can be tricky. Thankfully, once installed, it’s all very apparent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCuttlefish, named after a many-tentacled sea creature, is a sort of ‘\u003cem\u003eif this, then that\u003c/em\u003e‘ for your desktop that’s capable of doing automated tasks based on certain events you specify.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo, for example, you could configure it to disable Bluetooth when the screensaver starts; or have Firefox open up the second you connect to a WiFi network. when you connect to Wifi.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGuest contributor \u003cem\u003eKev Quirk\u003c/em\u003e wrote a thorough run-down of \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/automate-ubuntu-with-cuttlefish\"\u003ehow to put Cuttlefish tentacled talents to use\u003c/a\u003e in Ubuntu back in September – \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/automate-ubuntu-with-cuttlefish\"\u003edo check it out.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/cuttlefish/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Cuttlefish on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePostman\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(First release: August 2012)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/jmp2sMCeQkQ?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePicking just one last item for this list was hard. 2012 saw so many great applications created, many of which came about as entries to the \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu App Showdown Winners Announced\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/ubuntu-app-showdown-winners-announced\"\u003eUbuntu App Showdown\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut my final entry is for Postman. It’s not the most useful app for its purpose, but it is one of the best looking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt uses a psedu-literal metaphor for ‘sending’ your photos to Flickr and Ubuntu One; you put photos in the envelope, then attach a ‘stamp’ f0r ‘Flickr’, ‘Picasa’, ‘Google+’ and/or ‘Ubuntu One’ to send it to those services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1356030121759","timestampUsec":"1356030121759372","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4005bf5a2d3e6cea","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Download","News","mac","osx","ubuntuone"],"title":"Official Ubuntu One Mac Client Leaves Beta",
"published":1356030082,"updated":1356030082,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/ubuntu-one-for-mac-goes-stable"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/oS7N-Oea8CY/ubuntu-one-for-mac-goes-stable","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDespite the popularity of alternatives, Ubuntu One remains my go-to cloud storage/sync service.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd good news for anyone who dual-boots Ubuntu with OS X is that the official Ubuntu Mac client \u003ca href\u003d\"http://voices.canonical.com/ubuntuone/2012/12/19/official-mac-os-x-client-for-ubuntu-one/\"\u003ehas slipped out of beta\u003c/a\u003e and gone ‘stable’ in its 4.0 release.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Screen Shot 2012-12-20 at 14.52\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Screen-Shot-2012-12-20-at-14.52.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"526\" height\u003d\"311\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have an \u003ca title\u003d\"Official Ubuntu One App for Mac Enters Beta\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/official-ubuntu-one-client-for-mac-enters-beta\"\u003eolder version of the Mac client\u003c/a\u003e installed you will need to download this version and re-install. This is because earlier builds lack an auto-update option.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that this has now been integrated into the app, so future updates will arrive fuss-free.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu One for Mac joins Ubuntu, Windows, Android and iOS as platforms with official clients. An \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Files App Comes to the Nokia N9 (Unofficially)\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/05/ubuntu-one-files-app-comes-to-the-nokia-n9-unofficially\"\u003eunofficial app for the Nokia N9 is also available\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eChanges Since the Beta\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA number of things have changed between the previous beta versions and this, the 4.0 stable build.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirstly, and importantly for a ‘sync’ service, Ubuntu One remains running the background after you close the main window. It can be closed entirely by selecting ‘Quit’ from the panel indicator menu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tray area menu longer works like a traditional Mac panel menu: You can’t ‘switch’ to it using the navigation keys, and clicking on it doesn’t use the ‘blue’ selection highlight (see image above).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTrival points aside, the update also brings a set of new ‘transfer progress’ icons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Screen-Shot-2012-12-20-at-14.46.33.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Transfer Icon\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Screen-Shot-2012-12-20-at-14.46.33.png\" alt\u003d\"Ubuntu One Transfer Icon\" width\u003d\"291\" height\u003d\"78\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMac App Store Bound?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eNo plans to submit it to the Mac App Store\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu One developers have told me that they have ‘\u003cem\u003eno plans\u003c/em\u003e‘ to submit the application to the Mac App Store.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy not? They say that Apple’s \u003cem\u003e‘sandboxing requirements would severely hinder our capabilities.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich though understandable is a shame. It would’ve been nice to see our fruit-emblemed friends add some Ubuntu goodness to their diets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu One for Mac is a free download requiring OS X 10.6 or higher and an Ubuntu One account.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://one.ubuntu.com/downloads/mac/\" "published":1356006302,"updated":1356006302,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/unity-previews-look-updated-in-ubuntu-13-04"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/39ZhM18k0F0/unity-previews-look-updated-in-ubuntu-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnity’s\u003cem\u003e Previews\u003c/em\u003e feature has seen a number of refinements over the last week as work on Unity in 13.04 continues.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA slicker animation has been introduced, along with better visual differentiation between the active and inactive preview items.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re a subscriber to our \u003ca title\u003d\"OMG! Ubuntu! On YouTube\" href\u003d\"http://youtube.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eYouTube channel\u003c/a\u003e then you’ll have seen a video of these tweaks in action yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/xvpK1mQsTpM?feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIn Detail\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe changes aren’t subtle, and anyone familiar with the Previews feature as it works in 12.10 will notice the different.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost notable thus far is the new ‘drop-down’ animation when opening a preview. Although not quite as ‘interesting’ in action as that used in 12.10, it is faster and cleaner. Preview details themselves now appear within a container to better differentiate the details pane from general icon grid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"new-unity-animation\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/new-unity-animation.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFollowing that thinking, the container also adds a small ‘call out’ item pointing to the icon, file or item being previewed and ‘ghosts’ (turns into darkened silhouettes) the icons of items \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e being previewed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a user navigates through the preview slides \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/1060941\"\u003ethe relevant ghost icon will light up\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e Ubuntu 13.04 is in active development. Changes featured here are not complete or indicative of the final release, due April 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d39ZhM18k0F0:YgrIBmdO4pE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/39ZhM18k0F0\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
