},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1355938207896","timestampUsec":"1355938207896399","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/60571b980293916c","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","DareUp WingSuit"],"title":"Flying Game ‘Dare Up! Wingsuit’ Lands on Ubuntu",
"published":1355938104,"updated":1355938104,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/dare-up-wing-suit-added-to-ubuntu?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003ddare-up-wing-suit-added-to-ubuntu"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/zH9l45AcjVk/dare-up-wing-suit-added-to-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/wingsuit.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"wingsuit\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/wingsuit.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWill \u003cem\u003eDare Up! Wingsuit,\u003c/em\u003e a new addition to the Ubuntu Software Center, take off with users?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike a lot of recent game arrivals on Ubuntu \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.vnvgamez.com/en/dareup2.php\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e makes it’s debut thanks to the game engine it uses, Unity3D, having added support for exporting games to Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFreefall Fun\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe premise of \u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e is straightforward: you control your character as they ‘glide’ over a varying mountainous terrain. The closer to the surface you fly the more points you score. The more ‘special moves’ you can pull off the more points you earn.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust don’t fly too close or you’ll crash!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/x-ewukCvmqU?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game doesn’t deviate from its simplistic-sounding set-up, though the challenge varies depending on your choice of ‘jump off’ point and the terrain near-by. One additional ‘mode’, an in-air Slalom with rings, is available – though I found the challenge an aneurysm waiting to happen!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomisation options include the ability to change the colour of your suit, and select a ‘gender’ body.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuying Dare Up! Wingsuit\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough \u003cem\u003eWingsuit\u003c/em\u003e is available for free on Mac OS X and Windows (by way of the Unity Web Browser Plugin) Ubuntu players will first need to buy it through the Ubuntu Software Center for $2.99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is the minium price at which Canonical allow developers to sell apps at.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/dare-up-wing-suit/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e DareUp WingSuit on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith no new levels, exclusives, or add-ons to speak of in this “paid” version it’s hard for me to recommend buying it. That isn’t to say that the game isn’t good; it’s an ideal title for those seeking quick, easy and carefree – albeit disposable – gameplay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBut it’s nothing that you won’t find available for free elsewhere. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dzH9l45AcjVk:OVAxK-AdTj4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/zH9l45AcjVk\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

sudo apt-get install vlc\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause this is a \u003cem\u003ethird party \u003c/em\u003ePPA you install from this at your own risk. At the time of writing it contains VLC 2.0.5 and its various components as well as a \u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~n-muench/+archive/vlc?field.series_filter\u003dquantal\"\u003ehandful of other applications\u003c/a\u003e, including music app Audacity and video editor LiVES.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs such you may not want to add this PPA if you use either of those applications as they will be upgraded.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMy advice is to stick with the version of VLC available from the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Software Center - \u003c/em\u003eit may be one version behind whirlwind highlights of a number of milestones reached by the open-source Unix-like operating system during the last 12 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmongst the items highlighted is the unstoppable march of Android, the launch of affordable Linux-powered Chromebooks from Google, and the success of the Linux Foundation itself in attracting more big-name members.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerhaps the only critical thing there is to say about the otherwise buoyant celebration,concerns the decision to frame it within a Firefox browser window running Games developers are being encouraged to submit their ‘minimum’ and ‘recommend’ System Requirements to Valve for publishing ‘ASAP’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAmnesia\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDynamite Jack\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEversion\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eiBomber Attack\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eKilling Floor\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRed Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSerious Sam 3:BFE\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSword \u0026amp; Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1355321063584","timestampUsec":"1355321063584998","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/7bcb1d3f2fe3f3b4","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Dev","News","dash","icons","raring ringtail","unity"],"title":"New Dash Icons Proposed for Ubuntu 13.04",
"published":1355321042,"updated":1355321042,"alternate":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/new-dash-icons-proposed-for-ubuntu-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUpdated navigation bar icons for the Unity Dash have been proposed for Ubuntu 13.04.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe updated designs by Matthieu James iterate rather than overhaul those currently used in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/62D2c.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"new lens nav icons in 13.04\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/62D2c.png\" alt\u003d\"new lens nav icons in 13.04\" width\u003d\"455\" height\u003d\"130\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRounder icons are proposed for ‘Home’, ‘Files’, ‘Photos’ and ‘Video’ lenses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eApplications Lens\u003c/em\u003e icon sports the same ‘A’ design \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Updates Software Center, Update Manager Icons in 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/ubuntu-updates-software-center-update-manager-icons-in-13-04\"\u003eas that used on the new\u003cem\u003e Ubuntu Software Center\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eSoftware Updater\u003c/em\u003e icons debuted late last month.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt certainly says “Applications” more than that the currently used \u003cem\u003e‘ruler, crayon, pen’\u003c/em\u003e icon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/icons-watered.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"359\" height\u003d\"145\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e#Uh-oh\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far, so good. The changes are refined versions that better convey the content of their respective lens.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, somewhat controversially, this updated set suggests replacing the traditional Gwibber ‘blobby-bird’ lens icon for the official Twitter bird.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince Gwibber is more than just a Twitter client (although I know of few people who use it for anything other than Twitter) you might wonder whether this makes sense.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that it’s unlikely that this will remain the default Gwibber Lens icon. A new icon design was mooted during the development of Ubuntu 12.10 but its creation was \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/unity/+bug/1056191/comments/1\"\u003eshunted over to\u003c/a\u003e the Ubuntu 13.04 development cycle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat do you think of them? Improvement? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e Ubuntu 13.04 is in active development. Changes featured here are not complete or indicative of the final release, due April 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"

"updated":1355240682,"canonical":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/vzc2jML-cXc/ubuntu-one-referral-space-goes-awol"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/fqxyL2qg01M/ubuntu-one-referral-space-goes-awol","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"ubuntuone-banner\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/ubuntuone-banner1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e Update: 11th December: This issue has now been fixed. \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSome Ubuntu One users are experiencing issues with extra storage earned as part of the\u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Referral Scheme Launched, Offers 20GB Extra Space\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/ubuntu-one-referral-scheme-launched-offers-20gb-extra-space\"\u003e Ubuntu One Referrals programme.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUp to 20GB of free space can be gained through the affiliate scheme, but the bug means that Ubuntu One is – \u003cem\u003eat the time of writing\u003c/em\u003e – no longer showing accrued space in users’ accounts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, one user who contacted us has ‘lost’ access to over 20GB of space, \u003ca href\u003d\"http://twitter.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eanother who Tweeted us\u003c/a\u003e is down 8.5GB. Rumours initially guessed that the ‘free’ space was time limited, though no such limit was made in the initial announcement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Data will be safe’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe reached out to Ubuntu One team for clarification.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey told us that they are\u003cem\u003e ‘aware of the issue’\u003c/em\u003e and ar\u003cem\u003ee ‘actively working on [fixing] it’, \u003c/em\u003eadding that any data stored in the ‘missing space’ has not been deleted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘Your data will be safe,’\u003c/em\u003e they assured us,\u003cem\u003e ‘no worries about that.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs this issue only affects space earned via \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu One Referral Scheme Launched, Offers 20GB Extra Space\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/ubuntu-one-referral-scheme-launched-offers-20gb-extra-space\"\u003ethe Ubuntu One Referrals programme\u003c/a\u003e and not that puchased in 20GB chunks, few people are likely to be affected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBut if you do log into your Ubuntu One account and notice you’re down a few GBs – hold tight, it’ll be fixed soon.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1355079611664","timestampUsec":"1355079611664099","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/9167ca54b6d865d6","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","Review","bittriprunner","canabalt"],"title":"Sidescroller Run Off: Bit.Trip Runner Vs Canabalt [Review]",
"published":1355079592,"updated":1355079592,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/sidescroller-run-off-bit-trip-runner-vs-canabalt-review"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/sQMsi-mK8MI/sidescroller-run-off-bit-trip-runner-vs-canabalt-review","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAmongst the mélange of Humble Indie Bundle titles are two side-scrollers with similar, yet unique takes on well-timed spacebar mashing: Canabalt and Bit.Trip Runner. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese titles aren’t the sprawling role-playing games and first person shooters of large studio productions, but nevertheless encapsulate the art of video games in their humble, yet pleasing experiences.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBit.Trip Runner\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/bitr.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBit.Trip Runner is the fourth title in the sprawling \u003cem\u003eBit.Trip\u003c/em\u003e series (including \u003ca title\u003d\"Bit.Trip.Beat on OMG! Ubuntu!\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/bit-trip-beat-its-like-pong-turned-evil\"\u003epreviously reviewed\u003c/a\u003e title \u003cem\u003eBit.Trip Beat\u003c/em\u003e). Much like its predecessors, Bit.Trip Runner features rhythm-based movement through multiple levels, culminating in a boss fight before proceeding to the next set of maps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe gameplay is fairly straightforward. You kick, crouch, and jump to avoid obstacles and rack up points by collecting gold and power ups throughout the map. A jump into a wall or slide into a rock will send you back to the beginning of the level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/se.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you manage to collect all the gold bars in a single run, a bonus round gives you an opportunity to collect more gold bars in a “retro” level without the lively music or moving backdrops.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e The game throws the entire colour spectrum at the screen… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCranking the difficultly down to “Easy” eliminates the gold bars from the map and cranking it up to “Perfect” means any missed power ups or gold bars sends you back to the beginning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour in-game actions are timed to the music, though I found my movements slightly ahead of the beat – something that can easily trip you up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMuch like one of its predecessors, \u003ca title\u003d\"Bit.TRIP.Beat: It’s Like Pong Turned Evil\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/bit-trip-beat-its-like-pong-turned-evil\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eBit.Trip Beat\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, the moving backdrops often obstruct your view of upcoming obstacles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/G7f7OZpuffM?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the frustration of running into the same walls and UFOs repeatedly, the music adds aural complexity as you gain power ups throughout a map.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven when a level loses its flavour a few restarts in, the soundtrack will continue to provide some sanity as you angrily mash your arrow keys and spacebar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/b.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/b.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game is visually stimulating, but often throws the entire colour spectrum at the screen in a hodgepodge of character, obstacle, and backdrop design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, again, the title flourishes aurally where it might let down in gameplay and overstimulate with visuals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBit.Trip Runner and its soundtrack were included as part of Humble Indie Bundle 4 and 6.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough it is currently unavailable for Linux through the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/steam-for-linux-beta-adds-yet-more-users\"\u003eSteam Beta\u003c/a\u003e, it \u003cem\u003eis\u003c/em\u003e available through the Ubuntu Software Center for $7.99 or by visiting the Humble Bundle site to redeem your USC copy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/bittriprunner/\" title\u003d\"BIT.TRIP RUNNER on the Ubuntu Software Center\"\u003e BIT.TRIP RUNNER on Ubuntu \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/reviewcanabtl.png\" alt\u003d\"review of bit trip runner on ubuntu\" width\u003d\"512\" height\u003d\"339\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCanabalt\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/playerscreen.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/playerscreen.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"168\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Museum of Modern Art \u003ca title\u003d\"Video Games at the Museum of Modern Art\" href\u003d\"http://www.moma.org/explore/inside_out/2012/11/29/video-games-14-in-the-collection-for-starters/\"\u003erecently announced\u003c/a\u003e a new collection of artwork consisting solely of video games. \u003cem\u003eCanabalt\u003c/em\u003e is one of the first 14 titles in this new collection, including well-known games like Tetris, Myst, and Portal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eIt is the pop art to the Renaissance sculpture of other games heralded as art \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhilst my memories of \u003cem\u003eMyst\u003c/em\u003e from the early 90s include crudely drawn maps and illegible combinations in various notepads, Canabalt doesn’t demand puzzle mastery or offer compelling storytelling. It is the pop art to the Renaissance sculpture of many other games heralded as art – engaging or enraging depending on the player.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike Bit.Trip Runner, Canabalt is an endless run through a generated map replete with glass curtain walls to smash through, obstacles to avoid, and falling debris to leap over as you jump from rooftop to rooftop. And jumping is all you can do.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/canabl.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you progress through the map, your character gains more and more speed until you crash into the various obstacles on the rooftops, come face-to-face with falling objects, or meet an untimely death with a poorly executed jump.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003ethe soundtrack catapults this title beyond its otherwise banal gameplay\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMuch like Tetris, you can brave the challenge alone or with a second player.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn both cases, the minimalistic gameplay sounds leave the majority of the aural experience to the soundtrack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough I never made it farther than a few thousand metres and, thus, only a few paces into any given piece of music, the soundtrack catapults this title beyond its otherwise banal gameplay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/TkLSYkRjU2g?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe visual style is also compelling in its simple, yet striking presence. Combined with the soundtrack by composer Danny Baranowsky (also known for his work on \u003cem\u003eSuper Meat Boy\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eThe Binding of Isaac\u003c/em\u003e), the audio-visual design makes the gameplay itself a backdrop to the sensual experience within an industrial cityscape bombarded by machinery and crumbling beneath your feet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eArs Gratia Artis or Simply Banal?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what does this game have to offer if not compelling gameplay? In the same way that abstract art and conceptual poetry challenge the definitions of their genre and incite fiery opinions from the entire spectrum of art and literary criticism, Canabalt fills a seemingly ambivalent role as both a pleasing timewaster and a game-like work of art.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhether you expect artistic dialogue or simply entertainment from Canabalt, its visual and aural design outpace the gameplay, but not necessarily to its detriment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAvailability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCanabalt won’t be found on Steam or the Ubuntu Software Center; however, the download from the Humble Bundle site is simply an HTML file with embedded flash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you skipped the last few Android Humble Bundles, never fear. The title is also freely available on the web (though lacking a two player option). The soundtrack is available on Bandcamp with a “name your price” scheme.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.adamatomic.com/canabalt/\" title\u003d\"Canabalt from Adam Atomic and Danny B\"\u003e Play Canabalt Online \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://dbsoundworks.bandcamp.com/album/canabalt-soundtrack-ringtones-pack-w-bonus-fathom-megamix\" title\u003d\"Canabalt soundtrack on Bandcamp\"\u003e Canabalt Soundtrack on Bandcamp \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dsQMsi-mK8MI:y_DSHGbI39g:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dsQMsi-mK8MI:y_DSHGbI39g:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dsQMsi-mK8MI:y_DSHGbI39g:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dsQMsi-mK8MI:y_DSHGbI39g:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dsQMsi-mK8MI:y_DSHGbI39g:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg "updated":1354902642,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/steam-for-linux-beta-adds-yet-more-users"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/xACQLCQNJgs/steam-for-linux-beta-adds-yet-more-users","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/steambeta.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"steambeta\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/steambeta.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore users now been given access to the limited Steam for Linux beta, Valve have confirmed.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://steamcommunity.com/games/221410/announcements/detail/1749910796493493022\"\u003eAnnouncing the expansion\u003c/a\u003e of beta access on the \u003cem\u003eSteam for Linux\u003c/em\u003e form, Valve’s \u003cem\u003eFrank\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eCrockett \u003c/em\u003eurged those who have applied previously to check their inbox for a redemption code.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis expansion brings the total number of \u003cem\u003eSteam for Linux\u003c/em\u003e users up to \u003ca href\u003d\"http://steamcommunity.com/games/221410/members\"\u003e21,542 Members\u003c/a\u003e. The company \u003ca title\u003d\"Steam Open Linux Beta to 5000 More Gamers\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/steam-open-linux-beta-to-5000-more-gamers\"\u003eadded an additional 5,000\u003c/a\u003e users late last month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew Bug Forums\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to wider access, Valve also announced several new sub-forums have been added for testers to report bugs in. These include sections for Valve Game bugs, Non-Valve games bug, to forums for bug reporting against specific graphics cards.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGetting Close\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother sign that the Steam for Linux beta is nearing its end listing of \u003ca title\u003d\"Steam Games Begin Adding Linux System Requirements\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/steam-games-begin-adding-linux-system-requirements\"\u003eLinux System Requirements  games\u003c/a\u003e, the beta period for Serious Sam 3: BFE is now over – meaning players need to purchased the game inorder to keep playing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSaved game data remains unaffected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSerious Sam 3: BFE\u003c/em\u003e was available to play for free during the beta period. With that period now over, could the client be one step closer to a proper release?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor a full list of Linux-friendly games available on Steam can be found hiding behind the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://store.steampowered.com/search/?term\u003dlinux#os\u003dlinux\u0026amp;advanced\u003d0\u0026amp;sort_order\u003dASC\u0026amp;page\u003d1\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Linux Compatible Steam Games \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eDon’t forget to join the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://steamcommunity.com/groups/omgubuntu\"\u003eOMG! },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354892726519","timestampUsec":"1354892726519029","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/f4fcb17c824bede9","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","News","dash","raring ringtail","unity"],"title":"More Online Results Heading to Ubuntu Dash in 13.04",
"published":1354892141,"updated":1354892141,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/more-online-results-heading-to-ubuntu-dash-in-13-04"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/JmkGF3QcSbY/more-online-results-heading-to-ubuntu-dash-in-13-04","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/original-shopping-lens.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Shopping Lens As it Looks in Ubuntu 12.10\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/original-shopping-lens.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Unity Shopping Lens As it Looks in Ubuntu 12.10\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore online integration is coming to Ubuntu in its next release, Canonical have \u003ca href\u003d\"http://blog.canonical.com/2012/12/07/searching-in-the-dash-in-ubuntu-13-04/\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu 13.04 will \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/mark-shuttleworth-explains-ubuntus-new-amazon-adware-feature\"\u003e‘fulfil’ the goal of the Unity Dash\u003c/a\u003e to be a one-stop global search tool. It will include more ‘Scopes’, a new relevancy ranking system, and a wider range of commercial product suggestions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis, Canonical are hoping, will allow users find whatever they need – be it online, local, or commercial - direct from the Ubuntu desktop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo what can we expect?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMore Scopes, Better Results\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe most notable change will be even more ‘scopes’ – small, modular and specific ‘search engines’ for the Dash – in the default Ubuntu install.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA wider range of sources being searched means a wider range of results to be displayed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo prevent the Dash from being over-populated with irrelevant ’noisy’ Wikipedia, Amazon, Flickr, etc results a new feature will be added that only displays \u003cem\u003e‘the right [results] based on relevancy’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething the current Amazon Lens could certainly do with!\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e …A mix of local and online results. \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs an example, searching for the band ‘Coldplay’ will fetch results from your local music collection, and scopes such as YouTube, Amazon Music, Last.FM, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis ‘mix’ of online and local results will be determined by a new ‘smart scope service’, created with the aim of retyrning ’ranked online search results’ to Dash to ‘balance against local results to return the most relevant information to the user.’\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstant Purchasing of Music \u0026amp; Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of my faovurite features in Ubuntu 12.10 is the ability to install \u003cem\u003efree\u003c/em\u003e applications directly from the Dash, without the need to open the Software Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/KbrOrR3wctc?start\u003d54\u0026amp;fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor Ubuntu 13.04 this ‘instant installation’ idea will be expanded to encompass the purchase of music from \u003cem\u003eUbuntu One Music\u003c/em\u003e and apps and eBooks from the Ubuntu Software Center – mo browser needed!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis, Canonical say, will ‘…\u003cem\u003edeliver the fastest possible purchasing experience directly from the Dash.’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMore Commercial Suggestions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough unlikely to be welcomed by some, Ubuntu 13.04 will expand its commercial suggestions to include results from additional online retailers and services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e ‘refined privacy options will be introduced’ \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, unlike the ‘first’ iteration of the Shopping Lens that caused so much controversy, Canonical appear to be approaching this second version with a new, more considered focus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew filters for narrowing down shopping results are currently being tested, and refined privacy options for disabling/curtailing the data-espousing tendencies of online scopes are to be introduced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhether these changes will be enough to placate those not sold on the idea of commercial results remains to be seen…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dJmkGF3QcSbY:QuZoa5DfJrs:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca "published":1354831238,"updated":1354831238,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/planetside-2-dev-gives-hope-for-linux-port"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/dmo1v3dxnpo/planetside-2-dev-gives-hope-for-linux-port","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/276549_209775182400434_978649401_n.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"276549_209775182400434_978649401_n\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/276549_209775182400434_978649401_n.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"160\" height\u003d\"160\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eCould Sony Entertainment’s \u003cem\u003emassively multiplayer online first person shooter\u003c/em\u003e ’PlanetSide 2′ ever make it on to Linux? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘freemium’ game, a sequel to the popular 2003 game ‘\u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PlanetSide#Sequel\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ePlanetSide\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e‘, is currently only available for Windows.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, if one of the game’s developers is to be believe then there is hope for Linux fans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWriting on the official \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/113423196043401332805/posts/S5kkRKtHPPX\"\u003eGoogle+ \u003cem\u003ePlanetSide 2\u003c/em\u003e page\u003c/a\u003e a developer by the name of\u003cem\u003e ’blaze’\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/113423196043401332805/posts/S5kkRKtHPPX\"\u003eresponded\u003c/a\u003e to a query about Linux with this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf there’s enough of a desire for it, who knows? It’s not something we’re currently focusing on, but be sure to let us know if that would be something you’d be interested in and we’ll take it into consideration!\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDiplomatic Response\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChances are that this is nothing more than a diplomatic response. An enthusiastic but non-committal ‘maybe’ curries more favour with people than a cold rigid ‘no’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich, funnily enough, is precisely what the President of Sony Online Entertainment\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003egave Linux users back in August.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnswering the question of a Linux port via a Reddit \u003cem\u003e‘Ask me Anything’\u003c/em\u003e session, SOE’s \u003cem\u003eJohn Smedley \u003c/em\u003esaid:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘[Users] aren’t going to see PlanetSide 2 on Linux [but] will see it on Mac.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the same session \u003cem\u003eSmedley\u003c/em\u003e also reaffirmed his position on Windows 8, saying that he ‘\u003ca title\u003d\"Interview with Inside Mac Games\" href\u003d\"http://www.insidemacgames.com/news/story.php?ID\u003d21101\"\u003eabsolutely strongly\u003c/a\u003e‘ believes that the OS won’t be a good thing for PC gamers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/u/0/113423196043401332805/posts/S5kkRKtHPPX\"\u003eGoogle+\u003c/a\u003e via Robert Brown (Tips)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354809885264","timestampUsec":"1354809885264539","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/81737cd9332f0d54","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","News","canonical","jobs","multidevice"],"title":"Canonical Hunting for New ‘Head of Apps Design’",
"published":1354809742,"updated":1354809742,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/new-canonical-job-post-head-of-apps-design"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/qFi0rOXV7dQ/new-canonical-job-post-head-of-apps-design","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/canonical-logo.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"canonical-logo\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/canonical-logo.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"79\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new job listing from Canonical once again reinforces the ‘design first’ philosophy shaping the Ubuntu experience. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a newly posted role for a ‘Head of Apps Design’, Canonical are seeking a capable designer capable of ‘\u003cem\u003edelivering high-quality, value-adding, and unique apps for the Ubuntu platform\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e‘\u003c/em\u003e that \u003cem\u003e‘…address key user needs and serve as a vehicle to demonstrate Ubuntu’s values.’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExciting stuff.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe applicant will also be expected to work with 3rd party developers to ‘\u003cem\u003ecreate new apps and increase the quality of apps for Ubuntu’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo aid in this, the role will see the \u003cem\u003e‘establish[ing] app design practices and guidelines that align with SDK work and encourage good design practices for app developers’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePart of that could be eased by introducing a set of standard \u003cem\u003eHuman Interface Guidelines\u003c/em\u003e (HIG) for app developers to work to – a \u003ca title\u003d\"Canonical Seeking Designer for ‘Core Apps’, ‘HIG’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/01/canonical-job-posting-seeks-designer-for-core-apps-hig\"\u003erole Canonical were attempting to fill earlier this year.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Business’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before we get too excited by the possibilities that a consistent and coherent set of app guidelines could do for Ubuntu and its ‘form factors’, there is a pretty big clue as to the specific area to-which the ‘head of apps design’ will be focusing:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\u003cp\u003e“[Creating an] apps design strategy that connects with business strategy.”\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough ‘business strategy’ might not sound as exciting as ‘shiny new desktop apps’, it’s still possible that the remit of the role encompasses some desktops apps, such the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Software Center\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eUbuntu One,\u003c/em\u003e that are key parts of Ubuntu’s current business model’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhatever the role actually entails it’s unlikely that we will see any work resulting from it before Ubuntu 14.04 – the date at which Mark Shuttleworth expects Unity to have reached its ‘multi-platform’ goal of running on phones, tablets, desktops and TVs, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterest piqued? You can check out the job description by pushing the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://ch.tbe.taleo.net/CH03/ats/careers/requisition.jsp?org\u003dCANONICAL\u0026amp;cws\u003d1\u0026amp;rid\u003d548\" title\u003d\"head of apps design for ubuntu job posting\"\u003e Canonical ‘Head of Apps Design’ Job Listing \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dqFi0rOXV7dQ:XQJK2pqzRM0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/qFi0rOXV7dQ\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354741532225","timestampUsec":"1354741532225502","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/8eec2d02b923b3bb","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Dev","News","Video","raring ringtail"],"title":"First Wave of Minor Unity Tweaks Land in Ubuntu 13.04",

title\u003d\"Chameleonic Overlay\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/cam.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Chameleonic Overlay in Raring\" width\u003d\"100\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA number of small changes have landed on the Ubuntu desktop in the latest update to Unity.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough none of them will be causing any jaws to drop in wonderment, the small and subtle – if not yet finished – updates do fix a number of out-standing usability ‘bugs’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmongst the changes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eShortcut Overlay Badges Now Chameleonic\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFaster visual feedback when opening launcher item\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTitlebar and Glow changes to windows in Switcher\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOverlay scrollbars in the Dash\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWorkspace Switcher indication\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003eSeveral of these were already expected having been mentioned\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can see them in action in the video below:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/p3cJgadR1gk?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOut of this current crop of changes it is the ‘immediate feedback’ effect that is the hardest to see.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘original’ animation \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/893140\"\u003ewas felt to\u003c/a\u003e fade in too slowly after the initial click ‘[making] the responsiveness of the Launcher is being perceived as slow.’\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e Remember: Ubuntu 13.04 is in active development. Changes featured here are not complete or indicative of the final release, due April 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003d2T8yUJDS9t4:cANdDr57zr0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/2T8yUJDS9t4\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

"updated":1354719212,"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/google-earth-for-linux-signal-11-fix-coming?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dgoogle-earth-for-linux-signal-11-fix-coming"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/CY2Kis_2k7k/google-earth-for-linux-signal-11-fix-coming","type":"text/html"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/earth.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"google earth error\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/earth.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"200\" height\u003d\"200\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003eAn updated version of  Google Earth 7 that \u003cem\u003ewill\u003c/em\u003e work in Ubuntu is on the way.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe most recent update to the desktop app, Google Earth 7.0.1, was released in late October 2012. It brought with it an improved ‘tour guide’ feature and 3D imagery previously only available via the Android and iOS versions of the app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut for all its new features the Linux app was lacking a key one: the ability to work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCaught Signal 11\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMere minutes after its official release the Google Earth product forums were inundated with messages from frustrated Linux users unable to get the application to run.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the application is able to install fine, and displays its splash screen when opened, that’s as far as many users get. The app catches a ‘signal 11′ error and closes almost immediately after.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/googleearth.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"googleearth\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/googleearth.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"444\" height\u003d\"114\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Google Earth’s defence the application has always been a little bit rubbish on Linux, \u003ca title\u003d\"[How To] Make Google Earth 6.2 Look ‘Native’ in Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/01/how-to-make-google-earth-look-native-in-ubuntu\"\u003ethough typically only afflicted in the looks department.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompounding the frustrations of those experiencing the ‘signal 11′ issue were messages from other Ubuntu users for whom the build worked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFix Coming\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThankfully Google’s software development team have been paying attention, and I’m told that a new build that ‘fixes the issues experienced by many Linux users’ will be released ‘shortly’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo ensure that there are no issues, Google have been testing the build with a handful of Ubuntu users for the last week or so.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe new build will carry the version number 7.0.1.8283 (current build 7.0.1.8244), though if you don’t fancy checking version numbers to see if it’s released just keep an ear to this blog: we’ll let you know as soon as it’s out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor more on Google Earth visit the official web site.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp sending Anonymous e-mails\u003c/a\u003e, jumps a spot from 8th spot to #7.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBraid \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eremains a firm favourite with Ubuntu users, chalking up its 13th consecutive month inside Ubuntu’s ‘Top 10 Paid Chart’!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNovember’s other ‘new’ title, acclaimed #10.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAmensia: The Dark Descent \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003eremains Ubuntu’s best seller for a second consecutive So to sweeten the deal for the festive period Canonical are offering a free Ubuntu t-shirt, beanie, or cap with every purchase – giving you a \u003cem\u003emaximum\u003c/em\u003e saving of £10.23.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot too shabby, right?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://shop.canonical.com/product_info.php?products_id\u003d1046\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Buy Ubuntu Boombero Speaker + Free Gift \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUbuntu Office Essentials Bundle\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/office-ess.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Ubuntu Office Bundle\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/office-ess.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"200\" height\u003d\"177\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf caps and smartphone speakers aren’t your thing perhaps a new set of ‘office essentials’ are?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe bundle comprises:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Laptop Sleeve\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Mouse\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu Mouse-mat\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Ubuntu-branded laptop sleeve is available in four sizes: 10″, 13″, 15″ and 17″.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePortable USB mice truly are essentials, especially if you’re on a portable with finicky touchpad. The square, flat shape of this one might not be to everyone’s tastes, mind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, buying this bundle saves you 15% off of total it would cost you to buy these items individually.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://shop.canonical.com/product_info.php?products_id\u003d1044\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ubuntu ‘Office Essentials’ Bundle \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eUbuntu Winter Bundle\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Ubuntu warmers pack\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/winter-warmer.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Ubuntu warmers pack\" width\u003d\"200\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe last of the three bundles on offer is designed to keep you warm and cosy during the cold winter months. Oh, and save you money.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou get an Ubuntu fleece in one of 6 sizes (small through xxx-large); a modest looking beanie hat, and \u003cem\u003ethe\u003c/em\u003e definitive Ubuntu mug.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you follow us on \u003ca href\u003d\"http://youtube.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eYouTube\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href\u003d\"http://instagram.com/omgubuntu\"\u003eInstagram\u003c/a\u003e you’ll have seen us forcing it into shot on more than one occasion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://shop.canonical.com/product_info.php?products_id\u003d1045\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ubuntu ‘Winter Warmers’ Offer \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eBeware the Postage\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘drawback’ of ordering anything from the Canonical Store is the sting of postage. This can, at times, be eye-wateringly prohibitive, so be sure to factor it in to your total before demanding a bundle from Santa.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dz0VoWv-0IwE:iwYyHtOtb_Y:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/z0VoWv-0IwE\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Daily.","continuation":"CPLN8eeFwrMC","self":[{"href":"http://www.google.com/reader/api/0/stream/contents/feed/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2Ffeed?r\u003dn\u0026c\u003dCJzVoo21_rMC\u0026n\u003d40\u0026ck\u003d1361446155325\u0026client\u003dscroll"}],"alternate":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk","type":"text/html"
}],"updated":1354543860,"items":[{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354543860853","timestampUsec":"1354543860853404","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/793c637e084c1821","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","Review","racing","rc mini racers"],"title":"Hands on With ‘RC Mini Racers’ for Ubuntu [Review]","published":1354543681,"updated":1354543681,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/V9mrmhJxAJI/rc-mini-racers-ubuntu-review","type":"text/html"
}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/rc-mini-racers-ubuntu-review?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003drc-mini-racers-ubuntu-review"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e‘RC Mini Racers’ joins a procession of successful games \u003ca title\u003d\"‘RC Mini Racers’ Hits Ubuntu Software Center Lands on Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/rc-mini-racers-hits-ubuntu-software-center-lands-on-ubuntu\"\u003emaking their way to Linux and the Ubuntu Software Center. \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHaving spent several weeks at the top spot of the Mac App Store’s \u003cem\u003e‘Top Free Games’\u003c/em\u003e chart, as well as several months inside the top 10, this title offers Linux gamers another taste of the burgeoning interest in Linux as a gaming platform.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGameplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e‘RC Mini Racers’ is a game with nothing but frenetic and explosive racing between missile-toting RC cars in mind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/all_the_things.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"all_the_things\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/all_the_things.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"550\" height\u003d\"413\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe title features three racing modes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCircuit Races\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSprint Races\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCoin Racing\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCircuit races\u003c/em\u003e are the traditional checkpoint races found in other popular racing titles. You and nine AI competitors fight it out in various 5-lap tracks through backyards and over roofs from checkpoint to checkpoint.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSprint races\u003c/em\u003e take place on similar tracks, but last only a few checkpoints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the misnamed \u003cem\u003e“coin racing”\u003c/em\u003e does away with any actual racing and lets you roam free in the open, albeit small, world, collecting “coins” for in-app purchases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/racwin.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"racwin\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/racwin.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tracks wind around a single neighbourhood in various configurations with enough variety to keep you entertained every few lazy afternoons. Though tracks feature helpful arrows to guide you toward the next checkpoint, you may find yourself weaving through the wrong backyards and backtracking to find a missed checkpoint.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMoney Making \u0026amp; Truck Tweaking\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can earn money by hitting other players with well-placed mines, firing a barrage of missiles into their undercarriages, and racking up air time on the ramps and curbs scattered across the landscape.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis money can be used directly to unlock more tracks. Each of the four “circuits” in circuit and sprint racing mode have unlockable tracks for \u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEasy, Medium, Hard\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e, and\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e Insane\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/strong\u003edifficulties, with competitors getting more aggressive with each successive level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomising and buying more cars  require coins “bought” through the in-app purchasing interface or found in the coin racing mode. In-game purchases differ slightly from this title’s previous iterations on Android, iOS and OS X.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhilst this title carries a freemium model on other platforms, the $4.99 price tag in the Ubuntu Software Center does away with any actual purchases beyond the game itself and lets you trade $250,000 of in-game cash for 5 coins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCars can be customised through the \u003cem\u003e“Pimp Shop”\u003c/em\u003e with options to change wheel style, antenna colour, and body colour; however, customising the body colour alone can cost as much as 100 coins. A cool sum of 150 coins unlocks one of the cheaper vehicles available in the “Car Store”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/buying_a_car.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"buying_a_car\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/buying_a_car.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e It takes $7.5 million of in-game currency to buy enough coins to afford [a new car] \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt takes $7.5 million of in-game currency to buy enough coins to afford one of these additional vehicles. As I could only net around $75,000 at most in a single circuit race, you may find it takes a fair few plays before you can afford that hot pink RC minivan of your dreams!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, sporting the default truck with default trim doesn’t hamper the RC mayhem in the least.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHandling\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRacing feels more or less like a stripped down Mario Kart with the copious shells and power ups replaced by mines, missiles, and a turbo boost.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach new game reminds you that ‘R’ resets your vehicle – something you’ll be doing often. The vehicles are light and any explosions or collisions can send you spiralling in the air.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA “Steering Setup” mode lets you customise a vehicle if you find it too sensitive or slow to respond whilst ramming other vehicles or dodging mines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsole gamers can also use a gamepad, but I found it much easier to control the sometimes finicky vehicles with the arrow keys.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/racing.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"racing\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/racing.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGraphics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e …low resolution textures and rough models are to be expected \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe title doesn’t tout itself as the next \u003cem\u003eGran Turismo\u003c/em\u003e and the low resolution textures and rough models are to be expected. But none of this takes away from the pure pleasure of racing RC cars without the interminable need to change batteries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn a desktop with an Nvidia GTX 260 and the latest \u003ca title\u003d\"New NVIDIA Driver ‘Doubles Performance’ on Linux\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/new-nvidia-driver-doubles-performance-on-linux\"\u003eNvidia 310 drivers\u003c/a\u003e, the game runs smoothly with all the options at their highest in windowed and in fullscreen with TwinView still enabled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs always, your own mileage may vary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSound\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe in-game sound effects capture the crunch of plastic against pavement and the high-pitched squeal of an RC car’s motor. Some in-game sounds are oddly reminiscent of other popular titles – grabbing missiles, mines, or a turbo boost sounds akin to Gordon Freeman picking up health packs, whilst finishing a race is eerily reminiscent of doing the same in Mario Kart.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game’s soundtrack is understandably limited for an indie title, featuring a handful of “hard rock” tracks. If the energetic verve wears thin, music and gameplay sound can be tweaked separately for maximum aural pleasure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e‘RC Mini Racers’ is no \u003cem\u003eNeed for Speed,\u003c/em\u003e but it’s exactly what it says on the tin: a simple, fast-paced RC racing game to relive – with missile-launcher modifications – those remote-controlled days of yore.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRC Mini Racers is available to buy from the Ubuntu Software Center, on both \u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu 12.04 \u003c/strong\u003eand\u003cstrong\u003e Ubuntu 12.10\u003c/strong\u003e, for $4.99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/decane-rcminiracers/\" title\u003d\"RC Mini Racers on Ubuntu\"\u003e Buy RC Mini Racers on Ubuntu Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354477976955","timestampUsec":"1354477976955425","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/eeefd80aabb47eb2","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","Download","News","reddit","Reditr","social network apps"],"title":"Desktop Reddit App ‘Reditr’ Available for Ubuntu",
"published":1354477875,"updated":1354477875,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/03DSfCrt7h4/reditr-reddit-desktop-app-for-ubuntu-deb-download","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/12/reditr-reddit-desktop-app-for-ubuntu-deb-download?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dreditr-reddit-desktop-app-for-ubuntu-deb-download"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDesktop Reddit app\u003cem\u003e ‘Reditr’\u003c/em\u003e has been packaged up for Ubuntu and made available for download.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe application, a sort of ‘TweetDeck for Reddit’, allows Reddit fans to browse content from the popular social sharing site via a manageable, multi-column style layout.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/redot.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Reditr Main Screen in Ubuntu 12.10\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/redot.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Reditr Desktop app in Ubuntu\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the main window can look overwhelming at first all columns can be edited, or removed, and others can be added.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnly want to follow 2 or 3 sub-Reddits? You can. Want to view ‘all the Reddits’? No sweat, it can do that too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe application is more than featured. The phrase ‘everything and the kitchen sink’ comes to mind when using it. This is both good and bad.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGood because Reddit users will find virtually any/every features of the website in the app (and then some), but bad because it’s not an  instantly accessible to ‘non-Reddit’ users as it could’ve been.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the strongest ‘features’ of the application is that, unlike the website it’s based on, you never have to leave the app to view a link, picture or video. Everything can be viewed ‘in-app’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eFrom the main view you can hover over images to get a pop-up preview:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/popover.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"popover\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/popover.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClicking on a post opens it up fully, allowing you to browse comments, see linked media in better detail, and up or down-vote straight from the app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/comments.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"comments\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/comments.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor browsing image-heavy sub-reddits there’s a dedicated \u003cem\u003eGallery\u003c/em\u003e feature:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/gallery.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"gallery in /r/cats\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/gallery.jpg\" alt\u003d\"gallery in /r/cats\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther features include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNew Item Submission\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCommenting\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAuto-updating columns\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUp and down voting\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLight and dark themes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNSFW Toggle\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSadly Reditr lacks any direct Ubuntu integration. You won’t find a launcher quicklist or native notification bubbles or \u003cem\u003eMessaging Menu\u003c/em\u003e integration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReditr is as customisable as it is featured. A quick play around with the \u003cem\u003ePreferences\u003c/em\u003e section will help you tailor it just the way you want.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor a quick orientation watch this video, made by the Reditr developers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"375\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/eWzEyxSndhE?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Reditr\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReditr is a free application available to download for Ubuntu-based distributions (as well as Mac, Windows and Chrome)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo PPA is provided yet, though the developers are looking into it. Hopefully the developers will be persuaded to submit the app to the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Software Center\u003c/em\u003e, too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, for now, you’ll need to grab one of the .Deb installers from the Download section of the website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://reditr.com/#!/Download\" title\u003d\"Redtr "published":1354209625,"updated":1354209625,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/rC-c3gYaQLc/screencloud-adds-ubuntu-one-imgur-uploading","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/k5AR_r_pKfw/screencloud-adds-ubuntu-one-imgur-uploading"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eScreenshot sharing tool \u003ca title\u003d\"ScreenCloud Lets You Take, Share Ubuntu Screenshots Quickly\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/06/screencloud-lets-you-take-share-ubuntu-screenshots-quickly\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eScreencloud\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e has \u003ca title\u003d\"Screencloud 1.1.0 Updated\" href\u003d\"http://blog.screencloud.net/?p\u003d33\"\u003ebeen updated\u003c/a\u003e with Ubuntu One and Imgur uploading support.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA tray-area applet, Screencloud lets you quickly take snaps of your desktop and its applications then upload them directly to one of several supported image hosting services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/main.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"main\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/main.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"331\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘plugins’ feature adds Imgur, Ubuntu One and Dropbox uploading. These, along with a number of pre-existing options, are accessible through the app’s \u003cem\u003ePreferences\u003c/em\u003e section:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet timer delay\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnable ‘Capture window borders’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnable/Disable Notifications\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet Shortcuts\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnable Ubuntu One, Imgur \u0026amp; Dropbox plugins\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/screencloud-adds-ubuntu-one-imgur-uploading/services\" title\u003d\"Image Hosting Services in Screencloud\"\u003e\u003cimg width\u003d\"150\" height\u003d\"100\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/services.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Image Hosting Services in Screencloud\" title\u003d\"Image Hosting Services in Screencloud\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/screencloud-adds-ubuntu-one-imgur-uploading/orefer\" title\u003d\"Various Preferences in Screencloud\"\u003e\u003cimg width\u003d\"150\" height\u003d\"100\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/orefer.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Various Preferences in Screencloud\" title\u003d\"Various Preferences in Screencloud\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/screencloud-adds-ubuntu-one-imgur-uploading/shortcut11\" title\u003d\"Shortcuts\"\u003e\u003cimg width\u003d\"150\" height\u003d\"100\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/shortcut11.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Shortcuts\" title\u003d\"Shortcuts\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Screencloud Update in Ubuntu 12.04 \u0026amp; 12.10\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn old version of Screencloud is available to install through the Ubuntu Software Center. To use the new plugins you’ll need to grab the latest release, packaged up as easy-to-install .Deb files, direct from the Screencloud website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://screencloud.net/\" title\u003d\"Download Screencloud for Ubuntu\"\u003e Download ‘Screencloud 1.1.0′ for Ubuntu \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dk5AR_r_pKfw:PPch06toP4w:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg
