},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354203794605","timestampUsec":"1354203794605416","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/de4ee3c01518dea4","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","Download","lenses","scopes"],"title":"Make Ubuntu Smarter With The ‘Unity Answers Lens’",
"published":1354203215,"updated":1354203215,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/o3z2C-eAC7w/unity-lens-answers","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/unity-lens-answers?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dunity-lens-answers"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/dalek.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"dalek\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/dalek.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"400\" height\u003d\"203\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is Ubuntu? Where do Dalek’s come from? And can you cook pasta in a microwave?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t worry this is not a pop quiz, but examples of questions that I have, at various points in my life, turned to Google to get answers for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, a new Lens for Ubuntu’s Unity desktop makes finding answers to common questions insanely easy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeet the \u003cem\u003e‘Unity Answers Lens\u003c/em\u003e‘.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Lens works like this: you open the Dash, enter a question in the Dash search bar (complete with a question mark) and, if an answer can be found, it’ll appear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"image-1\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/image-1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"194\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eUnity Previews\u003c/em\u003e feature introduced in Ubuntu 12.10 lets you right-click on the answer to see further information:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-28-at-17.11.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Screen-Shot-2012-11-28-at-17.11\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-28-at-17.11.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSadly, the magic isn’t flawless. More questions I asked went unanswered than answered. And it’s not always easy to tell if an answer can’t be found as the lens displays nothing – no ‘sorry’, no ‘no results’; nothing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA \u003cem\u003e“No answer found – search on Google?”\u003c/em\u003e listing would be more user friendly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eQuery Magic\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo you can ask it questions, and it gives you answers (if it can find them). But what’s powering it? Where is it getting its answers from?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI’d like to say the \u003ca href\u003d\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akashic_records\"\u003eAkashic Records\u003c/a\u003e, but I’d be lying. Even Ubuntu developers haven’t yet managed to create an interface with theosophy!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstead the lens uses something more earthly to query for your search term and fetch its results: the \u003cem\u003eautomatton.org\u003c/em\u003e API.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe website powering the API collates its information from all over the web (Yahoo! Answers, Wikipedia, ‘What-is-what.com’, ChaCha, etc) and the ‘best scoring’ answer is returned in the Lens ready to plug you gap in knowledge.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe idea is novel, and echoes \u003ca title\u003d\"Mark Shuttleworth Explains Ubuntu’s New ‘Amazon Suggestions’ Feature\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/mark-shuttleworth-explains-ubuntus-new-amazon-adware-feature\"\u003eMark Shuttleworth’s plans for the Dash\u003c/a\u003e to become a one-stop shop for ‘finding anything, anywhere’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Unity Lens Answers in Ubuntu 12.10\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGetting the lens installed in Ubuntu 12.10 is as easy as copy and pasting the following commands into a new \u003cem\u003eTerminal \u003c/em\u003ewindow:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo add-apt-repository\u003cstrong\u003e ppa:scopes-packagers/ppa \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install unity-lens-answers\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter installing log out and back in to enable the feature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:qj6IDK7rITs\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003do3z2C-eAC7w:5OK_bixLExY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/o3z2C-eAC7w\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"

Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354134573890","timestampUsec":"1354134573890519","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4cafcd8f2d1d8286","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Dev","News","Pro User","compiz","SRU"],"title":"Compiz Fix To Bring Better Gaming Performance to Ubuntu",
"published":1354134541,"updated":1354134541,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/eEoH8Su3BvQ/compiz-fix-bringing-better-gaming-performance-to-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/compiz-fix-bringing-better-gaming-performance-to-ubuntu?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dcompiz-fix-bringing-better-gaming-performance-to-ubuntu"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAn update to Compiz that improves gaming performance is on its way to Ubuntu.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompiz 0.9.8.6, currently in preparation, enables a small feature that improves full-screen OpenGL gaming performance in Unity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the update installed, which enables ‘\u003cem\u003eUnredirect Fullscreen Windows\u003c/em\u003e‘  in Ubuntu’s default window manager by default, the developer spearheading the update, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/107379654278574464995\" rel\u003d\"author\"\u003eTimo Jyrinki\u003c/a\u003e, benchmarked a 18% increase in FPS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhich isn’t bad, at all!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut why hasn’t this been enabled before now? Timo explains that ”\u003cem\u003egetting the feature work fluently has required fixes in both Compiz and drivers\u003c/em\u003e” which, until now, haven’t been ready.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe update, which is targeted for Ubuntu 12.10 and, eventually, 12.04, will hopefully arrive in the not so distant future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the mean time those most in need of this fix – and running Ubuntu 12.10 – can install it from the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~unity-team/+archive/sru\"\u003eUnity Team SRU (Stable Release Update) PPA. \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor more details on adding that PPA, and more technical run-down of the processes behind this update, head on over to Timo’s blog by clicking the the link below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://losca.blogspot.co.uk/2012/11/game-performance-improvement-for-ubuntu.html\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003deEoH8Su3BvQ:KbJQWn_OLNg:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354133195362","timestampUsec":"1354133195362492","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/7c2b16b7fb5ec96d","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","Review","machinarium","review"],"title":"Machinarium for Linux [Review]",
"published":1354132979,"updated":1354132979,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/MMoEhnCKwc0/machinarium-for-linux-review","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/machinarium-for-linux-review?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dmachinarium-for-linux-review"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFollow the story of an atypical robot hero set out to rescue his robot-girlfriend, and in turn save the city and defeat the bad guys.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/uwZBdWRSBRs?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMachinarium, is another artfully designed puzzler from \u003ca title\u003d\"Machinarium | Amanita Design\" href\u003d\"http://amanita-design.net/games/machinarium.html\"\u003eAmanita Design\u003c/a\u003e. Like most role-playing games, you control the titular character, in this case a robot, as you guide him through the eponymous city, collecting items and solving environmental puzzles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOverview\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhilst quiet in its narrative, Machinarium is rife with plot; an unexplained bomb plot against the city, combined with an opportunistic kidnapping. Yet the game focuses on our unassuming robot friend and his simple desire to return to his absent female companion, after being accidentally dumped in the scrap yard.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/machinarium-screenshot1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMachinarium\u003c/em\u003e is notable in that it contains no written or spoken dialogue, at least not understandably so. Instead, you are guided through the game by a series of animated thought bubbles from the player’s character, and from the various characters you interact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/machinarium-screenshot3.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/machinarium-screenshot3.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGameplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt no point is Machinarium obviously straightforward, solving the puzzles does require a degree of logic. Within the game, your interaction is limited to objects within the robot’s reach, fortunately our hero is drawn to items of interest so you’re not left dragging the cursor about trying find some sign of interactivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond standing and picking up things, our robot hero has some abilities (albeit they are rather mundane): he can stretch and squish his torso and extend his arms to reach and interact with things that may be of some use to him, some of which he’ll eat for use later.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/machinarium-stretchy-robot.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/machinarium-stretchy-robot.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"200\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e If you get stuck, the game does provide some help. Each level has a use-once hint available, which becomes less useful the further you progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlternatively, beating a side-scrolling mini-game unlocks a walkthrough for the current puzzle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eLike the rest of the game, the walkthrough is not written or spoken, but is a series of sketches describing the current puzzle and how to solve it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe folks over at \u003ca title\u003d\"Amanita Design\" href\u003d\"http://amanita-design.net/\"\u003eAmanita Design\u003c/a\u003e seem to have a knack for beautiful games, and Machinarium is no exception. With the entire game being hand-drawn, it gives the dystopic Machinarium a certain whimsy, and the industrial trip-hop soundtrack is quite befitting as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re into logic-puzzle games, Machinarium is perfect -thankfully, it has built in hints for those inevitable moments of frustration. However, like most puzzle games, it’s replayability is lost when the answers are known.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFlash\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMachinarium uses Adobe Flash as it’s engine; suffice to say, there are performance issues on Linux.  Having said that, my chief problem was cursor drift within the game, which I found was solved when disabling the full-screen mode, then the game ran relatively smoothly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuy \u0026amp; Install Machinarium for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMachinarium is available for purchase in the Ubuntu Software Centre for $10.00, or you may have gotten it as part of the \u003ca title\u003d\"Humble Bundle for Android 4\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/humble-bundle-for-android-4-launches-with-5-titles\"\u003eHumble Bundle for Android 4\u003c/a\u003e lineup.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/machinarium/\" title\u003d\"Buy Machinarium for Ubuntu\"\u003e Buy Machinarium from the Ubuntu Software Centre \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eMachinarium is cross-platform; the PC version supports Linux, Mac OS, or Windows and is found on \u003ca title\u003d\"Machinarium on Steam\" href\u003d\"http://store.steampowered.com/app/40700/\"\u003eSteam\u003c/a\u003e, or if you’re into mobile: Android and iOS (limited to the iPad 2 it seems).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca },"author":"Sam Hewitt","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354125876433","timestampUsec":"1354125876433339","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/281bc42e0811accf","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Exclusive","Interview","Daniel Ryan","DevOps","Election","JuJu","Obama for America"],"title":"We Interview Daniel Ryan, Director of Front-End Development for ‘Obama for America’",
"published":1354125785,"updated":1354125785,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/LjDafB6lcgk/we-interview-daniel-ryan-director-of-front-end-development-for-obama-for-america","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/we-interview-daniel-ryan-director-of-front-end-development-for-obama-for-america"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/potus-and-dnaiel.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"potus-and-dnaiel\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/potus-and-dnaiel.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"179\" height\u003d\"269\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWith the Election in the rear-view mirror for Americans we are starting to learn about the tools, assets and people that helped President Barack Obama win re-election. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of tools that helped give Obama for America an edge was “Ubuntu” due to its cost-savings and the familiarity that members of the team had with it and how well it was supported in the cloud.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI recently had an opportunity to interview \u003cem\u003eDaniel Ryan,\u003c/em\u003e who was the Director of Front-End Development for Obama for America, and here’s what he had to say…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHi Daniel, So you lead front-end development for Obama For America (hereon ‘OFA’), Can you tell me more about this role and what it entailed?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003eSure. I led a team of two dozen developers, QA techs and support staff that produced client-side code for the campaign. Additionally I liaised with our server-side and devops teams to coordinate work between everyone.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSo there has obviously been quite a bit of buzz surrounding the news that OFA used Ubuntu can you tell me why you guys chose Ubuntu and why it was a valuable piece of the puzzle?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e ‘Ubuntu was the lowest cost route’ \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRather than me telling you what I think, I asked Scott VanDenPlas, our lead DevOps engineer, why we chose Ubuntu:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSure, it was the lowest cost route. Don’t care what we run in ops necessarily, but engineers have all used Ubuntu on desktop at least. Debian underpinnings are awesome, and we did deploy our apps via apt… \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn the end, it keeps a consistent environment for developers and makes it familiar. We always tried to get out of the way. Ubuntu also tends to be updated very aggressively, and is well integrated with ec2. The cloud-init stuff Moser worked on was very helpful early on as well.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e ‘I’ve been considering installing Ubuntu as my personal OS’ \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI see you’re quite the Pythonista! What kind of hardware do you develop on and what OS? If not Ubuntu why?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI write my code on a MacBook Air running Mountain Lion and deploy to EC2 running Ubuntu 12.04 server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI’ve been considering installing Ubuntu as my personal OS for a while, but I’ve never wanted to spend the time learning new tools to make the transition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat kinds of hobbies do you have outside of technology?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrently my biggest hobby is sleeping and sitting on a beach. It’s been quite a year and a half. My academic background is in history, so I love reading good history. I got on a big John Adams kick while at the campaign.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e ‘we’re not in a zero-sum game; everyone can share effort and reap reward.’ \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat are your thoughts on technology like \u003ca title\u003d\"Open Stack website\" href\u003d\"http://www.openstack.org/\"\u003eOpenStack\u003c/a\u003e?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s absolutely fascinating to me. Thinking of computing on a building or multi-site level is such a mind-bender. It’s great to see so many big players working together to build out standards like this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI really love the mindset behind open-source that says we’re not in a zero-sum game; everyone can share effort and reap reward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhere do you go from here now that the re-election was a success?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003eI’m considering a bunch of offers, thinking about potential start-ups, and mostly enjoying time to catch up with my family and friends. I won’t be making any big decisions before 2013.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you have any advice for aspiring developers interested in getting involved in technology within the political realm?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI was chosen by the campaign in large part because of my work in responsive design and big data visualizations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom a skills standpoint, the work that makes you stand out in any development crowd will apply to the political arena as well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGet involved with things like \u003ca title\u003d\"Code for America website\" href\u003d\"http://codeforamerica.org/\"\u003eCode for America\u003c/a\u003e. There’s a finite pool of need for devs in politics, but an infinite need for devs in civic governance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWe would like to thank Daniel Ryan and Scott VenDenPlas for taking time out of their busy schedule to do this interview with us.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLinks\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003eYou can find Daniel Ryan’s code on GitHub \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/dryan\"\u003ehttps://github.com/dryan\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cem style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003eDaniel Ryan’s Personal Website is at \u003ca href\u003d\"http://dryan.com/\"\u003ehttp://dryan.com/\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cem style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003eDaniel Ryan is also on Twitter \u003ca Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1354119107735","timestampUsec":"1354119107735875","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/d2260717e9b63b46","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","Download","News","nitro","todoapps"],"title":"To Do App ‘Nitro’ Hits Ubuntu Software Center",
"published":1354118942,"updated":1354118942,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/Dy5cn_nHX4k/nitro-task-manager-hits-ubuntu-software-center","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/nitro-task-manager-hits-ubuntu-software-center"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nitroinstore.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"nitroinstore\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nitroinstore.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"259\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe insanely handy task management app \u003ca title\u003d\"Nitro Website\" href\u003d\"http://nitrotasks.com/\"\u003eNitro\u003c/a\u003e has finally hit the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd no, you’re not misunderstanding: for despite its creation way back in April, it has taken a fair ol’ while for the application to get approved, published, and stocked on the shelves of the Software Center…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFree, Nitro is also available for OSX (via the Mac App Store) and as a web app (via the Chrome Web Store).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNitro stands out from a the deluge of other to-do/note-taking apps out there for a number of reasons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirstly, it looks \u003cem\u003egood\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTasks are divided cleanly; there’s no excessive toolbar to sort through, and all of the key features are within reach in the one window.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"new-nitro-linux-theme\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/new-nitro-linux-theme.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecondly, it has some stellar features, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSmart lists\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRecurring Tasks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMagic Sorting\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUbuntu One and Dropbox Sync\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTags and labels\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUnity integration\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThemes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Nitro in Ubuntu 12.10 \u0026amp; 12.04\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGetting Nitro in Ubuntu 12.04 and 12.10 couldn’t be easier.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust open up the Ubuntu Software Center and search for ‘nitro’. Hit the ‘Buy’ button (don’t worry, it’s a free app) and begin installation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/nitro/\" title\u003d\"Nitro on the Ubuntu Software Center\"\u003e Nitro on the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eHopefully the developers other apps, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Stormcloud app for Linux\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/linux-weather-app-stormcloud-adds-color-options-more\"\u003eStromcloud\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/em\u003eand \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/instapaper-pocket-support-added-to-linux-rss-app-lightread\"\u003eLightread\u003c/a\u003e, \u003c/em\u003ealso find their way out of the ‘backlog’ queue and land in the Software Center shortly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca "updated":1354103678,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/JJdBx01U6_4/ubuntu-powering-wii-u-demo-booths","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/ubuntu-powering-wii-u-demo-booths"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHave you played on an in-store demo unit of the Wii U recently? If so there’s a good chance you were actually playing a game on Ubuntu.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu’s aubergine splash screen was snapped mid-boot in a Wii U demo booth at a BestBuy store.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/wiiuubuntu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"wii u ubuntu booth\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/wiiuubuntu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"wii u ubuntu booth - real or fake?\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"478\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSounds strange, right? But according to one Reddit user, \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.reddit.com/user/schizm0\"\u003eschizm0\u003c/a\u003e, the Wii U demo booths in stores \u003cstrong\u003edon’t run off a Wii U console at all:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e“[It\u0026#39;s] not a genuine Wii U. Runs a port of Rayman Legends but that’s it. The computer itself is under the Wii U. Only the controller is real. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHis source? A \u003ca title\u003d\"Gamestop\" href\u003d\"http://www.gamestop.com/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGamestop\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e manager.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReal or Fake?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut how likely is this to be true?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on the experience of some who have played on these demo units, it would go someway to explaining early performance woes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e“I remember being disappointed by the Gamepad visuals on the demo stations. Everything seemed extra blurry and not very responsive unlike the actual system.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, it seems like a \u003cem\u003emighty complex effort\u003c/em\u003e to go to just for a demo unit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd porting the game from Wii U to Linux wouldn’t be a trivial – or cheap – task (though \u003cem\u003eUbisoft\u003c/em\u003e have said that they plan to bring the game in question to the PC).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Prior to General Wii-lease’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese snaps were taken before the general release of the Wii U (which, here in the UK, is still yet to happen) so this could’ve been one attempt by Nintendo to get the console out there in the hands of shoppers without the risk of a console ‘leak’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘Insert USB Key’ error on the boot screen would certainly point to a security measure being in place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUltimately, whether real, fake or not-as-currently-described, the image serves at least to stir the imagination.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBut for now it’s back to reality… \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca Today it’s arrived. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI’ll brush over repeating what we said last time suffice to say it’s a natty little racing game with enough individuality to make it worth the small $4.99 price tag.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’ll have a full review of it later this week so if the trailer below doesn’t sell you on it you can wait for our verdict (hint: we like it).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/LO3iudqmEkY?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWant to see the game on Steam? Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRC Mini Racers\u003c/em\u003e costs $4.99 but, unlike the Mac and Android versions, doesn’t contain any pesky in-app purchases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt works on both Ubuntu 12.04 and 12.10, and has relatively modest hardware requirement.s\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353866668721","timestampUsec":"1353866668721227","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/63d83ea140433bb3","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","News","decane games","racing","rc mini racers"],"title":"Hit Mac Game ‘RC Mini Racers’ Gears Up for Ubuntu Release",
"published":1353852849,"updated":1353852849,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/6vgKmbW0qs8/rc-mini-racers-ubuntu-release","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/rc-mini-racers-ubuntu-release"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHit Mac racing game ‘\u003ca title\u003d\"RC Mini Racers Website\" href\u003d\"http://www.decane.net/game/linux/rc-mini-racers/\"\u003eRC Mini Racers\u003c/a\u003e‘ is gearing up for an Ubuntu release.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe racing title has proved popular on OS X, spending several weeks at #1 in the Mac App Store’s \u003cem\u003e‘Top Free Games\u003c/em\u003e‘ chart and 5 months in the top 10.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo far the game has clocked up a cool 620,000 downloads on OS X alone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow the developers behind the game, which is \u003ca title\u003d\"RC Mini Racers on Google Play Store\" href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id\u003dnet.decane.android.rcminiracers\u0026amp;feature\u003dnav_result#?t\u003dW251bGwsMSwxLDMsIm5ldC5kZWNhbmUuYW5kcm9pZC5yY21pbmlyYWNlcnMiXQ..\"\u003ealso available on Android\u003c/a\u003e, are bringing it to Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/chart.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"MAc App Store Games Chart\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/chart.jpg\" alt\u003d\"MAc App Store Games Chart\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"116\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe game’s popularity is not without foundation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlayers can control one of 22 remote-controlled-style cars across 24 tracks split into circuit and sprint races. Missiles, mines and speed-ups can be picked up en-route for devilishly destructive duelling; and each track has its own fair share of obstacles, ramps, and challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/example22.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"example22\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/example22.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn added ‘cash incentive’ within the game rewards you for creating mayhem on the track, pandemonium for other players, and displaying elite driving skills on the track. This cash can then be covereted into coins to spend on pimping out your ride with different colours, wheels, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOptions include 4 modes of difficulty (including ‘easy’ and ‘insane’, and whilst only 3 cars are unlocked to start with, there are another 15 to unlock as you play.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/LO3iudqmEkY?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGraphically it might not be the most awe inspiring racing game you’ve ever set eyes upon, and its gameplay isn’t genre-bending or definitive. But heck, who cares? RC Mini Racers is everything its real-life equivalent is: frantic, fast-paced and fun.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePrice\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the Mac and Android versions of the game are free to download the Ubuntu version won’t be – it will cost $4.99.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before anyone kicks a RC Mini Racer over the back garden fence, there\u003cem\u003e is\u003c/em\u003e a valid reason for this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu doesn’t offer a native framework for in-game purchases, something the other platforms do. So whilst Mac and Android users can get the game for free, they need to shell out cash for more a wider selection of racing vehicles .\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith an intended\u003cstrong\u003e $4.99\u003c/strong\u003e price tag, the Ubuntu version won’t have this limitation; you unlock more cars are you advance through the game. This might sound boring but it has the effect of making the Ubuntu version feel more like a traditional racing game than the ‘\u003cem\u003elimited freemium’\u003c/em\u003e title that critics on other platforms chastise it for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhen Can I Get It?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRC Mini Racers has been submitted to the Ubuntu Software Center, so although it’s on its way it could  still be a few weeks before it’s published and ready to download.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’ll have a full review of the Ubuntu version up shortly, and we’ll be sure to give you all a poke when it’s ready for purchase.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShould the application prove popular the developer intends to not only update the game with more cars (\u003cem\u003eOMG! Ubuntu!\u003c/em\u003e branded truck anyone? ;)), but bring more of his games, including fellow #1 Mac App Store hit ’\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.decane.net/game/mac-app-store/in-the-line-of-fire/\"\u003eIn the Line of Fire\u003c/a\u003e‘ to Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.decane.net/\" title\u003d\"Decane Games Website\"\u003e Decane Games Website \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353845668039","timestampUsec":"1353845668039452","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/4bce1bc6d39c3c68","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Review","linuxmint","review"],"title":"Linux Mint 14 with Cinnamon Desktop [Review]",
"published":1353841080,"updated":1353841080,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/gOqYzEnOJCg/linux-mint-14-with-cinnamon-desktop-review","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/vt5Ewm0tdtY/linux-mint-14-with-cinnamon-desktop-review"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePerhaps the most well-known and/or notorious derivative of Ubuntu: Linux Mint, has released its fourteenth version, codenamed: “Nadia”.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePriding itself on being for “newbies” and being a power user, Linux Mint is not among my favourite Linux distributions. Nevertheless, I’ve downloaded the latest version, with their Cinnamon desktop, to give it an in-depth review.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eFirst Impressions\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUpon first login you’re greeted in familiar Linux Mint style: a single panel along the bottom -with a plethora of menus, buttons and indicators- and the usual desktop icons atop a minty wallpaper.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/01-first-impression.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/01-first-impression.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eOut-of-the-Box\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike Ubuntu, Mint comes preloaded with a wealth of pre-installed software. This includes applications like \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/gimp/\"\u003eGIMP\u003c/a\u003e \u0026amp; \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/gthumb/\"\u003eGThumb\u003c/a\u003e for graphics, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/pidgin\"\u003ePidgin\u003c/a\u003e instead of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/empathy\"\u003eEmpathy\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/banshee\"\u003eBanshee\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/mplayer\"\u003eMPlayer\u003c/a\u003e \u0026amp; \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/vlc\"\u003eVLC\u003c/a\u003e for audio and video playback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to all of this, Mint provides it’s own set of “minty” tools, which include a custom update manager \u0026amp; software centre.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMint also includes proprietary software like Adobe Flash and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/openjdk-7-jre/\"\u003eJava\u003c/a\u003e, and multimedia codecs, so you can play all your music and video and browser the web with ease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePersonally, I think the Mint team could slim down the amount of pre-installed applications as there are duplications (and triplication in the case of VLC, MPlayer and Totem) of function, which seems unnecessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eCinnamon\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCinnamon being a complete fork of Gnome Shell, has a similar experience, but it provides a more traditional desktop metaphor of a panel with menus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLook \u0026amp; Feel\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe default colour scheme in Mint relies heavily on pale greens and dark \u0026amp; light greys, which is garish at times (particularly in the file browser). Mint’s application theme appears to be a variation on elementary’s with a hybrid of green and \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/faenza-icon-set-updates-adds-new-app-icons\"\u003eFaenza\u003c/a\u003e icons throughout.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSomething that bugs me deeply is the blurriness of the panel icons and menus -could definitely use some polish.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMint Menu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/02-mint-menu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/02-mint-menu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"250\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e The Cinnamon menu is more akin to a typical application menu than say the Unity Dash or the GNOME Shell overview; it provides users access to all installed applications, places and recent files, either through the menu or via the search box.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt also has a rudimentary “dock” built in for your favourite applications \u0026amp; places, as well as to house the session buttons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe menu itself doesn’t seem to be extensible nor does it provide results from online sources (like Amazon).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eNemo\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNadia comes with the Mint developers’ fork of the Nautilus file manager -\u003cem\u003eNemo-\u003c/em\u003e installed by default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/11-nemo-home.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/11-nemo-home.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNemo returns some of the features that the Gnome developers were removing from Nautilus; bringing back features and configurability to the toolbar, like addtion of removeable “Home”, “Computer”, “Refresh” and “Up” buttons\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNemo also retains the “compact” folder layout that has been removed from the Nautilus 3.6 series.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCinnamon Panel\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe slim panel along the bottom hosts a variety of applets, from left to right: the menu, a “Show desktop” button, a favourite applications launcher, the window list, the panel settings button, the usual system indicators and a window switcher\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/mintpanel.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/mintpanel.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"32\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever my favourite of these is a recent notifications indicator, which stores what on-screen popups you may or may not have missed -something I’d personally like to see in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/03-mint-notifications.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/03-mint-notifications.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"460\" height\u003d\"219\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike Gnome Shell and Unity, Cinnamon’s panel is heavily configurable by default, allowing users to configure its size, placement and items on the panel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/06-cinnamon-settings-panel.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/06-cinnamon-settings-panel.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHot Corner\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCinnamon comes with support for one hot corner which is configured to the top left and triggers the workspace overview, which is nifty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/21-workspace-hotcorner.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/21-workspace-hotcorner.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eExtensibility\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCinnamon, like Gnome Shell, can be enhanced via what Mint calls “Spices”. Users can download these “spices’ in the form of applets for the panel as well as themes and extensions for  Cinnamon itself -accessed either directly \u003ca href\u003d\"http://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/\"\u003eonline\u003c/a\u003e or through the settings manager.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/04-cinnamon-settings-main.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/04-cinnamon-settings-main.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePerformance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThroughout my whole experience using Linux Mint 14 for this review, I was surprised at how quick Cinnamon was, even in a live boot environment. Applications (the notoriously slow aside) opened promptly and window and workspace management was a breeze.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCinnamon does have a “2D” variation for lower spec machines, but as afar as I could tell it was simply\u003cem\u003e normal\u003c/em\u003e Cinnamon with the desktop effects disabled, which one can do through the Cinnamon settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConfigurability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeing partially Gnome, Mint suffers from having two separate settings panels; the Gnome Control Panel exists in tandem with the Cinnamon settings. While it is lovely to see the level configure-ability of Cinnamon, it would be nicer if the two were concatenated somehow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/22-system-settings-cinnamon-settings.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/22-system-settings-cinnamon-settings.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eSoftware Management\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstalling Applications\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite being a spin-off of Ubuntu, Mint does not use the Ubuntu Software Centre, instead it provides its own in-built software tool, dubbed “Software Manager”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/18-software-manager3.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/18-software-manager3.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile it bears some similarities to the Ubuntu Software Centre, such as applications categories, star ratings and user-based reviews, it excels in performance launching much quicker than the USC\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMint includes the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/synaptic/\"\u003eSynaptic Package Manager\u003c/a\u003e, for more direct package management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUpdating Software in Mint\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMint’s views updates more conservatively than most; it ranks the importance of an update numerically and by colour.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/23-mint-update.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/23-mint-update.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eThe “Update Manager” presents all the info to the user, which -for a distro aimed at Linux newcomers- is arguably overwhelming. Having said that it is quite robust and its features are better suited for power users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eIn Summation\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s true that working well out-of-the-box is great for inexperienced users, but presenting them with an over-abundance of apps isn’t entirely the way to do it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCinnamon is maturing as a desktop environment but it is still rough around the edges; I’ll give it some pluses for configurability, but it needs some work in improving its user-friendliness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor power-users, the inclusion of more advanced system and package management tools, the features of the “minty” tools and the overall configurability of the system may be to their liking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerformance-wise, I was surprised; I run Ubuntu with Unity and Linux Mint with Cinnamon was noticeably faster and more responsive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile I try not to hold it against Mint for being partially responsible for the fragmentation of desktop Linux, it is a solid distribution if you’re looking for alternatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Linux Mint 14 “Nadia”\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe default edition comes with either the Cinnamon (Gnome Shell fork) desktop or the MATE (a Gnome 2 fork) desktop. Both are offered for download with or without multimedia codecs included.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsually, some times after the official release, community editions that have KDE and XFCE  by default and a Debian-based version become available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.linuxmint.com/download.php\" title\u003d\"Download Linux Mint 14\"\u003e Download Linux Mint 14 \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca The developer, ‘AndrewDB’, is working towards getting an alpha build ready though. Also, Unity doesn’t run on the hardware yet so the XFCE desktop is being used instead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut hey – everything has to start somewhere, Amazon, for example, hold ‘Black Friday’ lightening deals across all of their territories. Which is great if you like bargains, less great if you’re not a fan of your inbox being spammed by “deal e-mails”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut as this is an Ubuntu blog we’re not here to highlight the pitiful reduction in hair-tongs, feet massagers and rack roasters. href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/skype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen\"\u003eSkype for Linux Updates, Add Windows Live Login, Multi-Arch Support\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMozilla Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe latest releases of \u003cem\u003eFirefox\u003c/em\u003e web browser and \u003cem\u003eThunderbird,\u003c/em\u003e both Ubuntu’s default apps, are also ready for upgrading.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFirefox 17\u003c/strong\u003e introduces a new ‘social API’ that can be connected to Facebook Messenger, letting you see notifications, messages and chat to contacts from any website.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/facebook-firefox.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"facebook-firefox\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/facebook-firefox.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"335\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther changes introduced include sandboxed security on iFrames; ‘click to play’ warnings on out-dated plugins, and larger icons in the ‘Awesome Bar’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirefox’s e-mail sibling\u003cstrong\u003e Thunderbird \u003c/strong\u003eadds a new menu button (familiar in style to that used in Google Chrome), though its introduction doesn’t affect the \u003cem\u003eApp Menu. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/thunderbird-17.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"thunderbird-17\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/thunderbird-17.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eElsewhere there are crash fixes, performance tweaks, and a properly functioning spell check.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo download button needed to get any of these releases: just open the Update Manager/Software Updater to upgrade to them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the case of Skype you will need the Ubuntu Partner Repository enabled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/03/instant-messaging-comes-to-thunderbird-13-speed-dial-to-firefox-13\" title\u003d\"Instant Messaging Comes to Thunderbird 13, Speed-Dial to Firefox 13\"\u003eInstant Messaging Comes to Thunderbird 13, Speed-Dial to Firefox 13\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/firefox-17-arrives-with-facebook-integration-baked-in\" title\u003d\"Firefox 17 Released, Adds New Social Feature\"\u003eFirefox 17 Released, Adds New Social Feature\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/skype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen\" title\u003d\"Skype for },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353565895009","timestampUsec":"1353565895009478","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/65a72b366a9ff9c2","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Hardware","Review","dell","laptop","Sputnik"],"title":"Hands On With The Dell XPS 13 Ubuntu Laptop",
"published":1353565798,"updated":1353565798,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/rZZp5kaoSTg/hands-on-with-the-dell-sputnik-ubuntu-laptop-review","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/hands-on-with-the-dell-sputnik-ubuntu-laptop-review"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik3.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik3.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Dell Sputnik\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"281\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Sputnik is Dell’s cleverly code-named latest laptop endeavour. It’s a Dell XPS 13 Ultrabook that has a line up of hardware that Dell feels will lure developers away from competing vendors. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI spent just over a month testing out the Sputnik, having been sent a unit directly from the good folks at Dell.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd here are my thoughts…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTech Specs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLets get the specifications out of the way:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e13.3″ HD (720p) Truelife WLED Lit Display\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e2.0 GHZ i7 Intel Core2 Duo processor (E4400)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4GB Dual Channel DDR3 SDRAM at 1333MHz\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e256GB Intel SSD\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntel HD Graphics 3000\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDimensions: 0.88 x 12.56 x 9.3\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWeight: 2.99 lbs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBattery Life: Approximately 4-5 Hours during Review Testing (May vary with your use)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Dell Sputnik running Ubuntu \" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"281\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Sputnik has a clean aluminum finish wrapping its display while the bottom of the laptop is covered by a mix of brushed aluminum and carbon-fiber material. One thing that disappointed me off the bat with the Sputnik was that although the device is still not a production device,  it has a panel on the bottom with an engraved Windows logo. It is my hope this will be sorted out before they start shipping with Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong the display is a 1.3MP webcam, which blends into the black glossy frame of the display quite nicely. Another striking feature was the keys on the keyboard felt much larger than previous Dell Laptops I had used and the backlighting is a good touch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe trackpad was nice enough but I missed the individual buttons. The design seems to be consistent with what were seeing in new Ultrabook designs. The reason I prefer the individual buttons is because occasionally I would accidentally trigger a click when typing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll in all I found the design to be very polished and precise which in my opinion made it a good fit for Ubuntu 12.04 which after all was codenamed the “Precise Pangolin”.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDisplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik2.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sputnik2.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Dell Sputnik (XPS 13) running Ubuntu\" width\u003d\"503\" height\u003d\"382\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI tested the Sputnik display at my desk and on a table in my living room, which was much lower than my desk. I then altered the position of the display and noticed some washout and degradation of colors when the screen was pushed far back or brought lower than would be typically used. For my use at the desk, I absolutely enjoyed the quality of the display, considering that Dell was limited in the dimensions they could pack into the form factor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne notable feature of the display is that it uses Gorilla Glass which is touted to be one of the strongest glass displays available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSound\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Sputnik has speakers just near the front of the device and I found them to be about average for laptop speakers but nothing too impressive; not that I was expecting anything spectacular from speakers on a laptop anyway.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is Dell has purposely used hardware known to work well with ALSA (Advanced Linux Sound Architecture), which Ubuntu uses. In addition to the speakers being fully supported on Ubuntu, I ran into absolutely no issues using Input audio devices either.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNetwork\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNothing too special to mention about the networking on this device aside from the fact that an integrated wireless A/B/G/N card comes default and works out of the box with Ubuntu 12.04 LTS and it also has Bluetooth support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePorts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Sputnik has easily accessible ports to include 1 USB 3.0, 1 USB 2.0, 1 Mini DisplayPort and 1 Audio Jack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePerformance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI was thrilled by the performance of the Sputnik and although I did attempt to do some benchmarking with the Phoronix Testing Suite, I ran into some errors and decided against posting the results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat being said the i7 Core available in the Sputnik brings true world class experience. I was even able to check out Team Fortress 2 on the Sputnik using the Steam Beta and I was amazed and how well the Sputnik handled. The SSD is clearly a great perk and made for amazingly fast boot times and excellent file transfer speeds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI thoroughly believe the performance to be in the top tier of laptops that ship with Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/ubuntu-pc-sales-skyrocket-in-2011\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu PC Sales Skyrocket in 2011\"\u003eUbuntu PC Sales Skyrocket in 2011\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/06/ubuntu-adoption-grew-160-in-india-last-year\" title\u003d\"Ubuntu Adoption Grew 160% in India Last Year\"\u003eUbuntu Adoption Grew 160% in India Last Year\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/06/ubuntu-dell-laptops-go-on-sale-in-india\" "published":1353536129,"updated":1353536129,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/bivP0ZGviaU/how-to-install-the-13-04-unity-launcher-design-updates","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-install-the-13-04-unity-launcher-design-updates"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAlong with the recently covered design changes \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Updates Software Center, Update Manager Icons in 13.04\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/ubuntu-updates-software-center-update-manager-icons-in-13-04\"\u003eset to arrive in Ubuntu 13.04\u003c/a\u003e came some changes to the look of the Unity launcher.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese small updates change the shape and icon of the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/1081697\"\u003edash home button\u003c/a\u003e (colloquially termed “BFB”) and tweak the look of Unity’s \u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/1081687\"\u003elauncher tiles\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, if you’re one of those folks who just can’t wait to get the latest thing I’ve created a simple little guide for you to follow to install these new-look ‘assets’ in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow To Install New Unity Design Assests\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst you must download the modified assets, which I’ve packaged as into the following zip file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://dl.dropbox.com/u/7027392/raring-launcher-assets.zip\" title\u003d\"Launcher Design Assets\"\u003e Download New Unity Launcher Design Assets \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExtract the contents of the archive and copy (as root) all the items in the “\u003cem\u003eassets\u003c/em\u003e” folder to \u003cem\u003e“/usr/share/unity/6″ \u003c/em\u003ereplacing the existing assets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo do this via via the \u003cem\u003eTerminal\u003c/em\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ecd \u0026lt;location of download\u0026gt;/raring-design-assets/assets\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo cp -r * /usr/share/unity/6\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the changes to take effect, you need only log out then back in.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/launcher1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/launcher1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"384\" height\u003d\"273\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo undo changes or revert to default just reinstall the “unity-common” package through the Ubuntu Software Center or by running the following command:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ccode\u003esudo apt-get install --reinstall unity-common\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/07/unity-glass-offers-refined-new-look-for-the-unity-launcher\" title\u003d\"‘Unity Glass’ Offers Refined New Look for the Unity Launcher\"\u003e‘Unity Glass’ Offers Refined New Look for the Unity Launcher\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/03/how-to-easily-skin-ubuntus-unity-desktop\" title\u003d\"[How To] Easily Skin Ubuntu’s Unity Desktop\"\u003e[How To] Easily Skin Ubuntu’s Unity Desktop\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/12/how-to-customise-unity-like-never-before\" title\u003d\"[How To] Customise Unity like Never Before\"\u003e[How To] Customise Unity like Never Before\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dbivP0ZGviaU:gU2_paNXq94:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dbivP0ZGviaU:gU2_paNXq94:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca Ubuntu! writer \u003ca title\u003d\"Are Ubuntu’s Software Icons Confusing?\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/are-ubuntus-software-icons-confusing\"\u003eSam Hewitt recently noted\u003c/a\u003e, a unification between the Software Center and various ‘Software Updater’ applications was missing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis update appears to address that directly by way of a uniform update icon ‘emblem’ (an ‘A’ (presumably fo ‘Application’) with a loading bar 3/4 completed across it).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn asset attached the\u003ca href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ayatana-design/+bug/1081691\"\u003e bug update\u003c/a\u003e for the icons’ release reveals that other new icons are on the way, too. These include a revamped BFB (the Ubuntu icon in the Unity launcher); a Faenza-style Ubuntu One icon; and a cleaner Workspace Switcher item that highlights the workspace currently in use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/lew-bfb.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Unity BFB Icon Updated\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/lew-bfb.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Unity BFB Icon Updated\" width\u003d\"363\" height\u003d\"143\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu \u003ca title\u003d\"Canonical Hire ‘Faenza’ Designer to Work on New Ubuntu Icon Set\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/canonical-hire-faenza-designer-to-work-on-new-ubuntu-icon-set\"\u003erecently confirmed that Faenza icon designer Matthieu James had been hired to work\u003c/a\u003e on a new icon set for Ubuntu – are these the first fruits of his labor?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-install-the-13-04-unity-launcher-design-updates\"\u003e[How-to] Install the 13.04 Unity Launcher Design Updates\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/ubuntu-13-04-default-wallpaper-revealed\"\u003eUbuntu 13.04 Default Wallpaper Revealed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/are-ubuntus-software-icons-confusing\"\u003eAre Ubuntu’s Software Icons Confusing? GNOME-Shell theme based on the design of this very website! \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFlattery aside, the theme by DeviantArt ~\u003ca href\u003d\"http://bimsebasse.deviantart.com/\"\u003ebimsebasse\u003c/a\u003e works well on the desktop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s not overly gaudy (always a risk when the colour orange is involved), and although there’s perhaps a little too much white for some eyes to take (hence why we have ‘noise’ added to the background of the website’s body), it’s well worth trying out whether you’re an avid reader of us or not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://bimsebasse.deviantart.com/art/OMG-Ubuntu-333130114?\"\u003e\u003cimg marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAnother month, and we’re graced by another release of the \u003cem\u003eFirefox\u003c/em\u003e web browser.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow on version 17, this latest release introduces a number of new features, including a new social API, larger icons in the ‘awesome bar’ and ‘click to play’ warnings on out-dated plugins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor a full list of changes refer to \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/17.0/releasenotes/buglist.html\"\u003ethe official release notes.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSocial API\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/facebookfox.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"facebookfox\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/facebookfox.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"193\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe  new’Social API” introduced in Firefox 17 is, so far, only supported by one website: Facebook.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen enabled, it adds a ‘persistent’ notification strip to the right-hand side of the toolbar. Here you’ll get alerts to new notifications, messages etc. It also allows you to have the Facebook chat sidebar enabled on all websites you browse.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMozilla are said to be courting other popular online services, including Twitter, to add support for it, though with code and documentation readily in the open anyone is free to add support for it right now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo switch it on for Facebook head over to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.facebook.com/about/messenger-for-firefox\"\u003efacebook.com/about/messenger-for-firefox\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Firefox 17\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirefox 17 can be downloaded from the official Firefox website. Hit the link below to head over there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/new/\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download anything\u003c/strong\u003e to get this update: it will arrive via the Software Updater/Update Manager in the coming day or so.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHow’s that for
