Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353364674149","timestampUsec":"1353364674149336","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/f3110cfb4c9e18df","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","App","Download","coverart","rhythmbox"],"title":"[How To] Add a CoverArt Browser to Rhythmbox",
"published":1353364696,"updated":1353364696,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/mr5LB5cApPQ/install-cover-art-browser-for-rhythmbox","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/install-cover-art-browser-for-rhythmbox?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dinstall-cover-art-browser-for-rhythmbox"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Finstall-cover-art-browser-for-rhythmbox%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dinstall-cover-art-browser-for-rhythmbox\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLooking for a visually slick way to browse your music collection in Rhythmbox? The following \u003ca title\u003d\"Coverart Browser on GitHub\" href\u003d\"https://github.com/fossfreedom/coverart-browser\"\u003eCoverArt Browser\u003c/a\u003e plugin might be just what you’re after… \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs the plugin name implies, \u003cem\u003eCoverArt Browser \u003c/em\u003elets you browse your music collection using cover art rather than the santdard ‘text’ labels that we’re all familiar with.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/coverart.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"coverart\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/coverart.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e‘Tiled Wonder’\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis plugin has actually been around for some time. Indeed, we \u003ca title\u003d\"Old Coverart Article\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2010/02/rhythmbox-cover-art-browser\"\u003efirst wrote about it back in February 2010.\u003c/a\u003e Sadly, development on the plugin stopped around the time of Ubuntu 11.04 meaning that it couldn’t be used with later versions of Ubuntu or Rhythmbox.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStep forward developers ‘\u003cem\u003efossfreedom\u003c/em\u003e‘, and \u003cem\u003eAgustín Carrasco\u003c/em\u003e, who have resurrected the tiled-wonder from the ravages of development hell to improve upon it, add new features, and package it up for Ubuntu 12.04 and up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew Features\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe number of features now included in the plugin is extensive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs well as simply displaying a grid full of album art for browsing, you can\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDrag \u0026amp; Drop cover art on to the browser\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFetch/search for missing album art\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDisplay Album \u0026amp; Artist name under the cover\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDouble click playing of albums\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSort covers by album name and artist\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdjust cover art size\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMultiple user-configurable options to tailor what you see and use.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExamine and change properties for an album/tracks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet ‘CoverArt Browser’ to Rhythmbox’s default view\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures In Use\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the ‘CoverArt’ sidebar item is selected you are presented with a simply grid of album covers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/coverart.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"coverart\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/coverart.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eThe CoverArt browser has support for searching. Click on the magnifying glass icon in the search bar to choose any areas to search specifically, or stick with the default which searches all fields’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/search.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"search\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/search.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"320\" height\u003d\"320\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing \u003cem\u003eCtrl+Click\u003c/em\u003e you can choose multiple artists or albums at a time, then right click to queue them up in the playlist – another new feature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/mutliqueue.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"mutliqueue\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/mutliqueue.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"500\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eCovers too small? You can change their size via the Preferences dialog of the plugin:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/preferences.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"preferences\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/preferences.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"383\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/150-pixel.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"150-pixel\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/150-pixel.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eInstall CoverArt Browser for Rhythmbox in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst things first: download the plugin\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~fossfreedom/+archive/rhythmbox-plugins/+files/rhythmbox-plugin-coverart-browser_0.5-1ubuntu2_all.deb\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download Coverart Browser for Ubuntu 12.10 \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce the plugin has finished downloading open your file browser and navigate to your \u003cem\u003eDownloads\u003c/em\u003e folder. Inside here find the ‘r\u003cem\u003ehythmbox-plugin-coverart-browser.deb\u003c/em\u003e‘ file and double-click on it to begin installation via the Ubuntu Software Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter installing has finished up open Rhythmbox (be sure to fully exit it first if it is already running), then mouse over the Top Panel in Ubuntu to reveal the App Menu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGo to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEdit \u0026gt; Plugins\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the ‘Configure Plugins’ window that opens check the box next to the \u003cem\u003e‘CoverArt Browser’\u003c/em\u003e entry to enable it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you need to access the \u003cem\u003ePreferences\u003c/em\u003e for the plugin at any time simply return to this window, select the \u003cem\u003eCoverArt Browser\u003c/em\u003e plugin and click the ‘\u003cem\u003ePreferences\u003c/em\u003e‘ button towards the bottom of the window.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2010/02/rhythmbox-cover-art-browser\"\u003eRhythmbox Cover Art Browser\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/08/webmenu-adds-handy-web-links-to-rhythmbox\"\u003e‘WebMenu’ Adds Handy Web Links to Rhythmbox\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dmr5LB5cApPQ:yD-NnRiaS6k:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg "published":1353348917,"updated":1353348917,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/MbfNOU-91uE/system76-unviel-17-extreme-gaming-laptop","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/system76-unviel-17-extreme-gaming-laptop?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dsystem76-unviel-17-extreme-gaming-laptop"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fsystem76-unviel-17-extreme-gaming-laptop%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dsystem76-unviel-17-extreme-gaming-laptop\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu hardware re-sellers \u003cem\u003eSystem76\u003c/em\u003e have today unveiled their product: the \u003cem\u003eBonobo Extreme\u003c/em\u003e laptop.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eAnd when they say\u003cem\u003e ’extreme’\u003c/em\u003e they mean it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSystem76′s CEO and Founder, \u003cem\u003eCarl Richell\u003c/em\u003e, boasts that the Bonobo Extreme is the \u003cem\u003e‘world’s fastest Ubuntu laptop’, \u003c/em\u003eciting Steam’s impending Linux arrival as reason for launching a \u003cem\u003e‘new benchmark in gaming performance’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eThe\u003cem\u003e Bonobo Extreme\u003c/em\u003e follows on from Octobers \u003ca title\u003d\"Meet The $799 All-in-One Ubuntu PC from System76\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/meet-the-799-all-in-one-ubuntu-pc-from-system76\"\u003elaunch of the first Ubuntu all-in-one PC\u003c/a\u003e, the Sable Complete.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"bonobo-extreme\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/bonobo-extreme.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSpecifications\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe laptop boasts a gargantuan, full-HD \u003cstrong\u003e17.3″ backlit display\u003c/strong\u003e - so not only will your games look fantastic but so will everything else.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe stock CPU is an \u003cstrong\u003eIntel i7 @ 2.6Ghz\u003c/strong\u003e (Quad core) but upgrade options can see bumped up to a i7-3940XM Extreme Processor @ 3.00GHz for another $530 or so.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe big sell of the Extreme to gamers will be the inclusion of a \u003cstrong\u003ededicated GPU \u003c/strong\u003eunder the hood. The base model sports a \u003cstrong\u003enVidia Geforce GTX 670MX\u003c/strong\u003e with 3GB of DDR5 RAM and 960 CUDA Cores. Not enough juice for you? You can upgrade to a Geforce GTX 680M with 4GB of DDR5 memory and 1344 CUDA cores for $134 more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA full-sized \u003cstrong\u003ebacklit keyboard\u003c/strong\u003e and a large clickpad with rubberized palm rests means whether day or night, working or playing you’re sure to have a comfortable experience using it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough, with those internals, I probably wouldn’t keep it on your lap ;)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"keyboard\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/keyboard.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWeight\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf there’s one drawback (that is inevitable in all ‘extreme’ laptops of this ilk) it’s weight.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt 8.60lbs/3.90 kg you won’t be throwing this one into your rucksack for a trip to the local café. This device is huge, thick and weighty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut you know what? That’s okay with me. Laptops like this should put power before beauty; choose raw performance over superfluous additions; and see usefulness win out against design-first trade-offs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs an added bonus, System76 even provide a free clamshell case with this model.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSpecifications in full (base model)\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e17.3″ Backlit Display with Glossy Surface ( 1920 x 1080 )\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntel i7 3630QM Processor clocked @ 2.40GHz (Quad core + hyper threading)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e8GB DDR3 RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e500 GB 7200 RPM HDD\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003enVidia Geforce GTX 670MX 3GB\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDVD Drive\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e8 Cell Battery\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePorts include\u003c/strong\u003e 5 x USBs (incl. USB 3.0); ethernet, card reader, the usual perforation of audio holes, and a Kensington lock. HDMI and Display Port outs are also included should you want to hook this beast up to another screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePrice and Availability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Bonobo Extreme, on paper at least, makes a great desktop replacement. But the price of portable performance is high, and the Extreme lives up to its name in yet another area: it \u003cstrong\u003ecosts $1499.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd that’s at $100 off as part of the System 76 xmas promotion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHead on over to the System76 xmas-themed website to check out full details on the laptop, as well as see offers on their other hardware.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.system76.com/laptops/model/bonx6\" title\u003d\"Buy Bonobo Extreme Laptop from System 76 src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dqj6IDK7rITs\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMbfNOU-91uE:XReuP7GF0yc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dMbfNOU-91uE:XReuP7GF0yc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMbfNOU-91uE:XReuP7GF0yc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dMbfNOU-91uE:XReuP7GF0yc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dMbfNOU-91uE:XReuP7GF0yc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/MbfNOU-91uE\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353266795156","timestampUsec":"1353266795156401","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/384ec7456b935ba4","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","How To","News","netflix"],"title":"[How To] Watch Netflix on Ubuntu","published":1353266550,
"updated":1353266550,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/fl-9cKnnnmc/how-to-use-netflix-on-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-use-netflix-on-ubuntu?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dhow-to-use-netflix-on-ubuntu"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fhow-to-use-netflix-on-ubuntu%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dhow-to-use-netflix-on-ubuntu\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"netflix1\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNetflix is up and running on Ubuntu – albeit unofficially, and via the familiar crutch of WINE. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeveloper \u003ca href\u003d\"https://plus.google.com/104121159376596045935/posts\"\u003eErich Hoover,\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.iheartubuntu.com/2012/11/ppa-for-netflix-desktop-app.html\"\u003eUbuntu blogger David Andrews\u003c/a\u003e have worked together to bring the worlds most popular movie streaming service \u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.iheartubuntu.com/2012/11/netflix-on-ubuntu-is-here.html\"\u003eto the Linux desktop.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe service has, until now, been confined to Windows, OS X, ChromeOS, Android and iOS platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut by bundling together a Windows build of \u003cem\u003eFirefox\u003c/em\u003e, the Microsoft Silverlight plugin required by Netflix, and adding some additional vital tweaks to make things work properly, these two developers have created a standalone ‘desktop app’ for Ubuntu that finally lets Linux-using Netflix subscribers play back movies and tv shows on their OS of choice.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut will there ever be official support?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the last year or so we have spoken to Netflix on numerous occasions to try and find out whether they have plans to \u003cem\u003eofficially\u003c/em\u003e provide Linux users with their service. Despite \u003ca title\u003d\"Native Netflix Client Coming to Linux ‘In The Next 12 Months’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2011/10/native-netflix-client-coming-linux-in-12-months\"\u003ea heartening promises now and then\u003c/a\u003e, the answer has always \u003ca title\u003d\"Netflix: ‘No Change in our plans for Linux’\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/netflix-no-change-in-our-plans-for-linux\"\u003eturned out to be a firm, resolute ‘no’\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTheir loss.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Netflix Desktop in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Linux community is nothing if not resourceful. If there’s something we don’t have or can’t use we find a way around it. And thus \u003cem\u003eNetflix Desktop\u003c/em\u003e was born.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install the app bundle you will first need to add the following PPA. Bear in mind that as this is not officially supported by Netflix, WINE or Silverlight, you add it at your own risk.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a new Terminal window enter:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-add-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:ehoover/compholio\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install netflix-desktop\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo launch the application open the Unity Dash and search for \u003cem\u003e‘netflix’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"netflix\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"191\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUsing Netflix Desktop in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen first launching the application a number of small prompts will appear asking you to install a few extra pieces that are required to get the app up and running. Agree to  all of these, then, once finished, re-launch the Netflix Desktop app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe application should launch fullscreen. Login to your Netflix account to be taken to the library. When you attempt to first play a title you will get another prompt – this time a Silverlight DRM one:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netfloox.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"netfloox\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netfloox.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou \u003cstrong\u003ehave to agree\u003c/strong\u003e to enable playback of restricted content inorder to use Netflix on Linux.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce done your programme or film will begin playing back fullscreen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix11.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"netflix11\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix11.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"281\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ‘app’ itself is actually nothing more than Firefox, so to exit the full-screen mode just tap F11.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"netflix1\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/netflix1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNetflix Linux Performance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOkay, now for the drawbacks. Playback performance may vary from’okay’ to  ’just acceptable’ to ‘frustratingly woeful’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor me, on an Intel i5 Quad Core @ 2.6Ghz, with 8GB of RAM, performance was, at best, passable. There were plenty of skips, lags, sync-issues and crashes to entertain me when the content wasn’t.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that others have reported much better success – even on more modest single-core hardware. So the rule here is to \u003cstrong\u003etry it out for yourself.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t forget that to use Netflix you do need to have an active account, or details on hand to sign up for a free month’s trial.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.iheartubuntu.com/2012/11/netflix-on-ubuntu-is-here.html\"\u003eiheartubuntu\u003c/a\u003e via \u003cstrong\u003eMichael T \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca Linux\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfl-9cKnnnmc:PXL7sp4Epdc:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfl-9cKnnnmc:PXL7sp4Epdc:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfl-9cKnnnmc:PXL7sp4Epdc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfl-9cKnnnmc:PXL7sp4Epdc:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfl-9cKnnnmc:PXL7sp4Epdc:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353076484254","timestampUsec":"1353076484254127","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/2990912cc6efb7db","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","How To","News","spotify"],"title":"[How To] Test Spotify’s New Web Player","published":1353075997,
"updated":1353075997,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/wNId7UuFaQ4/how-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dhow-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fhow-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dhow-to-test-spotifys-new-web-player\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpotify have launched a new web-based player for streaming music from their library.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough in beta the web-player puts 18 million tracks at your fingertips regardless of what OS or device you are using.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUntil now Spotify has only been available via dedicated desktop and mobile apps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the web player in beta you’d forgive it for having missing features or broken functionality, but – and here’s the good news – I’m yet to come across either. It feels like a finished product withthea beta label accidentally left on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBetter still, the interface is gorgeous; the look of the web player is more pleasing on the eyes than the dedicated desktop player.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"spotify-web\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/spotify-web.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s also very fluid; tracks play/pause instantly on my connection, and there’s no lag when switching between the various views. Even Flash, which is used to ‘stream’ the tracks, doesn’t seem to play up as much as it does with other music-streaming sites.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShuffle and looping are present; artwork is there; and every artists I searched for (that I know is available through the desktop app in the UK) was online ready for streaming.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/search.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"search\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/search.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"403\" height\u003d\"518\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOh, and did I mention that it works with free accounts?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhy Web and Why Now?\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA native ‘preview’ build of \u003cem\u003eSpotify for Linux\u003c/em\u003e has been available for a few years, but development on it is slow. This has, understandably, frustrated Linux users who use the service, many of whom pay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo does Spotify’s move to the web mean the end of a Linux client altogether?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/spotify-for-linux.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"spotify for linux client\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/spotify-for-linux-500x284.jpg\" alt\u003d\"spotify for linux preview\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"283\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnly Spotify’s developers can answer that, but it would certainly make sense to take already limited resources away from the Linux desktop client and put them into creating a unified and flawless online experience for all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact one is slightly bemused that Spotify didn’t do this sooner. It’s a logical move. As a ‘cloud service’ access is crucial: the more people who can access your service the more money you are going to make. And what’s more accessible than a web browser?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that this feature is happening now, because, super-sized catalog or not, rival services are gaining momentum.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eGoogle\u003c/em\u003e offers anyone with a Google account ‘anywhere’ access to 20,000 of their own tracks (plus ones bought via their service), which can be played back via mobile apps and the web; \u003cem\u003eAmazon, Sony,\u003c/em\u003e and Microsoft’s\u003cem\u003e Xbox Music\u003c/em\u003e are already au fait with the streaming-schtick; and the juggernaut that is \u003cem\u003eiTunes\u003c/em\u003e is rumoured to be going ‘cloud’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpotify has to keep on its toes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAccessing the Spotify Web Beta\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo access the beta of Spotify’s web player you will need to click on the following ‘invite’ link below. If you don’t click this link and go straight to the \u003cem\u003eplay.spotify.com\u003c/em\u003e website you might only see the bog-standard mobile site.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://t.co/t9qQ9lAU\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Spotify Web Player Beta \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eIf you go via the link then, through the powers of cookies, you’ll have access. Just login with your Spotify or Facebook account and you’ll be good to go.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eDon’t forget that you will need to have Adobe’s Flash player installed to use it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThanks to Paul F.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/06/how-to-fix-spotify-repo-key-change-error\"\u003e[How To] Fix Spotify Repo Key Change Error\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/05/spotify-for-linux-adds-tumblr-sharing-playlist-radio-streams\"\u003eSpotify For Linux Adds Tumblr Sharing, Playlist Radio Streams\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/03/spotify-launches-in-germany\"\u003eSpotify Launches in Germany\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwNId7UuFaQ4:hwzLklPCPzo:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dwNId7UuFaQ4:hwzLklPCPzo:wBxX2hOkimM\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dwNId7UuFaQ4:hwzLklPCPzo:I9og5sOYxJI\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dI9og5sOYxJI\" },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1353011473229","timestampUsec":"1353011473229479","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/e4d66cd0beeabc1c","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Gaming","Review","android","humblebundle","splice"],"title":"Splice: Sudoku in a Petri Dish",
"published":1353011387,"updated":1353011387,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/4HlCd6pi3uA/splice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/splice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dsplice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fsplice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dsplice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you’re not too germophobic or if you like playing God at the microcosmic level, then you’ll enjoy this microbial puzzle-game.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndie game developer \u003cem\u003eCipher Prime Studios\u003c/em\u003e, bring players into the world of the microscopic. Splice requires players to pull-apart and reconstruct increasingly complex strands of microbes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/f4Sw0lbqV9w?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo complete the experience, players are graced with an ethereal soundtrack and minimal, yet impressive graphics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/splice-screenshot-title.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/splice-screenshot-title.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGameplay\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003ethe initial experience of the game is slightly confusing… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince Splice provides no instruction, on ‘how to play’ or what to do, the initial experience of the game is slightly confusing, but once you get past that first 10 minutes of “what the heck am I supposed to be doing?” the game becomes quite engaging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn each sequence (pun intended), players are presented with a strand of microorganisms that must be rearranged into a given shape.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first few stages of the game involve simpler puzzles and only a single type of microbe, but as the game progressed they increase in complexity and diversity, gaining special characteristics or properties to either aid the player and increase the problems difficulty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/splice-screenshot1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/splice-screenshot1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite a seemingly straightforward concept, you cannot simply drag and drop bits around and hope for an easy victory; players are given a set number of splices, and once used up, you’re done, however Splice has a lovely fast-forward \u0026amp; rewind functionality help get past frustration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe puzzles involve, sometimes complex, forethought and trial-and-error. It would be nice if the game had an option to skip the trickier obstacles, adding this to it’s simple interface, makes Splice quite unforgiving to it’s players.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSummary\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003eSplice is addictive and frustrating at the same time… \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI found Splice to be both incredibly addictive and frustrating at the same time; the puzzles were just challenging enough to keep me engaged but every once in awhile a really difficult one arises. The game’s soundtrack and aesthetic are just incredible, albeit the minimalism is not for everyone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSplice I would recommend to the ardent puzzlers -the sudoku-playing, crossword-doing folks- and coming in at a nice price point (depending on the platform) it’s a thoroughly entertaining game.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuy \u0026amp; Install Splice for Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSplice can be found, at a reasonable $9.99 in the Ubuntu Software Centre, or featured as part of the latest \u003ca title\u003d\"Humble Bundle for Android 4\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/humble-bundle-for-android-4-launches-with-5-titles\"\u003eHumble Indie Bundle\u003c/a\u003e lineup.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://apps.ubuntu.com/cat/applications/splice/\" title\u003d\"Buy Splice from the Ubuntu Software Center\"\u003e Buy Splice from the Ubuntu Software Center \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSplice, like most games featured in a Humble Bundle, is cross-platform: players will find Splice available to purchase/download for Linux, Mac OS, or Windows; or for Android and iOS; or on Steam (though sadly not on the \u003ca title\u003d\"‘Steam for Linux’ Beta Released\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/steam-for-linux-launches\"\u003eLinux Beta\u003c/a\u003e, yet).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated "content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2F5-nuvola-tweaks-for-an-awesome-google-play-music-experience-in-ubuntu%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3D5-nuvola-tweaks-for-an-awesome-google-play-music-experience-in-ubuntu\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nuvola.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"nuvola\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nuvola.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you live in one the \u003ca title\u003d\"Google Play Music Arrives in Europe, Here’s How to Use it in Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu\"\u003eever-growing list\u003c/a\u003e of countries where \u003cem\u003eGoogle Play Music\u003c/em\u003e is now available you might be using the neat desktop music app ‘\u003ca title\u003d\"Google Play Music Arrives in Europe, Here’s How to Use it in Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu\"\u003eNuvola\u003c/a\u003e‘ to access and playback your music.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNuvola Player is a nifty app – and not limited to Google Play Music, either – but some of its best features aren’t enabled by default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut by following our list of five top tips you can tweak it to look and work as best as it can in Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Enable HTML5 Audio\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"html5\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/html5.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"82\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first thing I advise anyone using Google Play Music (whether in a browser or an app like Nuvola) is to enable HTML5 Audio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhy would you want to do this? Firstly, the Flash version of\u003cem\u003e Google Play Music\u003c/em\u003e is pretty crashy in Ubuntu so for a stable experience, consistent playback, and lower blood pressure, switching is more than worth it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecondly, Flash playback \u003ca title\u003d\"HTML 5 Audio in Google Play Music Uses Less Resources than Flash\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgchrome.com/enable-html5-in-google-play-music-for-a-faster-experience/\"\u003euses more resources than the HTML 5 version.\u003c/a\u003e If you’re on a portable device this means your battery will deplete quicker.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow to Switch to HTML 5 Audio in Google Play Music\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick the ‘cog’ icon in the Google Bar (next to your account avatar)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChoose \u003cem\u003e‘Music Labs’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eScroll down the experiments to find\u003cem\u003e ‘HTML 5 Audio’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnable it by clicking the dot next to \u003cem\u003e‘Enabled’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Turn On Sound Menu Integration\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"sound-menu\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sound-menu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntegration with the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Sound Menu\u003c/em\u003e is a key feature for any music player these-days. Annoyingly \u003cem\u003eNuvola\u003c/em\u003e doesn’t enable it out of the box, so you’ll need to switch it on yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow to Enable Sound Menu Support in Nuvola Player\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHover over the top panel to reveal the App Menu\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick through \u003cem\u003eService \u0026gt; Preferences\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the window that appears choose the \u003cem\u003eExtensions\u003c/em\u003e tab\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCheck the box next to \u003cem\u003e‘Remote Player Interface’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Declutter the Interface\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Toolbars in nuvola\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/ss.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Toolbars in nuvola\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"246\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe default look of \u003cem\u003eGoogle Play Music\u003c/em\u003e shows 3 toolbars by default. There’s the main application toolbar (labelled in the screenshot above), the Google Bar (also labelled) and Google Play Music displays player controls and track information at the bottom of the window.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChances are you won’t want all of these cluttering up your screen, so let’s streamline the interface by disabling the \u003cem\u003eGoogle Bar\u003c/em\u003e and the \u003cem\u003eTool Bar. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo disable the ‘tool bar’\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMouse over the top panel until the \u003cem\u003eApp Menu\u003c/em\u003e is displayed\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSelect \u003cem\u003eView\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick ‘Only Menubar’\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/only-menubar.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"only-menubar\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/only-menubar.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"304\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo Disable Google Bar\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHover over the top panel to reveal the App Menu\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick through \u003cem\u003eService \u0026gt; Preferences\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the window that appears choose the \u003cem\u003eServices\u003c/em\u003e tab\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCheck the box next to \u003cem\u003e‘Hide Google bar’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe result:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/after.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"after\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/after.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"246\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Set Up Last.FM Scrobbling\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMusic stat hound? Me too! I’ve been using Last.FM for several years and no matter the platform or app I’m using scrobbling is one of the first thing I set up.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNuvola comes with a Last.FM Plugin built in. To enable it:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHover over the top panel to reveal the App Menu\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick through \u003cem\u003eService \u0026gt; Preferences\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the window that appears choose the \u003cem\u003eExtensions\u003c/em\u003e tab\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCheck the box next to \u003cem\u003e‘LastFM’ \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWith LastFM selected, press the ‘Preferences’ button on the right\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick on the \u003cem\u003e‘authorize’\u003c/em\u003e and Last.fm will open in your browser\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLogin to last fm and authorise access\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReturn to Nuvola and hit the\u003cem\u003e ‘complete’\u003c/em\u003e button\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/laT.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Last FM in Nuvola\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/laT.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Last FM in Nuvola\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"454\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Extra Unity Fun: Quicklists \u0026amp; Notifications\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNuvola supports two other Unity desktop features – native notifications and Unity Launcher quicklists. But much like the Sound Menu (see tip 2 above) these are not enabled by default.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo enable them just check the ‘Notifications’ and ‘Unity Quicklist’ options in the extensions window and you’ll be all set!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/unity-features.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"unity-features\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/unity-features.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDo you have any Nuvola tips for Google Play Music or any of its other supported services? Share them in the comments below.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fzareasons-ubuntu-all-in-one-pc-might-look-a-little-familiar%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dzareasons-ubuntu-all-in-one-pc-might-look-a-little-familiar\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLinux hardware re-sellers ZaReason have debuted their ‘Zimo 930′ PC – an all-in-one desktop computer that has more than a whiff of familiarity about it.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Zimo 930 is a good looking, well-specc’d PC but it’s had its thunder stolen by last months launch of the \u003ca title\u003d\"Meet The $799 All-in-One Ubuntu PC from System76\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/meet-the-799-all-in-one-ubuntu-pc-from-system76\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSystem76 Sable.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd I don’t mean because both are ‘all-in-ones’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee, both devices look pretty much identical because they are both using the same “shell”, albeit with different logos on the front. And although the visual similarity isn’t a drawback of itself (hey – it’s  good looking computer) the specifications of the Zimo don’t stray too far from that offered by the Sable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/zimo1.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"zimo1\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/zimo1.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"400\" height\u003d\"536\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth have 21.5″ screens, Intel Graphics, 4GB of RAM, and an Intel i5 CPU.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo stand out a little the Zimo has a marginally more powerful processor (a quad-core \u003cstrong\u003e3.1Ghz i5\u003c/strong\u003e to the Sable’s quad-core 2.9Ghz i5); a 64GB SSD in place of a mechanical hard-drive; and a few extra ports.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt also includes WiFi as standard – something the System76 Sable doesn’t – and a lighter-coloured rear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUpgrade options include bumping the CPU up from an i5 to an i7, adding a second hard drive, and selecting a CD/DVD drive for inclusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpecifications:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e21.5″ HD Display (1920 x 1080)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntel i5 3570s @ 3.1 – 3.8 GHz\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4GB DDR3 RAM\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e64GB SSD\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntel HD Graphics\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePorts:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEthernet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e4x USB 3.0\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e2x USB\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHDMI Out\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDisplay Port\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAudio/Mic jacks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSD Card Reeader\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePrice\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerhaps the most apparent difference between the two is in the pricing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePricing for the Zimo \u003cstrong\u003estarts at $899\u003c/strong\u003e – $100 more than the ‘base model’ of the System 76 Sable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdmittedly you are getting some extras for that extra $100, and configuring the System76 to match the specs of the Zimo comes out at $882 – so it’s around the right price.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor more information on the Zimo 930 from ZaReason, or to buy, hit the button below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://zareason.com/shop/zima-930.html\" title\u003d\"ZaReason All in One PC\"\u003e Zima 930 All in One Ubuntu PC \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp "published":1352978531,"updated":1352978531,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/VZ_cpqJ9cZA/skype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/skype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dskype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fskype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dskype-for-linux-adds-windows-live-login-fresh-login-screen\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMicrosoft have released an updated version of Skype for Linux.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSkype 4.1 brings a new look login screen with support for Windows Live login.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/skype-4-1-for-linux.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"skype 4.1 for Linux\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/skype-4-1-for-linux.jpg\" alt\u003d\"skype 4.1 running in Ubuntu\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis latter feature is useful for two reasons: firstly it means you no longer need to sign up for a dedicated Skype account, but secondly it allows you to chat to your Windows Live contacts from the app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMicrosoft are shutting down their Windows Live chat network early next year, so this option has a purpose: to get people using the ‘recommended alternative’ as soon as possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"sign-in-\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/sign-in-.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you login with a Windows Live account you’ll be prompted to ‘merge’ it with your Skype account. A useful touch, but not vital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI opted to merge, but as it’s been such a long, long time since I used my Windows Live account I can’t tell whether it was successful; I still only see my Skype contacts listed and no-one else.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e64bit Friendly\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterestingly, the Skype website lists the Ubuntu 12.04 download as being ‘multi-arch’. This (theoretically) means that 64bit users can install the app using the same installer as 32bit users – without the need to jump through dependency hoops.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn practice it’s not entirely flawless. For example, I noticed that installing the package on 64bit Ubuntu doesn’t enable the tray icon despite the sni-qt package (used to display it) being installed. On 32bit it appears without problem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstall Skype 4.1 in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirstly I recommend that you fully remove any existing Skype install before beginning the upgrade. This will prevent any conflicts or errors appearing along the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext, download the installer file linked to the button below. It’s one package but works for both 32bit and 64bit Ubuntu users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.skype.com/go/getskype-linux-ubuntu-64\" title\u003d\"download skype 4.1 for linux\"\u003e Download Skype 4.1 for Ubuntu \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen it’s fully downloaded locate it in your file browser, then double click on the package to begin installation via the Ubuntu Software Center. Once install has completed open the Unity Dash and search for ‘Skype’.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLooking to better integrate Skype with the Ubuntu desktop? \u003ca marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUbuntu gamers wanting to get right to action with Steam can now do so straight from the login screen.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Steam Login for Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"https://github.com/thor27/steam-login/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSteam-login\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e runs nothing but Steam’s \u003cem\u003eBig Picture Mode.\u003c/em\u003e No fuss, no frills, just \u003cem\u003eSteam.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/steam-login.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"steam-login\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/steam-login.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"430\" height\u003d\"283\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt uses the lightweight \u003cem\u003exfwm4\u003c/em\u003e window manager powering the session behind the scenes. The result is less over-head on your hardware, leaving more juice for Steam to take advantage of.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe purpose of the session is solely to run Steam.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/big-screen-mode.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"big-screen-mode\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/big-screen-mode.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSteam-login \u003cstrong\u003eis not an official feature\u003c/strong\u003e of the \u003cem\u003eSteam for Linux beta \u003c/em\u003ebut a third party hack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003eThat doesn’t mean that it isn’t worth installing – if you’re a gamer it most certainly is.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNotes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo exit the Steam session you need to press the “S\u003cem\u003eteam”\u003c/em\u003e button followed by “\u003cem\u003eExit”.\u003c/em\u003e Pressing the close button will only minimize the window.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn to installing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re an official beta tester for Steam for Linux download and install the following .deb package.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/thor27/steam-login/blob/master/steam-login_3_all.deb?raw\u003dtrue\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Steam Login for Ubuntu (for official testers) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you do not have \u003cem\u003eofficial access\u003c/em\u003e to the beta you will need to install the ‘hacked’ version below. Note that some features/functions within Big Picture Mode may not be enabled or available to you.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/thor27/steam-login/blob/master/steam-login-hacked_3_all.deb?raw\u003dtrue\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Steam Login for Ubuntu (for non-testers) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eOnce you’ve installed (and assuming Steam is already set up with your account) you can log out, go to the session selector, click ‘Steam’, followed by ‘OK’, and then login.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eTo remove steam-login at a later date open the \u003cem\u003eUbuntu Software Center\u003c/em\u003e and search for ‘steam-login’, followed by \u003cem\u003e‘Remove’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eSteam in Action\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurious to see what Steam for Linux is like in action? },"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1352804987275","timestampUsec":"1352804987275173","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/107cda6db9b5fe30","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","How To","News","google","google play","nuvola"],"title":"Google Play Music Arrives in Europe, Here’s How to Use it in Ubuntu",
"published":1352804905,"updated":1352804905,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/FyxClszlIOc/how-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dhow-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fhow-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dhow-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGoogle’s online music service ‘\u003cem\u003eGoogle Play Music\u003c/em\u003e‘ has officially launched in select European countries, having been restricted to America for the last year or so.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re in the \u003cstrong\u003eUK, France, Germany, Italy or Spain\u003c/strong\u003e you can now buy legal music downloads from the some of the worlds biggest record labels straight from Google.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut there’s an extra feature on offer that makes Google Play Music stand out from competitors such as iTunes and 7Digital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUp-to 20,000 tracks can be uploaded from your hard-drive and into the cloud. These can then be ‘streamed’ back on any device with an internet connection, using a browser or a dedicated app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe official\u003cem\u003e Google Music Android\u003c/em\u003e app even lets you keep tracks, albums or artists of your choosing for playback offline.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/NCmJ-hie0H4?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSigning Up for Google Play Music\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAssuming you have a Google account signing up for Google Music is as easy as going to \u003ca href\u003d\"https://play.google.com/store/music\"\u003eplay.google.com/store/music\u003c/a\u003e and hitting the ‘\u003cem\u003eGet Started\u003c/em\u003e‘ button.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow for the “meh” bit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt this point Google \u003cem\u003emay\u003c/em\u003e ask you to ‘verify your country of residence’. To do this you’ll need to add a credit or credit card to Google Wallet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYes, the worlds largest internet company seem to think they can’t identify where you live without it…\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload Google Music Manager\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAssuming you complete the set-up the next step is to download Google’s \u003cstrong\u003eMusic Manager\u003c/strong\u003e application. This tool lets you set-up which music folders you want uploaded.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike some other Google products this one is even available for Linux users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://dl.google.com/linux/direct/google-musicmanager-beta_current_i386.deb\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Google Music Manager (32bit .deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://dl.google.com/linux/direct/google-musicmanager-beta_current_amd64.deb\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Google Music Manager (64bit .deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo install Google’s Music Manager just double-click on the\u003cem\u003e .deb\u003c/em\u003e file you downloaded and follow the prompts. Once done, open the Dash, search for \u003cem\u003eMusic Manager,\u003c/em\u003e and open it to get started.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/launcher.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"launcher\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/launcher.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"400\" height\u003d\"252\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe app has a number of small but useful preferences, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChoose upload directory/file\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAuto-uploading\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Google Music Manager in Ubuntu 12.10\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/ocveri.jpg\" alt\u003d\"Google Music Manager in Ubuntu 12.10\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBandwidth allocation\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDownload your entire library \u003cem\u003efrom\u003c/em\u003e the cloud\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIndicator Menu\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/menu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"menu\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/menu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"337\" height\u003d\"241\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA few things to note:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMusic Manager will not work in a virtual machine\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUploading only happens when the Music Manager app is running\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUploading a large collection will take time, so be patient\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eApps for Playback\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith your music collection safely transmuted into the cloud the next step knowing how to play them back.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo matter what OS you’re in you can always access your music by pointing a web-browser @ \u003ca title\u003d\"Google Play Music\" href\u003d\"http://play.google.com/music\"\u003eplay.google.com/music\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re using an Android or iOS device you’ll find Google Music apps in their respective app stores.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut in Ubuntu there is another option: a desktop music app called \u003cstrong\u003e‘Nuvola’.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nuvola-player.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"nuvola-player in Ubuntu\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/nuvola-player.jpg\" alt\u003d\"nuvola player in Ubuntu\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"298\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNuvola integrates Google Play Music into the Ubuntu desktop. This means you can use your keyboard media keys to control playback; the Ubuntu Sound Menu displays track information; notification bubbles appear, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInstalling Nuvola Player in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs Nuvola isn’t available from the Ubuntu Software Center you will need to add a PPA – a ‘personal package archive’ – to your system before you can install it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe quickest way to do this is using the Terminal, using the following commands:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:nuvola-player-builders/stable\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install nuvolaplayer\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter installation has completed launch ‘\u003cem\u003eNuvola\u003c/em\u003e‘ from the Dash, and select ‘Google Play Music’ from the app’s selection screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/5-nuvola-tweaks-for-an-awesome-google-play-music-experience-in-ubuntu\" title\u003d\"5 Nuvola Tweaks for An Awesome Google Play Music Experience in Ubuntu\"\u003e5 Nuvola Tweaks for An Awesome Google Play Music Experience in Ubuntu\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/new-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash\" title\u003d\"Search ‘Google Play’ from the Unity Dash\"\u003eSearch ‘Google Play’ from the Unity Dash\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/07/5-top-features-coming-to-nuvola-music-player-linux\" title\u003d\"5 Neat New Features Coming to Nuvola Music Player\"\u003e5 Neat New Features Coming to Nuvola Music Player\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dFyxClszlIOc:_d0Fh8R39B0:wBxX2hOkimM\"\u003e\u003cimg Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1352750517377","timestampUsec":"1352750517377726","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/75d01fda3984f167","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Download","android","google play","lenses"],"title":"Search ‘Google Play’ from the Unity Dash",
"published":1352750410,"updated":1352750410,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/8Lln34-bTJ8/new-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/new-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dnew-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fnew-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dnew-lens-lets-you-search-google-play-from-the-unity-dash\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new lens for Ubuntu 12.04 lets you search through \u003cem\u003eGoogle Play\u003c/em\u003e‘s catalog of apps, books and movies straight from Unity Dash.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe\u003cem\u003e Google Play Lens\u003c/em\u003e, created by Android developers \u003cem\u003eRotating Canvas,\u003c/em\u003e works just like any other Unity lens: you can use the lens directly, enter a search term and see results, or search straight from the \u003cem\u003eHome\u003c/em\u003e Lens.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"playlens\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/playlens.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this instance it’s the Google Play store being scoured for results – no mean feat for developers since the store doesn’t have a search API.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe resulting lens is okay, but it’s not perfect. It only displays 3 results (plus a ‘see more’ tile) and there is, at the time of writing, no way to filter these results down into\u003cem\u003e Apps, Books or Movies\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClicking on a search result (or the ‘view more results’ tile) opens up the \u003cem\u003eGoogle Play\u003c/em\u003e store in your default browser. From here you can queue an application/book/movie for installation on your phone or tablet, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe developers plan to add the ability to install apps directly from the lens itself in a future version.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCheeky Bonus\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRather cheekily, the \u003cem\u003eHome Lens\u003c/em\u003e lists an entry for their game ‘Choozak’ by default. It disappears as soon as you search but returns when you’re not.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"play-lens-23\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/play-lens-23.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003eInstall Google Play Lens in Ubuntu 12.04\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt present the Google Play Lens is only supported on Ubuntu 12.04, from where it can be installed from the developers PPA (usual caveats about third-party PPAs apply)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:abhshk-btra/rotatingcanvas\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install googleplaylens\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr by installing the .Deb package directly:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://launchpad.net/~abhshk-btra/+archive/rotatingcanvas/+files/googleplaylens_12.11_all.deb\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Google Play Lens for Unity \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eUbuntu 12.10 users \u003cem\u003ecan\u003c/em\u003e install the lens using the .deb package above, but don’t expect \u003cem\u003eUnity Previews\u003c/em\u003e to work with it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:right\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eVia \u003ca href\u003d\"http://rotatingcanvas.com/\"\u003eRoatingCanvas\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/splice-sudoku-in-a-petri-dish\" title\u003d\"Splice: Sudoku in a Petri Dish\"\u003eSplice: Sudoku in a Petri Dish\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-use-google-play-music-in-ubuntu\" title\u003d\"Google Play Music Arrives in Europe, Here’s height\u003d\"275\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA new ‘Ubuntu for Android’ commercial has appeared online.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe 2 minute animated spot explains the key concepts behind the technology, \u003ca title\u003d\"Meet Ubuntu for Android: The Next Step in Ubuntu’s Multi-Device Plan\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/02/ubuntu-for-android-announced\"\u003ewhich was first announced back in February\u003c/a\u003e, via irrelevant analogies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe width\u003d\"500\" height\u003d\"281\" src\u003d\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/iv1Z7bf4jXY?fs\u003d1\u0026amp;feature\u003doembed\" frameborder\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e “It’s not literally magic but it’s close.” \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Your quad core handset is a phone when it’s unplugged, but when you connect it to a monitor and keyboard and boom: you’ve got yourself a full Ubuntu-powered computer,”\u003c/em\u003e the narrator explains in the video.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“And since your PC is a phone you can make calls or sends texts from your desktop!”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ad ends with the narrator jovially advising viewers to ‘\u003cem\u003eget a Phone with Ubuntu for Android to start living a life less complicated’\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBut… It’s Still Not available\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSadly \u003cem\u003eMr Happy Narrator\u003c/em\u003e Man leaves out one slightly important point: you can’t get a phone with\u003cem\u003e Ubuntu for Android\u003c/em\u003e yet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat’s not to say that the idea hasn’t been popular. It has. Crazily so.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReams and reams of column pixels and social statuses have been given over to praise the concept since its announcement, and this cute animated ad with all its lighthearted sensibilities will only add to this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, the part of me that likes to indulge in wild speculation wants to ask \u003cem\u003ewhy\u003c/em\u003e this ad was released now when consumers can’t buy an Ubuntu for Android device, and no manufacturer or telecoms carrier has publicly announced plans to ship it?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIs its appearance a subtle prelude to a formal announcement? Is an Ubuphone finally in the offing?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLogical Joey says \u003cem\u003e‘probably not’.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s more likely that the ad was released to sustain and build on the awareness already generated for the technology. This pent-up demand could then be used by Canonical in negotiations with vendors interesting in rolling with it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBut for now this ad is just another tease at what might be – and no amount of cuteness can cushion the impatience generated by that.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated
