marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAre Ubuntu’s icons for the \u003cem\u003eSoftware Center, Update Manager\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eSoftware Sources \u003c/em\u003einconsistent and confusing for new users?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome users think so, including Sam Hewitt who has posted a set of proposed replacement icons to the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://lists.launchpad.net/unity-design/msg10093.html\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnity Design Mailing List.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Issue\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/current-icons.png\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"current-icons\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/current-icons.png\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"495\" height\u003d\"163\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003cp\u003e \u003cem\u003e “What does this box with an arrow have to do with updates?”\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe current icons are, he says, ‘\u003cstrong\u003eproblematic in their iconography and branding’, \u003c/strong\u003ewith two of the three in question using a box/package metaphor that could confuse new users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe cites a \u003ca title\u003d\"Bug Report #510212\" href\u003d\"https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/update-manager/+bug/510212\"\u003ebug report\u003c/a\u003e filed against Ubuntu’s \u003cem\u003eUpdate Manager, \u003c/em\u003ein which a user who conveys concern over the ‘legitimacy’ of Update Manager due to a lack of branding or documentation reference, as evidence of this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe Solution\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSam’s solution suggests unifying the design of the icons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/iconsss.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"iconsss\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/iconsss.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"495\" height\u003d\"139\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e“\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBy making [the icons] similar, they become related -rather: the other two become more related to the Ubuntu Software Center- and since the USC is a trusted application for users (or we want it to be), by association, the users ought trust the Update Manager and Software Sources,” \u003c/em\u003ehe argues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd it is hard to find fault with this. The current icons do indeed look disparate in their stylings, which is confusing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe “package” metaphor is also old and (largely) irrelevant. Ubuntu isn’t a hobby OS these days, it has millions of users worldwide. And many of these users aren’t looking to manage packages, they’re looking to install and remove applications.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe iconography needs to convey that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eNew Icon Theme\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith Canonical’s design team about to begin work on a new icon set for Ubuntu we do know that these icons will change. To what? That we don’t know, but you can bet your \u003cem\u003eSystem76 All-in-one\u003c/em\u003e that a whole raft of designs will be subjected to user testing before one is chosen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also shouldn’t overlook the original plan for the Ubuntu Software Center was to incorporate all of this separate package management tools into one unified interface (i.e the Ubuntu Software Center). That would solve this issue right away as one app equals one icon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMore Information\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo read more on Sam’s reasoning you can hit this button:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://docs.google.com/document/d/10WyeoBHMY-FmiEuGnKf8PSAGZ9GVMUQsh9-l8g8oSSI/edit\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Ubuntu Software Applications Icon Change Proposal \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOr if you just want to grab the icons and run you can hit this button:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://dl.dropbox.com/u/7027392/system-software-icons.tar.gz\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e System Software Icons (tar.gz) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca "published":1352724540,"updated":1352724540,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/fF8XtXEBOhg/unsettings-a-comprehensive-tweaking-tool-for-unity","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/unsettings-a-comprehensive-tweaking-tool-for-unity?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dunsettings-a-comprehensive-tweaking-tool-for-unity"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Funsettings-a-comprehensive-tweaking-tool-for-unity%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dunsettings-a-comprehensive-tweaking-tool-for-unity\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Unity desktop is more customizable than it’s often given credit for, you just have to install an extra app to unlock its potential.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral such applications are available, including \u003cem\u003eMyUnity\u003c/em\u003e,\u003cem\u003e Ubuntu Tweak\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eCCSM\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003e‘UnSettings’\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca title\u003d\"Unsettings Home Page\" href\u003d\"http://www.florian-diesch.de/software/unsettings/\"\u003eUnSettings\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e is arguably the most comprehensive of these, as well as being the easiest to use. Whatever your Unity tweaking needs \u003cem\u003eUnSettings\u003c/em\u003e will have you covered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFeatures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/unsettings-explained.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"unsettings-explained\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/unsettings-explained.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"288\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnsettings\u003c/em\u003e has been designed for use with Unity desktop environment and lets you easily change or adjust a number of Unity’s default settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing it you can:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChange GTK and icon Theme\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChange font sizes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTweak Unity Launcher look/behaviour\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDisable Overlay Scrollbars, App Menu, HUD, etc\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdjust Dash settings\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnable desktop icons\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRestore default settings\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003eAnd plenty more besides.\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnsettings \u003c/em\u003ealso lets you save your settings so you can import and apply them to a different computer running Unity – handy!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003eFor an overview of its interface refer to the annotated screenshot above.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHow to Install Unsettings in Ubuntu 12.10\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we list five neat things you can adjust using the application, you’ll need to install it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe application is in a perpetual beta. This means that you should expect bugs, crashes and flaws, some of which include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSwitching launcher back to \u003cem\u003e‘Show Always’\u003c/em\u003e doesn’t work\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePanel opacity change cannot be ‘undone’ using unsettings\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSome changes require log out to take effect\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnsettings is \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e available to install form the Ubuntu Software Center, which means to install it you’ll either need to add its PPA to your \u003cem\u003eSoftware Sources\u003c/em\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo add-apt-repository \u003cstrong\u003eppa:diesch/testing\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003esudo apt-get update \u0026amp;\u0026amp; sudo apt-get install unsettings\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eOr download the .Deb package installer from the link below:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.florian-diesch.de/software/unsettings/dist/unsettings_0.08ubuntu1_all.deb\" title\u003d\"Download Unsettings for Ubuntu 12.10\"\u003e Download Unsettings 0.8 (.deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Change icon theme\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu’s default icon set isn’t that bad, but for added splash of eye-candy there are a number of slick third party icon sets available for use in Ubuntu. Popular ones include the tiled-tastic look of \u003ca title\u003d\"Faenza Icon Set Updates, Adds New App Icons\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/10/faenza-icon-set-updates-adds-new-app-icons\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFaenza\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and the \u003cem\u003eMetro \u003c/em\u003einspired \u003ca title\u003d\"Ubuntu Icon Theme ‘Nitrux’ Gets Updated With New Icons\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/09/nitrux-umd-gets-updated\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eNitrux-MD\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/icons.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"icons\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/icons.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you’ve installed an icon theme you’ll need to use\u003cem\u003e Unsettings\u003c/em\u003e to ‘apply’ it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOpen \u003cem\u003eUnSettings\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGo to \u003cem\u003e‘Theme’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSelect your desired icon theme from the drop-down menu\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClick \u003cem\u003e‘Apply’\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3 style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003e2. Disable Bluetooth in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI rarely use the Bluetooth on my netbooks or laptops, so the fact that Ubuntu insits on enabling it \u003cem\u003eby default\u003c/em\u003e every time I reboot sucks – both figuratively and, where my battery is concerned, literally!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnsettings\u003c/em\u003e has a switch for disabling it properly. You’ll find it at the top of the ‘\u003cem\u003eIndicators’\u003c/em\u003e section.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/bluetooth.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"bluetooth\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/bluetooth.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"450\" height\u003d\"247\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Manage Unity Web Apps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUbuntu 12.10 debuted some nifty ’web apps’ integration with the Ubuntu desktop. It’s handy feature but far from complete. At present there is no easy way to disable/enable permissions for websites at a later date.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnSettings to the rescue…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/webapps.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"webapps\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/webapps.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Adjust Fonts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce upon a time I \u003ca title\u003d\"6 Desktop Fonts to try in Ubuntu\" href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2010/03/6-desktop-fonts-to-try-in-ubuntu\"\u003ebemoaned Ubuntu’s choice of font size for the desktop\u003c/a\u003e - it was huge! Thankfully for me, the introduction of the ‘Ubuntu font’ was just around the corner, and would solve this bug-bear of mine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut if you’re not happy with the default font, font size, or hinting \u003cem\u003eUnsettings\u003c/em\u003e has a wealth of settings to play with.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/fonts.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"fonts\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/fonts.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Add or Remove Workspaces\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAre 4 workspaces too many or not enough for you? It seems everyone has a different preference. \u003cem\u003eUnSettings\u003c/em\u003e lets you choose your own preference.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/workspaces.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"workspaces\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/workspaces.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfF8XtXEBOhg:xsCqT7L7jZQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfF8XtXEBOhg:xsCqT7L7jZQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfF8XtXEBOhg:xsCqT7L7jZQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?i\u003dfF8XtXEBOhg:xsCqT7L7jZQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?a\u003dfF8XtXEBOhg:xsCqT7L7jZQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/d0od?d\u003dyIl2AUoC8zA\" border\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003cimg src\u003d\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/d0od/~4/fF8XtXEBOhg\" height\u003d\"1\" width\u003d\"1\"\u003e"
},"author":"Joey-Elijah Sneddon","likingUsers":[],"comments":[],"annotations":[],"origin":{"streamId":"feed/http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/feed","title":"OMG! Ubuntu!","htmlUrl":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk"}},{"isReadStateLocked":true,"crawlTimeMsec":"1352649896227","timestampUsec":"1352649896227898","id":"tag:google.com,2005:reader/item/54a91910bc976d39","categories":["user/00694065464150071004/state/com.google/read","Download","How To","aura","chromeos"],"title":"[How To] Run ChromeOS in Ubuntu","published":1352649903,
"updated":1352649903,"alternate":[{"href":"http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/d0od/~3/d-uYaphJKsc/how-to-run-chromeos-in-ubuntu","type":"text/html"}],"canonical":[{"href":"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/11/how-to-run-chromeos-in-ubuntu?utm_source\u003drss\u0026utm_medium\u003drss\u0026utm_campaign\u003dhow-to-run-chromeos-in-ubuntu"}],"content":{"direction":"ltr","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ciframe src\u003d\"http://feedads.g.doubleclick.net/~ah/f/4n8ilq82fq4f7vj94j6mqqffhg/300/250?ca\u003d1\u0026amp;fh\u003d280#http%3A%2F%2Fwww.omgubuntu.co.uk%2F2012%2F11%2Fhow-to-run-chromeos-in-ubuntu%3Futm_source%3Drss%26utm_medium%3Drss%26utm_campaign%3Dhow-to-run-chromeos-in-ubuntu\" width\u003d\"100%\" height\u003d\"280\" frameborder\u003d\"0\" scrolling\u003d\"no\" marginwidth\u003d\"0\" marginheight\u003d\"0\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-11.58.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-11.58\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-11.58.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"289\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEver wanted to play with ChromeOS? A new unofficial ‘hack’ for Ubuntu lets you do just that – and with a minimum of fuss.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/dz0ny/lightdm-login-chromeos\"\u003e\u003cem\u003elightdm-chromeos-login\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e project, by \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/dz0ny\"\u003edz0ny\u003c/a\u003e, installs the ChromiumOS desktop and its Aura window manager \u003cem\u003ewithin\u003c/em\u003e Ubuntu. It even lets you login it to a full-blown Chrome desktop straight from the login screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut if using it on its own isn’t for you then be sure to try it out in windowed mode, which runs on the Ubuntu desktop:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/chromeos-in-ubuntu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"chromeos-in-ubuntu\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/chromeos-in-ubuntu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLimitations and Possibilities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, before anyone gets overly excited it’s important to realise what this “port” does and doesn’t allow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhilst it does make the ChromiumOS desktop in its entirety (that is browser, window manager, app launcher, status bar, notifications, etc) accessible from within Ubuntu it \u003cstrong\u003eremains separate \u003cem\u003efrom\u003c/em\u003e Ubuntu. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat means that whilst you can use it in Ubuntu you can’t run your Ubuntu apps in it (at least not yet), nor can you open an app within the ChromiumOS desktop and use it “in” Ubuntu.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo regardless of whether you run it windowed on your Ubuntu desktop or ‘login’ to a window-less desktop session running ChromiumOS full-screen from the Unity Greeter, the features and functions remain the same.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDisappointed? Don’t be. ChromiumOS is supposed to be a lightweight web-centric OS, and this port is giving you just that – albeit in a very convenient way; No Chromebook or LiveUSb needed here!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/mnu.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"mnu\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/mnu.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"400\" height\u003d\"448\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat Works\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you buy a Chromebook one thing you can count on is the OS being ready to work straight away. No fuss, no installs, no waiting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd despite this ‘hack’ being unofficial, not to mention running on a different OS, it has maintained as much functionality as it can from the get-go. The following features are all working at the time of writing:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGoogle Account login\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChrome Sync\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdobe Flash \u0026amp; Google Talk Plugins (if Chrome is installed in Ubuntu)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eJava (if it’s installed in Ubuntu)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSimple development for ChromeOS specific plugins/extensions(~/chrome-os/user)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHardware acceleration\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTablet mode\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e64bit Support\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne important thing to note is that ‘native’ networking is not up and running yet (remember, it’s running on top of Ubuntu rather than on its own).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut providing Ubuntu is connected to the internet then so is the ChromiumOS build. This is all automatic, no tweaking needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhat you can’t do\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn to the potential drawbacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith this project being barely one week old it shouldn’t surprise you to learn than a number of features and functions aren’t yet working. These include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eImporting images from camera, USB, etc\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eVarious system controls/hardware functions\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGuest login\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAuto-updating\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBattery information\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/battery.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"battery\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/battery.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"352\" height\u003d\"170\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDownload ChromeOS in Ubuntu (64bit Only)\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs \u003cem\u003elightdm-login-chromeos\u003c/em\u003e is \u003cstrong\u003estill in development\u003c/strong\u003e the inexperienced or stable-system dependant should steer clear of installing this. Suffice to say, it has locked up my computer a few times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe “app” is provided  as a .deb installer for Ubuntu 12.04 or 12.10 \u003cstrong\u003e64bit only\u003c/strong\u003e. Installing it in 32bit Ubuntu will work, but ChromeOS won’t run.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/dz0ny/lightdm-login-chromeos/blob/master/lightdm-login-chromiumos_1.0_amd64.deb?raw\u003dtrue\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e Download ‘LightDM Login ChromeOS’ (.deb) \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eWhen the package has finished downloading simply double-click on it to begin installation via the Ubuntu Software Center. During installation Ubuntu will warn you that the package is of ‘bad quality’ – it’s safe to ignore this (even Google’s Chrome browser installer gets this warning).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:left\"\u003eAs the package installs it will download a canary build of the Chromium OS browser and its Aura window manager. These are fetched very quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRunning ChromiumOS in Ubuntu\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow ChromiumOS is installed it’s time to run it. The first step is to open a terminal and run\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003echromeos\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eto launch the OS in a windowed mode. It’s best to do this first so that a) you can see if it’s working and b) to go through the set-up process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter setting up ChromiumOS you’ll land on the ChromiumOS desktop. I never had a desktop background the first time it showed for me, so to add some colour right-click on an empty part of the desktop and choose\u003cem\u003e ‘Set Wallpaper…’. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-14.46.jpg\"\u003e\u003cimg title\u003d\"Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-14.46\" src\u003d\"http://cloudfront.omgubuntu.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Screen-Shot-2012-11-11-at-14.46.jpg\" alt\u003d\"\" width\u003d\"499\" height\u003d\"391\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you use the Chrome/ium browser then all of your bookmarks, themes, web-apps and extensions will be silently syncing in the background. Google Drive will begin syncing the first time you open \u003cem\u003eFiles \u0026gt; Google Drive.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt was at this point that I experienced lock-ups and freezes. If this happens to you, just close the Terminal window to kill ChromiumOS.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor further information, or to report bugs/contribute, see the projects’ wiki page:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style\u003d\"text-align:center\"\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://github.com/dz0ny/lightdm-login-chromeos\" title\u003d\"\"\u003e LightDM Login ChromeOS on GitHub \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRelated Posts\u003c/h2\u003e\u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href\u003d\"http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2012/03/download-chrome-oss-50-new-wallpapers\"
